question: When considering an Application for Listing, what actions may the Regulator take regarding admission of Securities to the Official List, and how does the authority under section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR relate to the circumstance-based power described in subsection (2)?
gold_answer: The Regulator has power to manage outcomes at the listing stage by either declining the Application for Listing or controlling the terms on which Securities are admitted to the Official List through conditions or restrictions, including later changing or removing those conditions or restrictions. [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] In addition, section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR specifically supports the Regulator’s ability to impose conditions or restrictions on admission to the Official List and to vary or withdraw them, which aligns with (and is reflected in) the same set of actions described for admission decisions in the listing context. [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226] The circumstance-based framing in the listing provision means these actions (refusal, or the imposition/variation/withdrawal of conditions or restrictions) are exercisable in the circumstances identified in subsection (2), rather than as an unqualified discretion. [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] Practically, this links the FSMR section 52(1)(b) authority over admission conditions to the listing decision pathway that also includes the option to refuse the Application for Listing, with both sets of actions operating within the subsection (2) circumstances. [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226] [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b]

question: If the Regulator is looking at an Application for Listing, what can it do (including refusing the application), and how does section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR fit with the rule that these actions are only available in the circumstances in subsection (2)?
gold_answer: For an Application for Listing, the Regulator can choose to refuse the Application for Listing, or it can allow admission of Securities to the Official List but attach conditions or restrictions to that admission. [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] If conditions or restrictions are used, the Regulator can also later change them or remove them entirely (vary or withdraw them). [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] Section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR provides the underlying authority for the admission-related part of this: it expressly allows the Regulator to impose conditions or restrictions on admission of Securities to the Official List and to vary or withdraw those conditions or restrictions. [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226] The listing provision adds an important boundary: the Regulator’s ability to refuse the application or to impose/vary/withdraw admission conditions is stated to apply in the circumstances specified in subsection (2). [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] Taken together, section 52(1)(b) explains the scope of the admission-condition tools, while the listing provision ties both refusal and those tools to the subsection (2) circumstances. [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226] [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b]

question: For a Reporting Entity, how do the section 82 FSMR obligation to appoint an auditor and the requirement that the auditor be appointed in accordance with Part 15 and any Rules made for that Part operate together when making the appointment?
gold_answer: A Reporting Entity must ensure it has an auditor and that the appointment is made through the specific framework referenced for auditor appointments. [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] The baseline obligation is that the Reporting Entity is required to appoint an auditor under section 82 of the FSMR, so the entity cannot omit making an appointment. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] In addition, the appointment is not merely a general designation; it must be carried out in accordance with Part 15 and any Rules made for the purposes of that Part, meaning the Reporting Entity must follow that Part 15/Rules pathway when appointing the auditor. [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] Read together, section 82 establishes the duty to appoint, while the Part 15 and related Rules condition specifies the required method or procedural basis for how the auditor is appointed. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] Accordingly, compliance requires both (i) making an auditor appointment and (ii) ensuring that appointment is made under the Part 15 and Rules framework, rather than outside it. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb]

question: If a Reporting Entity needs to appoint an auditor, what does it have to do, and what process does it have to follow, based on section 82 of the FSMR and the Part 15/Rules requirement?
gold_answer: A Reporting Entity must both appoint an auditor and make that appointment using the specific appointment framework referenced for financial reports. [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] Section 82 of the FSMR creates the requirement for a Reporting Entity to appoint an auditor, so the entity has a clear duty to make an appointment rather than leaving the role unfilled. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] The financial reports provision adds that the Reporting Entity must have an auditor appointed in accordance with Part 15 and any Rules made for the purposes of that Part, so the appointment must be done through that Part 15 and Rules route. [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] Putting these together, the “what” is appointing an auditor (the obligation), and the “how” is that the appointment must be made in line with Part 15 and any Rules made for that Part (the required basis for the appointment). [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] This means a Reporting Entity should treat Part 15 and its Rules as the governing process for fulfilling the section 82 appointment duty. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb]

question: Where an Applicant/Authorised Person seeks FSRA approval for its FSP to cover a Regulated Activity in relation to both conventional assets (e.g., Securities or Derivatives) and Spot Commodities, how should the fee outcome be determined if the Regulator considers it fair and reasonable to reduce, waive or refund fees in that particular case?
gold_answer: If an Applicant/Authorised Person will undertake a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets in addition to Spot Commodities, it must seek approval from the FSRA for its FSP to permit it to carry out its Regulated Activity in relation to both asset types. [#SRC:e801f4a4-1a6e-4c91-92d6-724eec350cc0] In that dual-asset scenario, the fee outcome is not automatically cumulative across the conventional and Spot Commodity-related Regulated Activities where the FSRA exercises discretion to reduce or waive a fee, taking into account the high fees already imposed on Applicants/Authorised Persons conducting Regulated Activities using Spot Commodities. [#SRC:e801f4a4-1a6e-4c91-92d6-724eec350cc0] This aligns with the Regulator’s broader power to reduce, waive, or refund all or part of any fee (including supplementary or late payment fees) at any time, provided it considers that doing so would be fair and reasonable in the circumstances of the particular case. [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036] Accordingly, when the Regulator reaches a fairness-and-reasonableness view for the specific case, it may implement that relief in a way that prevents fees from stacking cumulatively across the two asset types, rather than charging full fees for both without adjustment. [#SRC:e801f4a4-1a6e-4c91-92d6-724eec350cc0] [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036]

question: Where an Issuer makes an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM and has published a Prospectus, what must the Issuer (or the person responsible for the issue of the Prospectus) do if, after the Prospectus is issued, a significant change occurs or a material mistake/inaccuracy or significant new matter arises, and what baseline prospectus requirement anchors this obligation?
gold_answer: In this scenario, the Issuer’s baseline obligation is to publish a Prospectus when it wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] Once that Prospectus has been issued, if at any time afterward there is a significant change in information, a material mistake or inaccuracy affecting a matter in the Prospectus, or a significant new matter arises, the Issuer or the person responsible for issuing the Prospectus must issue a supplementary prospectus. [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] The supplementary prospectus must (i) set out details of the relevant change, mistake, inaccuracy, or new matter, and (ii) meet the requirements referenced in section 62(1). [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] The timing trigger is explicitly “after the issue of a Prospectus” and applies whenever the specified events occur, meaning the duty is ongoing for the period after issuance rather than limited to a single update point. [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] This supplementary-prospectus duty is therefore an extension of the initial prospectus publication requirement that applies to Offers of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd]

question: If an Issuer is offering Securities to the public in or from ADGM and has already put out a Prospectus, what should happen if something important changes or a big error is found after the Prospectus is issued, and how does this connect to the original need to publish a Prospectus?
gold_answer: For an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, the Issuer is expected to publish a Prospectus as part of the applicable requirements for such offers. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] After that Prospectus has been issued, the rules then require an additional step if certain events occur: if at any time there is a significant change, or a material mistake or inaccuracy affecting something in the Prospectus, or a significant new matter arises, the Issuer (or the person responsible for issuing the Prospectus) must produce a supplementary prospectus. [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] That supplementary prospectus has two core content/compliance elements: it must describe the relevant change, mistake, inaccuracy, or new matter, and it must comply with the requirements in section 62(1). [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] The link between the two texts is that the supplementary prospectus obligation only makes sense once the Issuer has already met the initial prospectus publication requirement for the public offer in or from ADGM. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] The trigger is explicitly tied to the period after the Prospectus is issued, and it applies whenever the specified kinds of developments occur. [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c]

question: Where the Regulator considers a name issue under Section 117 of FSMR, how does the Regulator’s power to make a direction apply across (i) a Fund, (ii) a Sub-Fund, and (iii) a class of Units in a Fund, and what specific action may the Regulator require and from whom when the name is undesirable, misleading, or conflicts with another name?
gold_answer: If the Regulator forms the view that a relevant name is undesirable, misleading, or conflicts with a name used by another product, the Regulator has power to issue a direction under Section 117 of FSMR covering not only a Fund and a Sub-Fund but also a class of Units in a Fund. [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295] When exercising that power in relation to a Fund or a Sub Fund, the Regulator may require a concrete remedial step: it may direct the Fund Manager to change the name of the Fund or the Sub Fund. [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff] The triggering conditions align across both passages: the Regulator’s assessment (including where the name conflicts with another Fund/Sub-Fund name, or is undesirable or misleading) is the basis for intervention. [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff] The scope of what can be assessed for undesirability, misleading character, or conflict is broader in that it expressly includes a class of Units in a Fund in addition to Funds and Sub-Funds. [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295] Accordingly, compliance planning should treat the Fund Manager as the directed party for Fund/Sub Fund name changes, while recognizing that the Regulator’s naming-direction power extends to class-of-Units naming issues as well. [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff] [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that does not follow a non-mandatory requirement in a Mining Reporting Standard (for example, a non-mandatory item in Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code), what must the Mining Reporting Entity include in the disclosure, and how does this relate to the Regulator’s expectation of compliance under Rule 11.2.1(1) and the explanation approach referenced in Rule 11.2.2?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is expected to comply fully with non-mandatory requirements in a Mining Reporting Standard, but if it does not, it must transparently explain the departure within the disclosure itself. [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124] Specifically, where a disclosure does not meet a non-mandatory requirement in the relevant Mining Reporting Standard, the Mining Reporting Entity must include a statement in that disclosure describing both how the disclosure differs and why it differs from the non-mandatory requirement. [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f] This disclosure-level statement operationalizes the Regulator’s expectation that non-mandatory requirements are followed unless the entity explains non-compliance, including in relation to non-mandatory items such as those found in Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code. [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124] In practical terms, the Mining Reporting Entity should (i) identify the specific non-mandatory requirement it did not meet, (ii) describe the nature of the difference, and (iii) provide the reason for that difference, all within the disclosure. [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f] This approach aligns with the referenced expectation to explain non-compliance in accordance with Rule 11.2.2 when non-mandatory requirements are not followed. [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure doesn’t follow a non-mandatory part of a Mining Reporting Standard (like something in Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code), what exactly has to be written in the disclosure, and how does that fit with the Regulator’s expectation to comply or explain under Rule 11.2.1(1) and Rule 11.2.2?
gold_answer: If a Mining Reporting Entity does not follow a non-mandatory requirement in a Mining Reporting Standard, it still needs to address that gap directly and clearly in the disclosure. [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124] The disclosure must contain a statement that explains both (1) how the disclosure is different from the non-mandatory requirement and (2) why it is different. [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f] This is consistent with the Regulator’s stated expectation that the Mining Reporting Entity should fully comply with non-mandatory requirements (including examples such as Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code) unless it provides an explanation of non-compliance. [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124] In other words, the “comply or explain” idea is implemented by requiring the explanation to be included inside the disclosure whenever the non-mandatory requirement is not met. [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f] This also matches the reference to explaining non-compliance in accordance with Rule 11.2.2 when the entity does not follow non-mandatory requirements. [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124]

question: If a Listed Entity hasn’t fully followed APP 4, what does it need to say in its annual financial report, and what extra disclosure does the Regulator expect in the Prospectus and later under Rule 9.2.10—and what happens if the statements are inaccurate or false?
gold_answer: When a Listed Entity has not fully adopted APP 4, its annual financial report must clearly report both the status of adoption and the reasons and steps taken, and this should sit alongside the Regulator’s expectation that similar explanations and alternative measures are disclosed in the Prospectus and then continued under Rule 9.2.10. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] [#SRC:ff5bac8d-3dc7-46dd-a9ce-b0c32a42422e] In the annual financial report, the Listed Entity must state whether it has adopted the APP 4 best practice standards (the Corporate Governance Principles). [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] If adoption is not full (including partial adoption), it must explain why and describe what actions, if any, it has taken to achieve compliance to the extent the standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] The report must also include a statement by Directors on whether, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance, supported by information and assumptions and with qualifications if necessary. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] Separately, where a Reporting Entity does not adopt APP 4 or does so only partially, the Regulator expects the reasons and any alternative measures adopted to achieve the intended outcomes to be disclosed in the Prospectus and thereafter under Rule 9.2.10. [#SRC:ff5bac8d-3dc7-46dd-a9ce-b0c32a42422e] If the disclosures contain inaccurate or false representations, civil liability may be imposed under section 70 of the FSMR. [#SRC:ff5bac8d-3dc7-46dd-a9ce-b0c32a42422e]

question: For an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, how should the Resolution Pack requirement to include the master list of all Client Accounts be satisfied in terms of the specific data fields that must appear on that master list?
gold_answer: To satisfy the Resolution Pack requirement for an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, the master list of all Client Accounts must be included in the Resolution Pack and must be maintained with the specific account details prescribed for that master list. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] The Resolution Pack scope expressly includes the master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments, so the pack should contain the master list(s) that the Authorised Person maintains for those Client Accounts. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] In maintaining that master list, the Authorised Person must ensure it details, for each Client Account, the account name, account number, and where the account is located. [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] It must also identify the bank and include the bank’s address and contact information, and it must record the account’s terms and conditions. [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] Finally, the master list must show whether each account is open or closed and the date it was opened or closed, so that the Resolution Pack contains a complete and status-aware inventory of Client Accounts. [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d]

question: When putting together the Resolution Pack, what information has to be on the master list of all Client Accounts that the Authorised Person must keep?
gold_answer: The Resolution Pack must include the master list (or master lists) of all Client Accounts, and that list must be kept with the specific details required for each account. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] The Resolution Pack requirement applies to an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business and explicitly calls for master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments, so the pack should contain the maintained master list covering those Client Accounts. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] The master list itself must include, for every Client Account, the account’s name and number and where the account is held (its location). [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] It also has to identify the bank and provide the bank’s address and contact details, and it must capture the account’s terms and conditions. [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] In addition, the list must show whether the account is open or closed and record the opening date or closure date, so the Resolution Pack includes an up-to-date view of each Client Account’s status. [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d]

question: When a Prospectus has been filed with the Regulator and is intended to be treated as an “Approved Prospectus” for the purposes of subsection (1), what specific approval action must the Regulator take, and how does that action apply where the Prospectus comprises multiple documents under the Rules-based approval concept?
gold_answer: A filed Prospectus is treated as an “Approved Prospectus” only when the Regulator has taken an affirmative approval step, not merely because it has been filed. Under the Regulations’ framing, a Prospectus qualifies as an Approved Prospectus if it is approved by the Regulator in line with the requirements prescribed in the Rules, and references to a Prospectus in the Regulations are generally to an Approved Prospectus unless context indicates otherwise. [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1] In addition, for the filing to result in an Approved Prospectus for the stated statutory purpose, the Regulator must issue the Applicant a notice that states the Regulator’s approval. [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e] That notice must cover the Prospectus (or, where applicable, the Supplementary Prospectus). [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e] Where the Prospectus consists of multiple documents, the notice must expressly approve all of those multiple documents, aligning the practical evidence of approval (the notice) with the Rules-based approval concept used to define an Approved Prospectus. [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e] [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1]

question: If someone says a Prospectus is “approved” just because it was filed with the Regulator, what extra step is needed for it to count as an Approved Prospectus, and what changes if the Prospectus is made up of multiple documents?
gold_answer: Filing a Prospectus with the Regulator, by itself, does not make it an Approved Prospectus; an additional approval step is required. Specifically, the Regulator must issue the Applicant a notice that states the Regulator’s approval of the Prospectus (or, if relevant, the Supplementary Prospectus). [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e] This notice-based approval is the concrete action that turns a filed document into an approved one for the stated statutory purpose. [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e] Separately, the Regulations explain that a Prospectus is an Approved Prospectus when it is approved by the Regulator in accordance with the requirements prescribed in the Rules, and that when the Regulations refer to a “Prospectus” they generally mean an Approved Prospectus unless the context requires otherwise. [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1] If the Prospectus is made up of multiple documents, the Regulator’s notice must cover approval of all the multiple documents, not just one part, so that the approval aligns with how the Prospectus is constituted. [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e]

question: When an Authorised Person is establishing and maintaining systems and controls to deter/prevent and report suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes, how should it reflect best practices given the evolving nature of Financial Crime, and what concrete measures are indicated as examples for those systems and controls?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must have effective systems and controls that both (i) deter and prevent suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes against the Authorised Person and its Customers and (ii) enable reporting of suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes to the relevant authorities. [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] In establishing the systems and controls required for this purpose, the Authorised Person should also observe best practices, explicitly recognizing that Financial Crime evolves and that controls should be designed with that changing risk in mind. [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7] Practically, this means the required fraud/Financial Crime framework should be implemented and maintained in a way that can support both prevention/deterrence and reporting outcomes, while incorporating concrete control features that are identified as examples of best practice. [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7] Examples of such best-practice measures include using secure authentication, deploying biometrics, and monitoring customer behaviour metrics within anti-fraud and anti-Financial Crime systems and controls. [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7] Taken together, the obligation to establish and maintain effective systems and controls is met not only by having controls in place for deterrence/prevention and reporting, but by building them using these kinds of evolving best-practice techniques. [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7]

question: If an ADGM Green Portfolio has (1) assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy under Rule 3.8.4(a) and (2) assets that track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark under Rule 3.8.4(b), which part needs the third-party attestation and how often must it be done?
gold_answer: Only the portion of Eligible Green Portfolio Assets invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy under Rule 3.8.4(a) is subject to the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement, while the portion included in or otherwise tracking an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark under Rule 3.8.4(b) is excluded from that requirement. [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e] [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86] For the in-scope (taxonomy-aligned) portion, the Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager of an ADGM Green Portfolio must appoint a third party to attest to compliance with the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement. [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e] The attestation must be maintained on an ongoing basis and performed at least annually for that in-scope portion. [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e] By contrast, Rule 3.8.6 states that the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark in accordance with Rule 3.8.4(b), so those assets should not be counted when determining what the third party must attest to. [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86] This means the Investment Manager should apply the attestation only to the taxonomy-aligned slice and exclude the benchmark-tracking slice. [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e] [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86]

question: When a person is making an Offer of a Unit, how do the Chapter-level non-application provisions interact with the Rulebook’s chapter 4 Prospectus content and structure requirements for Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds, and where are the applicable Prospectus requirements instead located?
gold_answer: For an Offer involving Units, the combined effect is that the Chapter’s provisions (and Rules made for that Chapter) do not apply to the person making the Offer, and the Rulebook’s chapter 4 Prospectus content and structure requirements are also not applicable to Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds. [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a] [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] In this context, the Rulebook makes a specific carve-out for Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds by stating that chapter 4 Prospectus requirements (including content and structure) do not apply to those Prospectuses. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] Instead, the Prospectus requirements that do apply to an Offer of Units of Funds are located in the Fund Rules, which are identified as the source of applicable Prospectus requirements for such Offers. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] This allocation is reinforced by the statement that Section 57(1) of FSMR disapplies chapter 4 of the Rulebook to Fund Prospectuses, aligning the Rulebook’s chapter 4 non-application for Units of Funds with the broader non-application framework for the Chapter in relation to making an Offer of a Unit. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a]

question: If someone is making an Offer of a Unit, do the rules in this Chapter apply to them, and if the Offer is for Units of Funds, where do they find the Prospectus requirements instead of chapter 4 of the Rulebook?
gold_answer: A person making an Offer of a Unit is not subject to the provisions in this Chapter or the Rules made for the purposes of this Chapter in relation to that activity. [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a] Separately, when the Prospectus relates to Units of Funds, the Rulebook’s chapter 4 Prospectus requirements—covering content and structure—do not apply to those Prospectuses. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] Putting these together for an Offer that involves Units of Funds, you should not look to chapter 4 of the Rulebook for the Prospectus content/structure requirements, because that chapter is expressly stated not to apply to Fund Prospectuses. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] Instead, the Prospectus requirements that apply to an Offer of Units of Funds are found in the Fund Rules, which are identified as the applicable source for such Offers. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] This approach is consistent with the statement that Section 57(1) of FSMR disapplies chapter 4 of the Rulebook to Fund Prospectuses, reinforcing that chapter 4 is not the governing Prospectus framework for Units of Funds even though the Chapter itself is also stated not to apply to a person in relation to making an Offer of a Unit. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a]

question: If an Authorised Person decides to lower the value of its Exposures using things like Collateral, netting, guarantees, Credit Derivatives, or securitisation, what written policy does it need to have about using exclusions in Rule 4.15.12?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person chooses to reduce the value of its Exposures using the credit risk mitigation recognition options available in this Section, it must also ensure it has documented its policy for using any exclusions in Rule 4.15.12. [#SRC:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270] The need for a documented exclusions policy sits alongside the Section’s statement that the Authorised Person may, at its discretion, reduce Exposure values using one or more specified mechanisms. [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3] Concretely: - The Section permits discretionary reductions by, among other methods, applying specific provisions (that are not general provisions/reserves), netting claims and liabilities to a Counterparty if Section 4.13 conditions are met, recognising qualifying Collateral under the FCSA/FCCA approaches subject to Section 4.13 requirements, using eligible guarantees under Section 4.13.9, recognising qualifying Credit Derivatives included in Rule 4.13.11 if the transaction meets that Section’s conditions, and recognising securitisation transfers if Section 4.14 conditions are met. [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3] - Independently of which of those methods it uses, the Authorised Person must document its policy for the use of any exclusions in Rule 4.15.12. [#SRC:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270] So, whenever exclusions in Rule 4.15.12 are used in this context, they must be supported by a documented policy, even though the Exposure reductions themselves are discretionary. [#SRC:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270] [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3]

question: If a Fund Manager tells its auditor in writing to audit the Fund’s financial statements using IAASB standards, what does the Fund Manager then need to make sure the auditor actually says in the Fund Auditor’s Report (including anything that can be about a Sub-Fund and the annual accounting period)?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager’s responsibilities span both the engagement step and the content-control step: it must give a written requirement to its auditor to carry out an audit of the Fund’s financial statements under the relevant IAASB standards and to produce a Fund Auditor’s Report on those audited statements. [#SRC:8949f938-33e5-4393-a256-021917125579] After that, when arranging for the report to be produced, the Fund Manager must ensure the Auditor includes specific statements in the Fund Auditor’s Report. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce] These include whether the financial statements were properly prepared using the financial reporting standards the Fund adopted under FUNDS, and whether the statements give a true and fair view of the Fund’s financial position. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce] The true-and-fair view must cover net income and net gains or losses of the Fund Property (or, if applicable, the Fund Property attributable to the Sub-Fund) for the annual accounting period, and the financial position of the Fund or Sub-Fund at the end of that period. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce] The Auditor must also state if proper accounting records have not been kept or if the statements do not match records/returns or do not comply with applicable reporting standards, confirm whether it received all needed information and explanations, address consistency of the Directors’ report or Fund Manager’s report with the financial statements, and include any other matter required by FUNDS. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity says its economic assumptions are “commercially sensitive” in a Rule 11.9.1 forecast disclosure, what must it still explain, and when might it be hard to justify calling those assumptions sensitive? Also, what must it disclose about the Production Target used for the forecast?
gold_answer: Even where a Mining Reporting Entity believes its material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it must still include the material economic assumptions used for the forecast financial information and provide a statement that it considers them commercially sensitive together with an explanation of the methodology used to determine those assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] It must also disclose all other material assumptions used in preparing the forecast financial information. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] However, the Mining Reporting Entity should be cautious about asserting sensitivity where it is not warranted: if it has not yet entered into any commercially sensitive contracts that underpin assumptions such as commodity price, capital expenditure, or operational expenditure, it would be difficult to form a view that information about those assumptions is commercially sensitive. [#TGT:3b4ca4c9-5690-4bae-8c30-3d06642d6e95] In addition to assumptions, the disclosure must state the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, and it must include all information required for that Production Target (including the information contained in Rule 11.8.3). [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]

question: When applying Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6 to a reverse repurchase agreement, how should the firm determine the exposure amount (E) using the reverse repo formula, and what methodology must it use to calculate the market value (MV) inputs for both the Securities and any Collateral?
gold_answer: For a reverse repurchase agreement assessed under Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6, the exposure amount (E) is determined by taking the amount paid (or Collateral given) and subtracting the market value (MV) of the Securities received. [#TGT:4262e773-aad2-4422-b6b3-fea38fd9d619] To apply that formula correctly, the MV of Securities and the value of Collateral used as inputs must be calculated using the credit risk mitigation (CRM) provisions specified in Section 4.13, because Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6 require those MV and collateral values to be computed in accordance with that CRM methodology. [#SRC:379a83c2-96da-4b2a-acea-f8779444878d] In practice, this means the firm should (i) identify the relevant reverse repurchase agreement components (amount paid or Collateral given, and the Securities received), (ii) compute the MV of the Securities received using the Section 4.13 CRM approach, and (iii) compute the value of any Collateral (including Collateral given, where relevant to the reverse repo inputs) using the same Section 4.13 CRM approach, before inserting those values into the E calculation. [#SRC:379a83c2-96da-4b2a-acea-f8779444878d] This linkage ensures the reverse repo exposure formula uses MV and collateral values that are consistent with the required CRM calculation basis for Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6. [#TGT:4262e773-aad2-4422-b6b3-fea38fd9d619]

question: How would the Regulator assess whether a trader’s conduct in a crude oil contract—rapidly accumulating more than 90% of the physical inventory, not offering to lend it back at a reasonable commercial rate, and then unwinding in the final settlement window at rapidly increasing prices—amounts to Behaviour that secures an abnormal or artificial price level, given the requirement that the transactions or orders be otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices?
gold_answer: The described crude oil scenario can be assessed as potentially abusive where the trading strategy both creates an abnormal price outcome and is carried out through transactions or orders that are not for legitimate reasons and not in line with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] In the example, the trader rapidly amasses more than 90% of the physical inventory underlying the crude oil contract, does not offer to lend the crude oil back at a reasonable commercial rate, and then exits the position during the Exchange’s final settlement window at rapidly increasing prices, with the effect of cornering/squeezing the market. [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7] That conduct is described as causing an abnormal movement in the price of crude oil contracts for forward month delivery, which aligns with the concept of securing the price at an abnormal or artificial level. [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7] The “fusion” point is that the abnormal movement is achieved through the trader’s execution pattern (building the dominant inventory position and unwinding in the final settlement window), which is the type of transaction/order behaviour the rule targets when it is not undertaken for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] On these facts, the Regulator’s example supports treating the strategy as an abusive squeeze that may contravene the relevant prohibition, while the rule frames the key test as abnormal/artificial price impact coupled with lack of legitimate/accepted-market-practice justification. [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7] [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f]

question: For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, how should eligible financial Collateral be determined when the proposed Collateral is an instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5 but is a T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by an entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person and held as Collateral by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities?
gold_answer: Eligible financial Collateral for an Authorised Person using the FCCA is defined to include instruments listed in Rule 4.13.5, but that inclusion is narrowed by a specific exclusion for certain intra-Group capital instruments. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] In practice, even if the proposed Collateral falls within the category of instruments listed in Rule 4.13.5, it must be treated as ineligible if it is a T1 Capital instrument or a T2 Capital instrument issued by any entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person and it is held as Collateral by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities. [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685] Accordingly, the Authorised Person should apply a two-step determination: first confirm the instrument is within the FCCA-eligible set (including Rule 4.13.5 instruments), and then screen out any T1/T2 Capital instruments issued by a Financial Group entity when the Collateral is held within the Authorised Person’s Financial Group. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685] This ensures the FCCA eligibility assessment does not inadvertently treat intra-Group capital instruments as eligible merely because they appear on the Rule 4.13.5 list. [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685]

question: If an Authorised Person using the FCCA wants to take a Unit in a Collective Investment Fund as eligible financial Collateral, what extra checks apply to the Fund, and does the rule about excluding certain T1/T2 Capital instruments issued within the Financial Group affect what the Fund can hold to meet the 90% investment test?
gold_answer: A Unit in a Collective Investment Fund can count as eligible financial Collateral for an Authorised Person using the FCCA only if the Fund is an equity-focused fund meeting specific conditions, and the Fund’s holdings must be assessed against what is treated as eligible under the relevant rules. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] The Fund-related checks are: the Units must have a price that is publicly quoted daily, and at least 90% of the Fund’s deposited property must be invested in instruments that are listed in the FCCA-eligible rule set (this Rule and Rule 4.13.5). [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] When applying that 90% test, instruments that are excluded from eligible financial Collateral must not be treated as qualifying investments for this purpose; specifically, any T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by an entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person is excluded where it is held as Collateral by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities. [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685] Therefore, the Authorised Person should verify both the Fund’s daily public pricing and the 90% investment composition, while ensuring the composition is not satisfied by relying on excluded intra-Group T1/T2 capital instruments. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685]

question: When an Authorised Person seeks to recognise the effects of CRM for the types of Collateral referenced in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7, what specific pre-recognition conditions must it have in place under the requirements that must be complied with before recognition, including any constraints on eligible securities and any custodian-related safeguards?
gold_answer: To recognise the effects of CRM for the types of Collateral referenced in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7, an Authorised Person may do so only if it ensures the relevant requirements in Rule 4.13.8 are complied with, because compliance with those requirements is a condition for recognition. [#SRC:c36bf3cf-160f-43ab-bb40-9d7f5ceec7b8] Before recognition, the Authorised Person must ensure that the legal arrangement for pledging, assigning, or transferring the Collateral gives it a timely right to liquidate or take legal possession upon the Counterparty’s default/insolvency/bankruptcy (or other defined credit events in the transaction documentation), and where applicable also upon such events affecting the custodian holding the Collateral. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1] It must also take all steps needed under the applicable law to obtain and maintain an enforceable security interest (including registration where required) or to exercise netting/set-off rights for title transfer Collateral. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1] In addition, it must avoid Collateral where the Counterparty’s credit quality and Collateral value are materially positively correlated, and it must treat securities issued by the Counterparty or any Closely Related Counterparty as ineligible. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1] Operationally, it must have procedures enabling prompt liquidation while observing legal conditions for declaring default, and if a custodian holds the Collateral, it must take reasonable steps to ensure segregation from the custodian’s own assets. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1]

question: If an Authorised Person wants to count the risk-reduction effect of CRM using Collateral (the types mentioned in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7), what must it check and set up first under the “Requirements for Recognition of Collateral,” especially about being able to sell/take the Collateral quickly and what happens when a custodian holds it?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person can only recognise the effects of CRM for the types of Collateral referred to in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7 if it ensures the relevant requirements in Rule 4.13.8 are met, because those requirements are the gateway conditions for recognition. [#SRC:c36bf3cf-160f-43ab-bb40-9d7f5ceec7b8] Practically, before recognising CRM, it must confirm that the legal method used to pledge, assign, or transfer the Collateral gives it a right to liquidate or take legal possession in a timely way if the Counterparty defaults or becomes insolvent/bankrupt (or if other defined credit events in the transaction documents occur), and this also extends to the custodian’s default/insolvency/bankruptcy where applicable. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1] It must also have taken all steps needed under the law governing its interest in the Collateral to obtain and keep an enforceable security interest (including registration where required) or to exercise net/set-off rights for title transfer Collateral. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1] In addition, it must have procedures that allow prompt liquidation while observing any legal conditions for declaring the Counterparty in default, and if a custodian holds the Collateral, it must take reasonable steps to ensure the custodian keeps the Collateral separate from the custodian’s own assets. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1]

question: If the Regulator gets the Rule 3.2.2 notice and normally would tell the Host Regulator(s) within five Business Days about using the passporting procedures, when is it not allowed to send the notice under Rule 3.2.4(a), and what does that mean for publishing the Passported Fund details and telling the Fund Manager registration is complete?
gold_answer: Even where the process describes a five-Business-Day step to notify Host Regulator(s) after the Regulator receives the Rule 3.2.2 notice, the Regulator is not permitted to transmit the notice under Rule 3.2.4(a) in certain situations. [#TGT:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e] The Regulator must not send that notice if it believes the Fund Manager or the Public Fund is not complying with applicable legislation (including these Rules), or if it has reasonable grounds to think the Fund Manager or the Public Fund may fail to comply in the future. [#SRC:02c6d009-e171-41d6-adac-aaaaf2b66e5a] It also must refrain if it considers holding back is necessary and appropriate to meet its objectives. [#SRC:02c6d009-e171-41d6-adac-aaaaf2b66e5a] If the Regulator does not transmit the Rule 3.2.4(a) notice, the later steps described in the passporting sequence cannot be reached as written, because they depend on Host Regulator action and confirmation. [#TGT:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e] In particular, the Regulator’s publication of the Passported Fund details on the Register of Passported Funds and its notification to the Fund Manager that registration is complete are triggered only after the relevant Host Regulator confirms its Register has been updated to include the Passported Fund details. [#TGT:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e]

question: For an Authorised Person conducting periodic stress tests on securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures (including testing future ability to transact securitisation as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes), how must it determine the appropriate frequency and extent of those stress tests?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must run stress tests periodically for its securitisation activities and its off balance sheet Exposures, and those tests must include an assessment of the Authorised Person’s future ability to transact securitisation as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] The appropriate frequency and the extent (i.e., how often and how wide-ranging/deep) of the stress testing are not fixed; instead, they must be set by reference to the materiality of the Authorised Person’s securitisation volumes and its off balance sheet Exposures. [#SRC:053ecf47-4501-4027-a994-9ada059b5e73] In practice, this means the Authorised Person should calibrate its periodic stress-testing programme so that more material securitisation volumes and/or more material off balance sheet Exposures drive a higher frequency and/or greater extent of testing, while less material activity supports a lower frequency and/or narrower extent—provided the programme still covers both securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures and includes the forward-looking ability-to-transact element for CRM or liquidity purposes. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] [#SRC:053ecf47-4501-4027-a994-9ada059b5e73]

question: When an Authorised Person does stress tests for securitisation, what exactly has to be tested, and what should decide how often and how detailed the tests are?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must carry out stress tests on a periodic basis that relate to both its securitisation activities and its off balance sheet Exposures. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] Those stress tests must also cover a forward-looking check: whether the Authorised Person would still be able in the future to transact securitisation as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] How often the Authorised Person runs these tests, and how extensive they are, must be decided by looking at how material the Authorised Person’s securitisation volumes are and how material its off balance sheet Exposures are. [#SRC:053ecf47-4501-4027-a994-9ada059b5e73] Put together, the requirement is to (1) ensure the periodic tests cover the specified areas (securitisation activities, off balance sheet Exposures, and future ability to transact for CRM/liquidity), and (2) scale the testing frequency and depth based on the materiality of the securitisation volumes and off balance sheet Exposures. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] [#SRC:053ecf47-4501-4027-a994-9ada059b5e73]

question: During an investigation, how may the Investigator obtain relevant information and/or documents on a compulsory versus voluntary basis, and what specific written-notice requirements (including timing, place, and premises access conditions) illustrate the compulsory route?
gold_answer: During an investigation, the Investigator can obtain relevant information and/or documents either compulsorily or voluntarily; the compulsory route is described as being exercised principally through the Investigator’s powers under section 206(1)(b) and (c) of FSMR, while the voluntary route is simply obtaining the material on a non-compulsory basis. [#SRC:cf20c9eb-d551-42cd-87ce-691b75db72d4] Where the Investigator proceeds compulsorily, the TARGET text illustrates that this can be done by issuing a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, even if that other person is not connected to the Person Under Investigation. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] The written notice may require attendance at an interview at a specified time and place to answer questions, production of specified documents (or documents of a specified description) at a specified time and place, and provision of information or assistance as required. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] It may also require the person to permit entry to their business premises during normal business hours so the Investigator can inspect and copy documents located there, which is another concrete mechanism for obtaining documents compulsorily. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] In contrast, if the Investigator chooses the voluntary basis, the passages indicate only that relevant information and/or documents may be obtained without invoking those compulsory powers. [#SRC:cf20c9eb-d551-42cd-87ce-691b75db72d4]

question: If the Investigator needs information or documents during an investigation, what are the two ways they can get them, and what kinds of things can a written notice force someone (including someone not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to do?
gold_answer: The passages describe two ways the Investigator may obtain relevant information and/or documents during an investigation: on a compulsory basis (mainly by using its powers under section 206(1)(b) and (c) of FSMR) or on a voluntary basis. [#SRC:cf20c9eb-d551-42cd-87ce-691b75db72d4] When using the compulsory approach, the Investigator may send a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, even if that person is not connected to the Person Under Investigation. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] That notice can require several concrete actions that help the Investigator obtain information and documents, including: attending an interview at a specified time and place and answering questions; producing specified documents (or documents of a specified description) at a specified time and place; and providing information or assistance the Investigator requires. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] The notice can also require the person to allow the Investigator to enter the person’s business premises during normal business hours so the Investigator can inspect and copy documents on those premises. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] If the Investigator proceeds voluntarily instead, the text indicates the Investigator may obtain the relevant information and/or documents without relying on the compulsory powers. [#SRC:cf20c9eb-d551-42cd-87ce-691b75db72d4]

question: For an operating mine(s), when a Mining Reporting Entity’s Production Target is wholly derived from Ore Reserves together with Measured Mineral Resources and/or Indicated Mineral Resources (with Indicated Mineral Resources not being the determining factor in project viability), how should the entity treat compliance with Rule 11.8.3 while still meeting the disclosure content requirements that apply to a disclosure made pursuant to Rule 11.8.2?
gold_answer: Where the Production Target for an operating mine(s) is wholly based on Ore Reserves alone, or on Ore Reserves combined with Measured Mineral Resources, or on Ore Reserves combined with Measured Mineral Resources and/or Indicated Mineral Resources (so long as Indicated Mineral Resources are not the determining factor in project viability), the Mining Reporting Entity is not required to make its disclosure comply with Rule 11.8.3. [#SRC:1d86427d-4a34-4179-bd16-1f64e7ef8560] However, if the entity is making a disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2, it must still include the specified disclosure elements about how the Production Target was determined. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] In practice, that means the disclosure should cover the material economic assumptions used (or, if commercially sensitive, state that and explain the methodology used to determine them) and also include all other material assumptions. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] It must also state whether forecast commodity prices were used and, if so, confirm they were arrived at on reasonable grounds. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] Finally, it must break down the proportions of the Production Target attributable to the relevant categories (including Probable/Proved Ore Reserves and Indicated/Measured Mineral Resources, among others listed). [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]

question: If an Issuer is making an Offer in or from the ADGM that is directed at no more than 50 Persons in any 12-month period (excluding Professional Clients who are not natural persons), may the Securities be offered for subscription or sale under an Approved Prospectus that is not a current Prospectus, and what is the compliance consequence if the Offer does not fall within an exemption?
gold_answer: An Offer that is directed at no more than 50 Persons in any 12-month period (excluding Professional Clients who are not natural persons) is prescribed as an Exempt Offer for the purposes of section 61(3)(a) of the FSMR. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] If the Issuer’s Offer is within that Exempt Offer category, the question of whether Securities may be offered under an Approved Prospectus that is not a current Prospectus depends on whether an exemption under Rule 4.3.1 or 4.4.1 applies, because the restriction on using an Approved Prospectus that is not current is stated to operate except where such an exemption applies. [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38] Conversely, if the Offer does not fall within an applicable exemption (i.e., no exemption under Rule 4.3.1 or 4.4.1 applies), then the Securities covered by the Prospectus must not be offered for subscription or sale under an Approved Prospectus unless that Prospectus is a current Prospectus. [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38] In practical compliance terms, the Issuer should first classify whether the contemplated distribution meets the ADGM “no more than 50 Persons in 12 months” Exempt Offer circumstance, and then ensure that any offering under an Approved Prospectus is conducted only when the Prospectus is current unless an exemption under Rule 4.3.1 or 4.4.1 is available. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38]

question: Where an Offer is made only to Professional Clients, how should a firm reconcile that Exempt Offer status with the rule that Securities must not be offered under an Approved Prospectus unless the Prospectus is current, and what is the default position if no Rule 4.3.1 or 4.4.1 exemption applies?
gold_answer: An Offer made to or directed at only Professional Clients is prescribed as an Exempt Offer for the purposes of section 61(3)(a) of the FSMR. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] Separately, the rule governing use of an Approved Prospectus states a default prohibition: Securities to which a Prospectus relates must not be offered for subscription or sale under an Approved Prospectus unless that Prospectus is a current Prospectus. [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38] The same rule also makes clear that this prohibition is displaced only where an exemption under Rule 4.3.1 or 4.4.1 applies. [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38] Accordingly, even if the contemplated distribution is limited to Professional Clients (and therefore fits an Exempt Offer circumstance), the firm must still treat the “current Prospectus” requirement as the baseline for any offering conducted under an Approved Prospectus, unless it can rely on an exemption under Rule 4.3.1 or 4.4.1. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38] If no such exemption applies, the compliance outcome is straightforward: the firm cannot proceed to offer the Securities under an Approved Prospectus that is not current, regardless of the Professional Client-only targeting. [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38]

question: Where a person other than the Investigator fails to comply with a requirement under Part 17 of FSMR, who may certify the non-compliance, in what form, and what are the potential legal consequences once the matter is before the Court of First Instance?
gold_answer: If a person other than the Investigator (the “Defaulter”) does not comply with a requirement imposed under this Part, the person who imposed that requirement may certify the non-compliance, and the certification must be made in writing to the Court of First Instance. [#TGT:7b15b4a5-ba07-4cd8-8b3a-6fcfe6daeb23] Once a person has failed to comply with a requirement under Part 17 of FSMR and is certified in default, the Court of First Instance may, if satisfied, deal with the person as though the person were in contempt of court under section 214(1)–(2) of FSMR. [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf] In addition to (and not instead of) the contempt-style treatment that may follow the Court’s satisfaction, the same failure to comply with Part 17 requirements may also expose the person to being found to have committed a contravention of FSMR under section 218. [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf] Accordingly, the compliance risk is twofold: a written certification pathway to the Court by the person imposing the requirement, and potential Court handling akin to contempt plus possible contravention findings for the underlying non-compliance. [#TGT:7b15b4a5-ba07-4cd8-8b3a-6fcfe6daeb23] [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf]

question: If someone (not the Investigator) doesn’t follow a requirement under this Part, how does the issue get formally sent to the Court of First Instance, and what could happen to the person after that under Part 17 of FSMR?
gold_answer: When a person other than the Investigator (the “Defaulter”) fails to comply with a requirement imposed on him under this Part, the person who imposed the requirement can formally report that failure by certifying it in writing to the Court of First Instance. [#TGT:7b15b4a5-ba07-4cd8-8b3a-6fcfe6daeb23] For failures to comply with requirements under Part 17 of FSMR, the person who failed to comply can be certified in default, and if the Court of First Instance is satisfied, the Court may handle the person as if the person were in contempt of court under section 214(1)–(2) of FSMR. [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf] Separately, the same kind of failure to comply with Part 17 requirements may also lead to the person being found to have committed a contravention of FSMR under section 218. [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf] Putting these points together, the written certification to the Court is the procedural step that can bring the non-compliance before the Court of First Instance, and the potential outcomes include contempt-like treatment (if the Court is satisfied) and exposure to a contravention finding for the underlying non-compliance. [#TGT:7b15b4a5-ba07-4cd8-8b3a-6fcfe6daeb23] [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf]

question: When the Investigator needs access to documents relevant to an investigation, how can the Investigator lawfully obtain inspection-and-copying access to Documents on a person’s business premises, and what procedural and timing conditions apply when the Investigator uses a written notice to secure that access?
gold_answer: The Investigator can obtain inspection-and-copying access to Documents on business premises in two complementary ways: (i) by exercising the statutory power to enter business premises to inspect and copy documents that are relevant to the investigation, and (ii) by issuing a written notice that requires a person to permit entry for that same inspection-and-copying purpose, subject to specified conditions. [#SRC:6f288073-515c-4e53-9fa5-16c3700d2767] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] Using the written-notice route, the Investigator may direct either the Person Under Investigation or any other person (even if not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to permit entry to that person’s business premises. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] The notice-based permission is constrained by timing and purpose: entry must be during normal business hours and must be for inspecting and copying Documents on the premises. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] Separately, the underlying entry-and-copying power is framed by relevance to the investigation: the Investigator’s entry to business premises is for inspecting and copying documents where those documents are relevant for the purposes of the investigation. [#SRC:6f288073-515c-4e53-9fa5-16c3700d2767] Read together, the written notice provides a procedural mechanism (including who may be required and the normal-business-hours condition) to facilitate the Investigator’s investigation-relevance-based inspection and copying on business premises. [#SRC:6f288073-515c-4e53-9fa5-16c3700d2767] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]

question: If the Investigator intends to inspect and copy documents on business premises, how does the scope limitation tied to investigation relevance interact with the Investigator’s ability to compel permission to enter premises from persons beyond the Person Under Investigation, and what hours restriction applies to that compelled entry?
gold_answer: The Investigator’s ability to inspect and copy documents on business premises is anchored to an investigation-purpose limitation: the entry-and-copying activity is for documents that are relevant for the purposes of the investigation. [#SRC:6f288073-515c-4e53-9fa5-16c3700d2767] In parallel, the Investigator has a procedural tool to secure access by written notice, and that tool is not limited to the Person Under Investigation; it can be directed to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, regardless of whether that other person is connected to the Person Under Investigation. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] When the Investigator uses the written-notice mechanism specifically to obtain premises access, the notice may require the recipient to permit the Investigator to enter the recipient’s business premises for the purpose of inspecting and copying Documents on those premises. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] That compelled entry is expressly time-bounded: it must occur during normal business hours. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] Taken together, the relevance limitation governs what the Investigator is seeking to inspect and copy (documents relevant to the investigation), while the written notice expands who can be required to facilitate entry (including unconnected third parties) and adds an operational constraint on when entry may occur (normal business hours). [#SRC:6f288073-515c-4e53-9fa5-16c3700d2767] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]

question: When submitting the written application for Remote Member status, what specific information must the Applicant include to demonstrate how it will meet the Remote Member Requirements, and how should that demonstration address both (i) written submissions to jurisdiction (Regulator and ADGM Courts) tied to use of the Recognised Body’s facilities and (ii) the limits on activities and client base when using a Recognised Investment Exchange/Recognised Clearing House or undertaking activities on a Recognised Body?
gold_answer: The Applicant must include, within its written application, enough information to show how it will satisfy the Remote Member Requirements, and that explanation must be anchored to the particular Recognised Body for which membership is sought. [#SRC:9820bf55-9b39-42c8-8471-04d83bc34f82] In practice, the application should (1) identify the Recognised Body being applied to and (2) set out how the Applicant will meet the Remote Member Requirements, including the required written agreements and operational limitations. [#SRC:9820bf55-9b39-42c8-8471-04d83bc34f82] To be complete, the “how” should cover at least the following elements: (i) written, unconditional submission to the Regulator’s jurisdiction for matters arising from or relating to use of the Recognised Body’s facilities; (ii) written, unconditional submission to the ADGM Courts for proceedings in the ADGM arising from or related to that use; and (iii) written agreement to subject itself to ADGM legislation and the ADGM Courts’ jurisdiction in relation to its use of the ADGM Recognised Body. [#TGT:1c380817-662e-4a9b-ab9d-3bc555c5b20d] It should also explain how the Applicant will ensure that, when using the facilities of a Recognised Investment Exchange or Recognised Clearing House, it acts only as agent or principal within the scope of activities it is licensed to undertake by its Non-ADGM Regulator, and that, when undertaking activities on a Recognised Body, it does so only for non-ADGM clients (each subject to the stated rule carve-outs). [#TGT:1c380817-662e-4a9b-ab9d-3bc555c5b20d]

question: If you have information that isn’t generally available and it relates to Securities (and Related Instruments), how do you decide whether it counts as “Inside Information” based on whether it would move the price—especially using the “reasonable investor” test?
gold_answer: You decide this by checking both the baseline “Inside Information” conditions and the specific way the price-impact test is defined through the reasonable-investor standard. “Inside Information” includes information that is not generally available, relates to Securities (and Related Instruments), and would have a significant effect on the price of those Securities if it became generally available. [#SRC:06929b81-60bd-4eba-b32e-0cd4da539c58] To judge whether it would have that significant price effect, you apply the rule that information is likely to have a significant effect on price if and only if it is the kind of information a reasonable investor would be likely to use as part of the basis of investment decisions. [#TGT:4fb237d1-ed32-4d0c-8f77-32eb47b7c12a] This is consistent with the additional point that the relevant information is information a reasonable investor would use as part of the basis of their investment decision. [#SRC:06929b81-60bd-4eba-b32e-0cd4da539c58] In practice, once you have confirmed the information is not generally available and relates to Securities (and Related Instruments), you focus on whether a reasonable investor would use that type of information when deciding to invest; if yes, that is the decisive indicator that it is likely to have a significant effect on price for these purposes. [#SRC:06929b81-60bd-4eba-b32e-0cd4da539c58] [#TGT:4fb237d1-ed32-4d0c-8f77-32eb47b7c12a]

question: For an Authorised Person with a Financial Service Permission covering multiple Regulated Activities, how should the annual supervision fees be calculated (including the incremental fee for each additional Regulated Activity), and by when must the initial and subsequent annual amounts be paid to the Regulator?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that holds a Financial Service Permission allowing multiple Regulated Activities must determine its annual supervision fees by paying the highest supervision fee applicable to any of the Regulated Activities it is permitted to undertake, and then adding an additional annual supervision fee for each additional Regulated Activity. [#SRC:f63a38e6-be52-4208-83e6-f2ffca7eeaf6] Each incremental amount is capped: for every additional Regulated Activity applied for, the extra annual supervision fee is the lesser of $10,000 or the supervision fee that would apply to that specific Regulated Activity. [#SRC:f63a38e6-be52-4208-83e6-f2ffca7eeaf6] Once the relevant annual fee amount is due under these Rules, payment timing depends on whether it is the initial annual fee or a subsequent annual fee. The initial annual fee must be paid in full to the Regulator within twenty days from the date it becomes due, and it is prorated for the remainder of the calendar year. [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37] For later years, subsequent annual fees for the period starting 1 January are payable in advance and must be paid in full to the Regulator on or before 31 January of the calendar year to which the fee relates. [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37]

question: When a Framework Contract contemplates exchange-rate adjustments, under what conditions may changes in exchange rates be applied immediately and without notice, and what specific exchange-rate-related disclosures must the Framework Contract include to support that approach (including any Reference Exchange Rate methodology and any agreed treatment of changes in Reference Exchange Rates)?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider may apply exchange-rate changes immediately and without giving notice only in two situations: where the Framework Contract grants that right and the changes are based on Reference Exchange Rate information that has been provided to the Payment Service User in the required manner, or where the change is more favourable to the Payment Service User. [#SRC:d1ff305e-8ed4-430f-a3ca-684f0dc00939] To support and document this approach within the contractual disclosures, the Framework Contract must include exchange-rate information as part of the required contract content, including either the exchange rates to be applied or—if Reference Exchange Rates will be used—the method for calculating the relevant date used to determine those Reference Exchange Rates. [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] In addition, where relevant and if agreed, the Framework Contract must address how changes in Reference Exchange Rates will be applied and the related information requirements for those changes. [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] Practically, this means the immediate/no-notice mechanism should be anchored in the contract’s exchange-rate section and aligned to the contract’s stated Reference Exchange Rate approach, so that the “immediate and without notice” application is limited to the contractually agreed and properly disclosed Reference Exchange Rate basis (or to changes that benefit the Payment Service User). [#SRC:d1ff305e-8ed4-430f-a3ca-684f0dc00939] [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]

question: If a contract says exchange rates can change, when can the Payment Service Provider change the exchange rate right away without telling the Payment Service User, and what exchange-rate details must be written into the Framework Contract (especially if Reference Exchange Rates are used)?
gold_answer: An exchange-rate change can be applied straight away and without notice only if either (1) the Framework Contract gives that right and the change is based on Reference Exchange Rate information that has already been provided to the Payment Service User in the required way, or (2) the change is more favourable to the Payment Service User. [#SRC:d1ff305e-8ed4-430f-a3ca-684f0dc00939] For the written contract content that supports this, the Framework Contract must include exchange-rate information as part of its required disclosures, meaning it must state the exchange rates to be applied or, where Reference Exchange Rates will be used, explain how the relevant date is calculated for determining those Reference Exchange Rates. [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] Also, where relevant and if agreed, the Framework Contract must cover how changes in Reference Exchange Rates will be applied and what information requirements apply to those changes. [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] Putting these together, the “no notice” approach is not a general permission: it is tied to what the Framework Contract allows and to the contract’s disclosed Reference Exchange Rate basis (or to changes that benefit the Payment Service User). [#SRC:d1ff305e-8ed4-430f-a3ca-684f0dc00939] [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]

question: For an Offer of Securities, what must the Prospectus include regarding the application form, and what controls must the Person making an Offer of Securities apply to the distribution and acceptance of that application form in relation to the relevant Prospectus?
gold_answer: For an Offer of Securities, the Prospectus must include an application form that satisfies the applicable rule requirement, and the Person making an Offer of Securities must control both how that form is provided and which versions are accepted. [#SRC:4978892e-a29f-4bd5-b8e7-8b8d53bb2b6c] In practice, this means the Prospectus is not complete for this type of offer unless it contains an application form meeting the specified standard, and the offer process must be run so that applicants only receive and use the Prospectus-linked form. [#SRC:4978892e-a29f-4bd5-b8e7-8b8d53bb2b6c] Specifically, the Person making an Offer of Securities must ensure that an application form for the issue or sale of the Securities covered by the Prospectus Offer is not given to any Person unless that form is included in, or provided together with, the relevant Prospectus. [#TGT:9cb9a5a4-5f65-4a29-bff3-48a8ec5260ff] The Person must also ensure that only applications submitted using the form that is included in or attached to the Prospectus are accepted, which prevents acceptance of alternative or standalone forms. [#TGT:9cb9a5a4-5f65-4a29-bff3-48a8ec5260ff] Taken together, the Prospectus content requirement and the distribution/acceptance controls operate as a single compliance chain: the Prospectus must carry the compliant form, and the offeror must ensure that form is the only one circulated and accepted in connection with the Prospectus Offer. [#SRC:4978892e-a29f-4bd5-b8e7-8b8d53bb2b6c] [#TGT:9cb9a5a4-5f65-4a29-bff3-48a8ec5260ff]

question: If someone is making an Offer of Securities, what does the Prospectus need to have about the application form, and what are the rules about when that form can be given out and which applications can be accepted?
gold_answer: When there is an Offer of Securities, the Prospectus must include an application form that meets the stated rule requirement, and the Person making an Offer of Securities must make sure the form is only used in a way that stays tied to the relevant Prospectus. [#SRC:4978892e-a29f-4bd5-b8e7-8b8d53bb2b6c] Concretely, the Prospectus is required to have an application form for this type of offer, and that form must satisfy the specified standard referenced for Offers of Securities. [#SRC:4978892e-a29f-4bd5-b8e7-8b8d53bb2b6c] On the distribution side, the Person making an Offer of Securities must ensure an application form for the issue or sale of the Securities in the Prospectus Offer is not provided to any Person unless it is included in, or comes together with, the relevant Prospectus.
