[#TGT:9cb9a5a4-5f65-4a29-bff3-48a8ec5260ff] On the acceptance side, that Person must ensure that only applications using the form that is included in or attached to the Prospectus are accepted, so applications on other formats are not taken. [#TGT:9cb9a5a4-5f65-4a29-bff3-48a8ec5260ff] The linkage is that the Prospectus must contain the compliant form, and the offer process must ensure that same Prospectus-linked form is the only one handed out and accepted for the Prospectus Offer. [#SRC:4978892e-a29f-4bd5-b8e7-8b8d53bb2b6c] [#TGT:9cb9a5a4-5f65-4a29-bff3-48a8ec5260ff]

question: When an Investigator uses written notice to require a person (including a Person Under Investigation or any other person) to permit entry to business premises during normal business hours to inspect and copy Documents, what notice is required and can the Investigator proceed without giving advance notice where prior notice could prejudice the investigation?
gold_answer: An Investigator can require entry to a person’s business premises during normal business hours for inspection and copying of Documents by issuing a written notice that includes that requirement. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] Separately, when exercising the power to enter business premises under section 206(1)(e) of FSMR, the Investigator must give written notice that the power is being exercised, but the text makes clear there is no obligation to provide that notice in advance. [#SRC:36b4de81-9f09-4450-8fef-1fa5c5094980] In practice, this means the Investigator’s written notice can function as the mechanism to require the person to permit entry during normal business hours, while still allowing the Investigator to avoid prior notice where appropriate. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] The Investigator may decide not to provide prior notice of an inspection in circumstances where giving advance notice could prejudice the investigation. [#SRC:36b4de81-9f09-4450-8fef-1fa5c5094980] Accordingly, the compliance expectation is that written notice will be given, but it need not be delivered ahead of time, particularly where advance warning could undermine the investigative purpose of inspecting and copying Documents on the premises. [#SRC:36b4de81-9f09-4450-8fef-1fa5c5094980] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]

question: If an Investigator sends a written notice telling someone to let them into the person’s business premises during normal business hours to inspect and copy Documents, do they have to warn the person ahead of time, and when might they choose not to give advance warning?
gold_answer: The Investigator can use a written notice to require the Person Under Investigation or any other person to permit entry to that person’s business premises during normal business hours so the Investigator can inspect and copy Documents located there. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] When the Investigator exercises the power to enter business premises under section 206(1)(e) of FSMR, the Investigator will give written notice of exercising that power, but the text states there is no requirement to give that notice in advance. [#SRC:36b4de81-9f09-4450-8fef-1fa5c5094980] As a result, the person should expect written notice as the formal step connected to entry and inspection, but should not assume they will receive advance warning before the inspection occurs. [#SRC:36b4de81-9f09-4450-8fef-1fa5c5094980] The Investigator may consider it appropriate not to provide prior notice where giving advance notice could prejudice the investigation, which is an example of when the Investigator might proceed without advance warning even though written notice is still part of the process. [#SRC:36b4de81-9f09-4450-8fef-1fa5c5094980] This aligns with the written-notice mechanism that can be used to require permission to enter premises for inspecting and copying Documents during normal business hours. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]

question: When the Fund Manager of a Public Fund intends to use the passporting procedures so that the Public Fund becomes a Passported Fund, what notification must be made to the Regulator, and what additional written notice is required if a material change, error, or omission is identified after that notification but before Promotion begins in a Host Jurisdiction?
gold_answer: To use the passporting procedures so that a Public Fund becomes a Passported Fund, the Fund Manager must first notify the Regulator of its intention for the Public Fund to be a Passported Fund. [#TGT:9ca2c478-4456-4c79-b447-743632309a37] After that initial notification and during the period before Promotion starts in a Host Jurisdiction, the Fund Manager has an ongoing duty to monitor whether anything arises that could affect what was notified. [#SRC:b27b7465-dcf2-43cf-a342-6f999ce5dadc] If, at any time between the notification made under Rule 3.2.2 and the commencement of Promotion in a Host Jurisdiction, the Fund Manager becomes aware of any material change, error, or omission that is reasonably likely to be relevant to the notification, the Fund Manager must provide the Regulator with written notice without delay. [#SRC:b27b7465-dcf2-43cf-a342-6f999ce5dadc] Following receipt of that written notice, the Regulator is expected to act promptly by passing all relevant details of the material change, error, or omission to the relevant Host Regulator. [#SRC:b27b7465-dcf2-43cf-a342-6f999ce5dadc] In practice, this means the initial intention-to-passport notification is not a one-off step: it is coupled with a time-bounded obligation to update the Regulator in writing if relevant issues are discovered before Promotion begins. [#TGT:9ca2c478-4456-4c79-b447-743632309a37] [#SRC:b27b7465-dcf2-43cf-a342-6f999ce5dadc]

question: If a Fund Manager wants a Public Fund to become a Passported Fund using the passporting procedures, what do they have to tell the Regulator first, and what should they do if they later spot a material change, error, or omission before Promotion starts in a Host Jurisdiction?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager must start by notifying the Regulator that it intends for the Public Fund to be a Passported Fund under the passporting procedures. [#TGT:9ca2c478-4456-4c79-b447-743632309a37] After making that notification, there is a specific window—between the notification under Rule 3.2.2 and the commencement of Promotion in a Host Jurisdiction—during which the Fund Manager must take further action if new relevant information comes to light. [#SRC:b27b7465-dcf2-43cf-a342-6f999ce5dadc] If the Fund Manager becomes aware of any material change, error, or omission that is reasonably likely to matter to the earlier notification, it must send written notice to the Regulator without delay. [#SRC:b27b7465-dcf2-43cf-a342-6f999ce5dadc] The Regulator then has its own follow-on step: it will promptly provide the relevant Host Regulator with all relevant details about that material change, error, or omission. [#SRC:b27b7465-dcf2-43cf-a342-6f999ce5dadc] So, the process combines (1) an initial intention-to-passport notification to the Regulator and (2) a rapid written update obligation if the Fund Manager discovers a relevant issue before Promotion begins in the Host Jurisdiction. [#TGT:9ca2c478-4456-4c79-b447-743632309a37] [#SRC:b27b7465-dcf2-43cf-a342-6f999ce5dadc]

question: For a Customer that is not a Natural Person, how do the parties’ ability to agree in writing to disapply certain Rules and to set a different time period for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions affect the notification deadline that conditions a Customer’s entitlement to redress for an unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transaction?
gold_answer: A Customer’s entitlement to redress for an unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transaction is conditioned on giving notice to its Third Party Provider without undue delay and, at the latest, within twelve months of the transaction’s execution date. [#TGT:d299e513-87d9-47de-9c0f-1f15cca91cbb] Where the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider can, by written agreement, switch off specified Rules and can also agree that a different time period applies for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 20.10.1. [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] In practical compliance terms, you should treat the twelve-month outer limit and the “without undue delay” requirement as the baseline condition for redress in the Third Party Transaction context, but then check whether there is a valid written agreement (available only where the Customer is not a Natural Person) that changes the applicable time period tied to unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions under Rule 20.10.1. [#TGT:d299e513-87d9-47de-9c0f-1f15cca91cbb] [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] If such an agreement exists, the operative deadline for the relevant unauthorised/incorrectly executed scenario must be read through that agreed time-period modification, alongside the requirement that notification be made without undue delay upon becoming aware. [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] [#TGT:d299e513-87d9-47de-9c0f-1f15cca91cbb]

question: When an Authorised Person has identified that it fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement and is considering taking actions of the type described in Rule 3.19.3(b)(i) and (ii), what must it do regarding (i) limiting distributions after calculating the maximum distributable amount and notifying the Regulator, and (ii) preparing and submitting a capital conservation plan, including the submission deadline and required plan contents?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that has identified a failure to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement must both control any subsequent distributions by reference to its maximum distributable amount and also prepare and submit a capital conservation plan to the Regulator within a specified timeframe. [#TGT:7a946965-716a-431a-b643-57f91e0ff92e] [#SRC:27f9bf56-82e3-4122-9d99-41e44b5fee9e] First, if it subsequently takes any of the actions described in Rule 3.19.3(b)(i) and (ii), then after it has calculated its maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator, it must ensure it does not distribute more than that calculated maximum distributable amount. [#SRC:27f9bf56-82e3-4122-9d99-41e44b5fee9e] Second, because it has failed to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must prepare a capital conservation plan and submit it to the Regulator no later than five business days after it identified that failure. [#TGT:7a946965-716a-431a-b643-57f91e0ff92e] The plan must include: (a) estimates of income and expenditure and a forecast balance sheet; (b) measures to increase the CET1 Capital of the Authorised Person; (c) a plan and timeframe for increasing CET1 Capital aimed at restoring the Combined Buffer; and (d) any other information the Regulator might need to carry out its considerations referred to in Rule 3.19.10 effectively. [#TGT:7a946965-716a-431a-b643-57f91e0ff92e]

question: If a Recognised Body (whether a Recognised Investment Exchange or Recognised Clearing House) submits an application that concerns activities relating to Spot Commodities, and the same filing is also an application for a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Principal (but not as a Matched Principal), which fee provision applies and what amount must be paid to the Regulator?
gold_answer: In this combined scenario, two fee directions are triggered and must be applied to the parts of the application they address: the Spot Commodities element is governed by the Section 4.1 fee framework, while the Financial Services Permission element carries a fixed application fee of $40,000 payable to the Regulator. [#SRC:fb16bc56-352e-4a9e-82de-ebdb2b58ae49] [#TGT:957c813c-93ef-4a38-aacd-a92bd99e168c] The precondition for the Section 4.1 reference is that the application concerns activities relating to Spot Commodities and that those activities will be undertaken by a Recognised Body, specifically a Recognised Investment Exchange or a Recognised Clearing House. [#SRC:fb16bc56-352e-4a9e-82de-ebdb2b58ae49] Separately, the precondition for the stated dollar amount is that the Applicant is seeking a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Principal, explicitly excluding the case where it is acting as a Matched Principal. [#TGT:957c813c-93ef-4a38-aacd-a92bd99e168c] Accordingly, the Applicant must pay the Regulator $40,000 for that permission application, and must also look to Section 4.1 for the applicable fees for the Spot Commodities activities undertaken by the Recognised Body. [#TGT:957c813c-93ef-4a38-aacd-a92bd99e168c] [#SRC:fb16bc56-352e-4a9e-82de-ebdb2b58ae49]

question: A Recognised Investment Exchange applies for something that includes Spot Commodities activities it will undertake, and it is also applying for Financial Services Permission to deal in investments as principal (not as a matched principal). What fee rule applies to the Spot Commodities part, and how much must be paid to the Regulator for the dealing-as-principal permission?
gold_answer: You need to apply two linked fee statements: the Spot Commodities part of the application is charged under the Section 4.1 fees, and the dealing-as-principal permission application requires a $40,000 application fee paid to the Regulator. [#SRC:fb16bc56-352e-4a9e-82de-ebdb2b58ae49] [#TGT:957c813c-93ef-4a38-aacd-a92bd99e168c] The Section 4.1 reference applies because the application concerns activities relating to Spot Commodities and those activities will be undertaken by a Recognised Body, which includes a Recognised Investment Exchange. [#SRC:fb16bc56-352e-4a9e-82de-ebdb2b58ae49] The $40,000 amount applies because the Applicant is seeking a Financial Services Permission for the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Principal, and the text makes clear this is the case where it is not acting as a Matched Principal. [#TGT:957c813c-93ef-4a38-aacd-a92bd99e168c] So, for the combined filing, you would treat the Spot Commodities element as falling under Section 4.1 fees, while separately ensuring the Applicant pays the Regulator the $40,000 application fee for the dealing-as-principal permission. [#SRC:fb16bc56-352e-4a9e-82de-ebdb2b58ae49] [#TGT:957c813c-93ef-4a38-aacd-a92bd99e168c]

question: If a Listed Entity issues Restricted Securities and a holding lock is put on them, what has to be filed within two Business Days, and when can the lock be released so people can accept a Takeover offer or transfer/cancel the Securities?
gold_answer: Within two Business Days after issuing Restricted Securities, a Listed Entity must get an undertaking from an eligible entity and submit it to the Regulator, and that undertaking must cover placing a holding lock on the Restricted Securities and not releasing it without the Regulator’s prior written consent. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] The eligible entity providing the undertaking can be a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD, or another entity the Regulator considers suitable, and it is the entity that holds the Restricted Securities and applies the holding lock. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] Even after the lock is in place, release is not automatic; it requires the Regulator’s prior written consent, which is the same approval needed for any release contemplated by the undertaking. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] In a Takeover (or merger) situation, the Regulator may consent to the party managing the holding lock releasing it specifically to let holders of Restricted Securities accept the offer, or to transfer or cancel Securities under the Takeover. [#SRC:12178c65-d1b6-440a-91e1-c670c7d9ab67] Practically, the Listed Entity’s two-Business-Day submission establishes the lock-and-consent framework, and the Takeover-related release can occur only if the Regulator grants consent for that purpose. [#SRC:12178c65-d1b6-440a-91e1-c670c7d9ab67] [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76]

question: For an Authorised Person, how do the criteria in Rule 2.2.1 (which trigger application of the Appendix) connect to the specific quantitative and intent-based tests for when it must have a Trading Book, including the normal and look-back thresholds?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is within scope of the Appendix only if it meets the criteria in Rule 2.2.1, and that status is what makes it required to have a Trading Book under the Appendix framework. [#SRC:80bc7597-4d36-479b-a3e3-7c1f24dda06d] To determine whether the Authorised Person must have a Trading Book, apply the Trading Book tests that specify both the nature of positions and quantitative thresholds. [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0] In practice, the Authorised Person must have a Trading Book when it has positions that are required to be included in a Trading Book under Section A2.1 of App2, and those positions are held with trading intent as described in Rule A2.1.5. [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0] In addition, the total value of positions eligible for inclusion (based on those inclusion and intent conditions) must meet one of the specified size tests: either it normally exceeds $15 million or 5% of combined on- and off-balance sheet positions, or it exceeded $20 million or 6% at any time during the preceding 12-month period. [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0] Read together, the Appendix’s applicability hinge (meeting Rule 2.2.1) provides the scope, while the Trading Book requirement is operationalized by the position-type, trading-intent, and threshold tests. [#SRC:80bc7597-4d36-479b-a3e3-7c1f24dda06d] [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0]

question: If an Authorised Person is one that meets the criteria in Rule 2.2.1 (so the Appendix applies), what exact checks does it use to decide whether it must have a Trading Book, including the dollar/percentage limits and the 12‑month look-back?
gold_answer: If the Authorised Person meets the criteria in Rule 2.2.1, the Appendix applies to it and, on that basis, it is required to have a Trading Book when the Trading Book conditions are met. [#SRC:80bc7597-4d36-479b-a3e3-7c1f24dda06d] The decision is not based on a single factor; it requires checking the type of positions, the intent for holding them, and the size of the eligible positions. [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0] Specifically, the Authorised Person must have a Trading Book if it has positions that must be included in a Trading Book under Section A2.1 of App2, and those positions are held with trading intent under Rule A2.1.5. [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0] Then it must assess the total value of the positions that are eligible for inclusion based on those two conditions: the requirement is triggered if that total normally exceeds $15 million or 5% of its combined on- and off-balance sheet positions, or if it exceeded $20 million or 6% at any time in the preceding 12 months. [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0] The Appendix scope condition (meeting Rule 2.2.1) and the Trading Book tests together determine whether the Trading Book requirement applies in the Authorised Person’s case. [#SRC:80bc7597-4d36-479b-a3e3-7c1f24dda06d] [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0]

question: Where the Regulator issues a written notice directing an Authorised Person to submit returns in a different form, manner, or frequency than prescribed in Rule 2.3.2, how must the Authorised Person reconcile that direction with the obligation to prepare returns under the Chapter/PRU/EPRS requirements (including EPRS submission frequency) and to submit via EPRS, and for how long does the modified approach apply?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must treat the Regulator’s written notice as an operative instruction that changes the form, manner, or frequency of submission away from what would otherwise apply under Rule 2.3.2, while still meeting the baseline requirement to prepare returns under the Chapter framework and to submit them to the Regulator using EPRS. [#SRC:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b] [#TGT:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9] In practice, this means the Authorised Person should (i) continue preparing returns in line with the Rules in the Chapter, the instructional guidelines in PRU and elsewhere, and the EPRS requirements (including the frequency of submission described in EPRS), and (ii) submit those returns through EPRS, except to the extent the written notice specifically directs a different form, manner, or frequency than Rule 2.3.2 would prescribe. [#TGT:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9] [#SRC:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b] The modified approach is not temporary by default: the Authorised Person must keep submitting returns in accordance with the Regulator’s direction until the Regulator issues a further written notice directing otherwise. [#SRC:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b] This creates a clear control point: EPRS-based preparation and submission remains the standard operating method, but a written notice can override the Rule 2.3.2 baseline on form/manner/frequency for as long as that notice remains in effect. [#TGT:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9] [#SRC:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b]

question: If the Regulator sends a written notice telling an Authorised Person to file returns in a different way or on a different schedule than Rule 2.3.2, does the Authorised Person still have to use EPRS and follow the Chapter/PRU/EPRS preparation requirements, and when can it stop following the notice?
gold_answer: Yes: the Authorised Person must still prepare its returns under the Rules in the Chapter, the instructional guidelines in PRU and elsewhere, and the Regulator’s EPRS requirements (including the submission frequency described in EPRS), and it must submit the returns to the Regulator using EPRS. [#TGT:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9] At the same time, if the Regulator issues a written notice directing a different form, manner, or frequency of submission than Rule 2.3.2 would otherwise require, the Authorised Person must follow that direction for those aspects. [#SRC:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b] The practical reconciliation is that EPRS-based preparation and submission remains the default operating channel and standards, but the written notice can change how the returns are submitted (form/manner) or how often they are submitted (frequency) compared with the Rule 2.3.2 baseline. [#TGT:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9] [#SRC:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b] The Authorised Person cannot decide on its own when to revert: it must continue submitting returns in accordance with the Regulator’s direction until the Regulator issues another written notice telling it to do otherwise. [#SRC:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b] This means the “stop” point is controlled by a further written notice, not by the passage of time or internal preference. [#SRC:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b]

question: When the Regulator is considering disclosure under the permissions referenced in paragraphs (1)(b)(i)–(iv), (vi) and 1(c), what specific consent and purpose limitations apply if the information is (a) Confidential Information that originated in another governmental or regulatory authority, or (b) CRD Information as defined by reference to receipt from an EEA Competent Authority?
gold_answer: The Regulator may only disclose Confidential Information under the permissions referenced in paragraphs (1)(b)(i)–(iv), (vi) and 1(c) if the relevant consent conditions are satisfied, and those conditions differ depending on whether the information originated with another authority or is CRD Information. [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c] For Confidential Information that originates (in whole or in part) in another governmental or regulatory authority (whether within the Abu Dhabi Global Market or elsewhere), the Regulator must obtain that originating authority’s prior written consent before making the disclosure. [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c] If the information is CRD Information, the Regulator must treat it as Confidential Information received or obtained from an EEA Competent Authority by virtue of the Capital Requirements Directive, and therefore must obtain the prior written consent of the EEA Competent Authority that provided it. [#SRC:dc3f77a8-19bb-49c7-a2f8-f257642a9321] [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c] In addition, where the EEA Competent Authority’s consent is granted for a particular purpose, the Regulator’s disclosure must be limited strictly to that purpose. [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c] This CRD-focused consent framework aligns with the section 199(2) provisions that address information exchange and professional secrecy in the Capital Requirements Directive context. [#SRC:dc3f77a8-19bb-49c7-a2f8-f257642a9321]

question: If the Regulator wants to share Confidential Information using the permissions listed in paragraphs (1)(b)(i)–(iv), (vi) and 1(c), what does it need to do first when (1) the information came from another authority, and (2) the information is CRD Information received from an EEA Competent Authority under the Capital Requirements Directive?
gold_answer: Before the Regulator can disclose Confidential Information under the permissions in paragraphs (1)(b)(i)–(iv), (vi) and 1(c), it must check which consent rule applies based on where the information came from. [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c] If the Confidential Information (all or part) originated with another governmental or regulatory authority (inside the Abu Dhabi Global Market or elsewhere), the Regulator cannot disclose it unless that authority has provided prior written consent. [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c] If the information is CRD Information, it is a specific type of Confidential Information: it is received or obtained by the Regulator from the EEA Competent Authority by virtue of the Capital Requirements Directive. [#SRC:dc3f77a8-19bb-49c7-a2f8-f257642a9321] In that CRD case, the Regulator must obtain prior written consent from the EEA Competent Authority that supplied the information. [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c] Also, if the EEA Competent Authority’s consent is limited to a particular purpose, the Regulator may disclose the CRD Information only for that purpose and not for any other use. [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c] These steps reflect the section 199(2) focus on handling CRD-related confidential material in a way consistent with information exchange and professional secrecy expectations under the Capital Requirements Directive. [#SRC:dc3f77a8-19bb-49c7-a2f8-f257642a9321]

question: If an Employee uses equipment the Authorised Person provided (or allowed) to talk with a Client about a Transaction, when does the Authorised Person have to record and keep that call, and when is it not required because of the Rule 6.8.1(b)(iv) exclusion?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must take reasonable steps to make and retain recordings of voice and electronic communications when the communication is with a Client (or another Person) in relation to a Transaction, including messages about receiving, executing, or arranging execution of Client orders and passing related instructions. [#TGT:b67e7e61-b8d6-4ede-8736-73c331997df8] This duty is framed as being subject to Rule 6.8.1(b), and it applies where the communication is made with, sent from, or received on equipment the Authorised Person provided to an Employee or contractor, or equipment whose use the Authorised Person has sanctioned or permitted. [#TGT:b67e7e61-b8d6-4ede-8736-73c331997df8] Even if those conditions are met, the effect of Rule 6.8.1(b)(iv) is that conversations or communications made by Investment Analysts, retail financial advisers, and persons carrying on back office functions are excluded from Rule 6.8.1(a). [#SRC:42726734-2dda-41b2-bba0-84f238f4e0c5] So, to decide whether recording is required, you need both checks: (1) does the communication match the Client/Transaction and equipment conditions, and (2) is the person making the communication outside the excluded categories. [#TGT:b67e7e61-b8d6-4ede-8736-73c331997df8] [#SRC:42726734-2dda-41b2-bba0-84f238f4e0c5]

question: In assessing whether Behaviour involving effecting transactions or orders to trade that may create a false or misleading impression or secure an abnormal/artificial price is caught by the described category, how does the ability to establish that the conduct was for legitimate reasons and in conformity with an Accepted Market Practice affect the analysis?
gold_answer: Where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade that give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression about supply, demand, or price, or that secure the price at an abnormal or artificial level, the described category is framed to apply when those transactions or orders are done other than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] In that context, if a person can establish that they carried out the conduct or practice for legitimate reasons and in conformance with an Accepted Market Practice, that established showing aligns with the stated carve-out condition and therefore addresses the “otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity” element embedded in the category description. [#SRC:277b5e91-5efc-4b1d-a2b2-790aa0039f73] Practically, the analysis turns on two linked components: (i) whether the transactions/orders have (or are likely to have) the misleading/price-securing effects described, and (ii) whether the person can demonstrate legitimate reasons and conformity with an Accepted Market Practice, which is the specific basis identified for treating the conduct as market practice rather than falling within the “otherwise than” framing. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] [#SRC:277b5e91-5efc-4b1d-a2b2-790aa0039f73]

question: If someone places trades or orders that could mislead people about supply/demand/price or push the price to an abnormal/artificial level, what do they need to show about “legitimate reasons” and “Accepted Market Practice” for it to be treated as market practice instead of the kind of Behaviour described?
gold_answer: The described Behaviour focuses on transactions or orders to trade that (a) give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression about supply, demand, or price, or (b) hold the price at an abnormal or artificial level, when those actions are done other than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] Against that framing, the market-practice concept is tied to a person being able to establish that they carried out the conduct or practice for legitimate reasons and in conformance with an Accepted Market Practice. [#SRC:277b5e91-5efc-4b1d-a2b2-790aa0039f73] So, to have the conduct treated as market practice rather than fitting the “otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity” condition, the person must be able to demonstrate both elements: legitimate reasons and conformity with an Accepted Market Practice. [#SRC:277b5e91-5efc-4b1d-a2b2-790aa0039f73] This linkage matters because the Behaviour description explicitly uses the absence of legitimate reasons and Accepted Market Practice conformity as part of what characterizes the category, even where the effects involve misleading impressions or abnormal/artificial pricing. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] No additional timing, notification, or record-keeping steps are stated in the provided passages beyond the need to establish the legitimate-reasons/Accepted Market Practice basis. [#SRC:277b5e91-5efc-4b1d-a2b2-790aa0039f73]

question: When calculating Additional Tier 1Capital (AT1 Capital), how should the firm reconcile the SOURCE statement that AT1 Capital is the sum of AT1 Capital elements in Rule 3.11.2 subject to later deductions, with the TARGET specification of which capital elements make up that sum (including any related accounts)?
gold_answer: AT1 Capital should be determined by first identifying the capital elements that are included in the “sum” and then applying any deductions that the relevant Section requires later. [#SRC:07d97e4e-0f4e-4883-abf4-12a3890129f9] Concretely, the capital elements that make up AT1 Capital include (a) capital instruments that satisfy the eligibility criteria in Rule 3.11.3 and (b) the share premium accounts that relate to those eligible instruments. [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b] The SOURCE frames this as a sum of AT1 Capital elements referenced in Rule 3.11.2, but it also makes clear that the resulting amount is not final until the deductions specified later in the same Section are taken into account. [#SRC:07d97e4e-0f4e-4883-abf4-12a3890129f9] Accordingly, a compliant calculation approach is: (1) include the eligible capital instruments and their related share premium accounts as the component elements of AT1 Capital, and (2) treat that subtotal as subject to reduction by the deductions stipulated later in the Section. [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b] [#SRC:07d97e4e-0f4e-4883-abf4-12a3890129f9]

question: Under Section 92(2), when an Insider has Inside Information relating to a Financial Instrument, how should the prohibition on dealing be applied to a "Related Instrument", and where is the definition of "Related Instrument" located?
gold_answer: Section 92(2) prohibits an Insider from dealing or attempting to deal not only in the Financial Instrument (and, where relevant, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity) to which the Inside Information relates, but also in any Related Instrument connected to that Inside Information. [#SRC:4d6d9fa5-5edd-4280-9d7b-90fca017f5d7] For purposes of applying that prohibition, a Related Instrument is treated as within scope where, in relation to a Financial Instrument, it is an investment whose price or value depends on the price or value of the Financial Instrument. [#TGT:701dd6f2-183c-4150-a7ab-58ab24fc3f8f] This means the compliance analysis must extend beyond the instrument that is the direct subject of the Inside Information to any dependent-value investment, such as a derivative linked to the Financial Instruments of the relevant Issuer. [#TGT:701dd6f2-183c-4150-a7ab-58ab24fc3f8f] It can also include another Financial Instrument in a member of the Issuer’s Group, provided that the price or value of that other Financial Instrument depends (in whole or in part) on the price or value of the Issuer’s Financial Instruments. [#TGT:701dd6f2-183c-4150-a7ab-58ab24fc3f8f] The formal definition of “Related Instrument” is located at paragraph 1(9) of the CMC, which should be used as the reference point when determining whether a particular investment falls within Section 92(2)’s dealing prohibition. [#SRC:4d6d9fa5-5edd-4280-9d7b-90fca017f5d7]

question: For an Authorised Person that (i) has a Financial Services Permission to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as Principal, and (ii) operates as a Cell Company under Rule 3.11.2 or Rule 3.11.4, what annual supervision fees must be paid to the Regulator, and how does the number of Cells affect the total amount?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must pay the annual supervision fee applicable to the insurance Regulated Activities and, in addition, the separate annual supervision fees that apply because it operates as a Cell Company, with the Cell Company component increasing based on the number of Cells. [#TGT:6fc382ee-caf4-4abd-b571-718512a89e96] Specifically, where the Authorised Person has a Financial Services Permission to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as Principal, it must pay the Regulator $50,000 per year for either or both of those Regulated Activities (i.e., the same $50,000 amount applies whether it carries on one or both). [#TGT:6fc382ee-caf4-4abd-b571-718512a89e96] Separately, if that same Authorised Person operates as a Cell Company under Rule 3.11.2 or Rule 3.11.4, it must also pay an additional $8,000 annual supervision fee for the Cell Company itself, plus $1,000 for each Cell. [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b] Accordingly, the total annual supervision fees payable to the Regulator equal $50,000 plus $8,000 plus $1,000 multiplied by the number of Cells. [#TGT:6fc382ee-caf4-4abd-b571-718512a89e96] [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b]

question: For an Authorised Person that is authorised to Manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, how should the firm treat T2 Capital under the Part 4 capital resources framework when the Profit Equalisation Reserve and Investment Risk Reserve together exceed the Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement calculated under the IFR rules?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that is authorised to Manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu is subject to Part 4 for calculating capital resources, but it benefits from a specific carve-out affecting how T2 Capital is determined for that activity. [#SRC:daf2ec63-a8a3-4cd4-b0e3-450154245ed4] In applying that carve-out, the firm must remove from its T2 Capital the portion of reserves that sits above the relevant displaced commercial risk measure: specifically, it must exclude any amount by which the combined total of the Profit Equalisation Reserve and the Investment Risk Reserve is greater than the Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement (as calculated under the IFR rules). [#TGT:db2f1888-b83e-45c9-99f7-dfc2058f61c2] This means the exclusion is not a blanket removal of those reserves; it is a threshold-based adjustment that only applies to the excess over the displaced commercial risk capital requirement. [#TGT:db2f1888-b83e-45c9-99f7-dfc2058f61c2] Operationally, the firm should (i) identify whether it is authorised to Manage a PSIAu and therefore within the Part 4 exemption context, and (ii) compute the excess of the two reserves over the displaced commercial risk capital requirement and exclude that excess from T2 Capital when calculating capital resources. [#SRC:daf2ec63-a8a3-4cd4-b0e3-450154245ed4] [#TGT:db2f1888-b83e-45c9-99f7-dfc2058f61c2]

question: If an Authorised Person manages a PSIAu, does it still follow Part 4 for capital resources, and what exactly must it take out of T2 Capital when the Profit Equalisation Reserve plus the Investment Risk Reserve is higher than the Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement (under the IFR rules)?
gold_answer: Yes. Part 4 on calculating capital resources applies to all firms, including an Authorised Person that is authorised to Manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu; however, within Part 4 there is an exemption that affects the calculation of T2 Capital for that PSIAu management activity. [#SRC:daf2ec63-a8a3-4cd4-b0e3-450154245ed4] When applying the T2 treatment, the firm must adjust T2 Capital by excluding the amount of “excess reserves” tied to displaced commercial risk: it must exclude from T2 Capital any amount by which the total of the Profit Equalisation Reserve and the Investment Risk Reserve exceeds the Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement calculated in accordance with the IFR rules. [#TGT:db2f1888-b83e-45c9-99f7-dfc2058f61c2] In other words, the firm compares (Profit Equalisation Reserve + Investment Risk Reserve) against the displaced commercial risk capital requirement, and only the portion above that requirement is removed from T2 Capital. [#TGT:db2f1888-b83e-45c9-99f7-dfc2058f61c2] This approach links the PSIAu-specific exemption within the Part 4 capital resources framework to a concrete calculation step that depends on the IFR-based displaced commercial risk capital requirement. [#SRC:daf2ec63-a8a3-4cd4-b0e3-450154245ed4] [#TGT:db2f1888-b83e-45c9-99f7-dfc2058f61c2]

question: Where the Listing Authority is dealing with a time-critical continuous disclosure issue under Rule 7.2.1, what specific contactability and internal-authority arrangements should a Reporting Entity maintain to reduce the risk that the Listing Authority will Suspend the Listed Entity’s Securities because it cannot promptly reach or obtain effective engagement from the Reporting Entity?
gold_answer: A Reporting Entity should structure its contact arrangements and internal decision-making so the Listing Authority can reach the Reporting Entity quickly and obtain prompt, effective action on sensitive, time-critical continuous disclosure matters, thereby reducing the risk of a Suspension being imposed due to failed or ineffective contact. [#SRC:8fbe10b4-f49e-4b93-b470-a3c663f2ab94] In practice, this means the Reporting Entity should be readily contactable by phone and available to discuss pressing Disclosure issues during the normal trading hours of the relevant RIE and for at least one hour before and after those hours each Business Day. [#TGT:40f90ce3-56d4-440a-abf9-2ab4b8249d8e] It also means ensuring that the relevant Officers responsible for communication with the Listing Authority have both the organisational knowledge to hold meaningful discussions on Rule matters and the authority to request a Trading Halt or Suspension and to make a Disclosure when required. [#TGT:40f90ce3-56d4-440a-abf9-2ab4b8249d8e] These measures directly address the risk scenario where the Listing Authority cannot contact the Reporting Entity’s designated contact points, or those contacts lack the knowledge or authority to resolve the matter promptly, in which case the Listing Authority may Suspend the Listed Entity’s Securities until the issue is properly resolved. [#SRC:8fbe10b4-f49e-4b93-b470-a3c663f2ab94]

question: If the Listing Authority needs to deal with an urgent disclosure problem and can’t quickly reach the Reporting Entity’s designated contacts (or those contacts can’t act), what should the Reporting Entity do—especially around being reachable and having the right people empowered—so it avoids the risk of the Listed Entity’s Securities being Suspended?
gold_answer: To avoid the risk that the Listing Authority may Suspend the Listed Entity’s Securities because an urgent, sensitive continuous disclosure issue cannot be resolved promptly, the Reporting Entity should make sure the Listing Authority can quickly reach the right people and that those people can take effective action. [#SRC:8fbe10b4-f49e-4b93-b470-a3c663f2ab94] Concretely, the Reporting Entity should be easy to contact by phone and be available to discuss pressing Disclosure issues during the normal trading hours of the RIE where the Listed Entity’s Securities trade, and for at least one hour before and after those hours each Business Day. [#TGT:40f90ce3-56d4-440a-abf9-2ab4b8249d8e] It should also ensure its relevant Officers who communicate with the Listing Authority have enough organisational knowledge to discuss Rule matters meaningfully and have the authority to request a Trading Halt or Suspension and to make a Disclosure if required. [#TGT:40f90ce3-56d4-440a-abf9-2ab4b8249d8e] These steps are important because, if the Listing Authority cannot contact the Reporting Entity’s designated contact points or those contacts lack the knowledge or authority to address the matter promptly, the Listing Authority may impose a Suspension until the issue is properly resolved. [#SRC:8fbe10b4-f49e-4b93-b470-a3c663f2ab94]

question: For an Authorised Person, how does the obligation to maintain the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times interact with the requirement to calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital, including the specific calculation components and rule cross-references that determine the amount that must be maintained?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must ensure that the required buffer amount is continuously held in the form of CET1 Capital, and the Countercyclical Capital Buffer calculation is one mechanism that determines a CET1 Capital buffer amount that must be maintained. [#SRC:97faadb3-289b-44a9-9f5c-3ea5c35e39cf] Specifically, the Authorised Person is required to calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by taking its Total Risk Exposure Amount and multiplying it by a weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates applicable to certain exposures. [#TGT:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] The Total Risk Exposure Amount used in that calculation must be determined under Rule 3.5.7, and the weighted average of the buffer rates must be computed under Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8, based on the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures are located. [#TGT:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] Separately, the requirement to maintain the required buffer amount “at all times” applies to the buffer amount as calculated in accordance with Rule 3.18.4, meaning the Authorised Person must keep that CET1 Capital buffer continuously available rather than only at a point-in-time calculation date. [#SRC:97faadb3-289b-44a9-9f5c-3ea5c35e39cf]

question: When an Issuer proposes to offer Securities for subscription or sale under an Approved Prospectus, how does the requirement that the Prospectus be a current Prospectus interact with the Regulator’s prescribed categories of Exempt Securities (for example, a rights issue where a document is made available describing the number and nature of the Securities and the reasons for and details of the Offer)?
gold_answer: An offer for subscription or sale of Securities under an Approved Prospectus is not permitted unless the Prospectus is a current Prospectus, except where an exemption under Rule 4.3.1 or 4.4.1 applies. [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38] Separately, the Regulator has prescribed specific types of Securities as Exempt Securities for the purposes of section 61(3)(b) of the FSMR, including Securities offered, allotted or to be allotted in connection with a rights issue where (i) the Securities are of the same class as Securities already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange and (ii) a document is made available with information on the number and nature of the Securities and the reasons for and details of the Offer. [#TGT:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0] In practical compliance terms, you must first determine whether the contemplated Securities fall within one of the Regulator’s Exempt Securities categories (such as the rights issue category with its same-class and document-availability conditions). [#TGT:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0] If the offer is proceeding “under an Approved Prospectus,” the baseline rule remains that the Prospectus must be current unless the relevant exemption under Rule 4.3.1 or 4.4.1 is available and applies to the transaction. [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38] Accordingly, the Exempt Securities analysis and the “current Prospectus” condition must be assessed together to confirm whether the offer can proceed as structured. [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38] [#TGT:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0]

question: For the purposes of Rule 2.5.5, what must a Recognised Body have in place, and what standard of effort must it apply, to ensure its commercial interests (including profitability) do not adversely affect the performance of its Regulatory Functions?
gold_answer: A Recognised Body must both implement an internal control framework and actively apply a reasonableness standard to prevent its commercial interests from harming the performance of its Regulatory Functions. [#SRC:0a71e314-db1c-4038-aea2-9ce748ddbfd8] Specifically, for the purposes of Rule 2.5.5, it must maintain adequate systems and controls, including documented policies and procedures, designed so that pursuing commercial interests (expressly including profitability) does not negatively impact how it carries out its Regulatory Functions. [#SRC:0a71e314-db1c-4038-aea2-9ce748ddbfd8] In addition to having those arrangements, it must take all reasonable steps to ensure that the performance of its Regulatory Functions is not adversely affected by its commercial interests, which sets an ongoing conduct expectation rather than a one-time design requirement. [#TGT:74bba2cd-f78a-4308-96b7-5431d4be50d5] Read together, the obligation is not satisfied merely by having policies on paper; the Recognised Body must also act reasonably in practice to keep commercial drivers from impairing regulatory performance. [#SRC:0a71e314-db1c-4038-aea2-9ce748ddbfd8][#TGT:74bba2cd-f78a-4308-96b7-5431d4be50d5]

question: If a Recognised Body is trying to grow profits, what does it need to set up (for Rule 2.5.5) and what does it need to do in practice so that its Regulatory Functions are not harmed by those commercial interests?
gold_answer: A Recognised Body must combine proper internal arrangements with ongoing practical action so that commercial interests—explicitly including profitability—do not damage the performance of its Regulatory Functions. [#SRC:0a71e314-db1c-4038-aea2-9ce748ddbfd8] For the purposes of Rule 2.5.5, it needs adequate systems and controls, and these must include policies and procedures aimed at preventing its pursuit of commercial interests from adversely impacting its Regulatory Functions. [#SRC:0a71e314-db1c-4038-aea2-9ce748ddbfd8] Beyond setting up those controls, it must also take all reasonable steps to ensure that its Regulatory Functions are not adversely affected by its commercial interests, which indicates an active, continuing effort to manage that risk. [#TGT:74bba2cd-f78a-4308-96b7-5431d4be50d5] In other words, the Recognised Body should both have adequate policies/procedures and apply reasonable steps in operation so commercial goals do not interfere with regulatory performance. [#SRC:0a71e314-db1c-4038-aea2-9ce748ddbfd8][#TGT:74bba2cd-f78a-4308-96b7-5431d4be50d5]

question: For documents that must be submitted in final form to the Regulator before 9:00am on the day the Regulator is to consider an application, who must sign the documents required by Rule 2.4.5, and which specific documents are required (including when a pricing statement is required)?
gold_answer: On the day the Regulator is to consider the application, the Applicant must both (i) submit specified documents to the Regulator by 9:00am in final form and (ii) ensure that the documents required by Rule 2.4.5 are properly signed by the correct signatory. [#TGT:dc66c345-5fd8-4956-8ee4-f839e841bd7c] [#SRC:0dd551f7-727e-4872-9782-b54e37104017] The submission obligation applies to documents that must be provided on the day, and it sets a firm deadline: before 9:00am on the day the Regulator will consider the application. [#TGT:dc66c345-5fd8-4956-8ee4-f839e841bd7c] The documents that must be submitted in final form are: (1) a completed Shareholder statement; and (2) a completed pricing statement where the application involves a placing, open Offer or Offer for subscription. [#TGT:dc66c345-5fd8-4956-8ee4-f839e841bd7c] Separately, the Applicant must ensure that the documents required by Rule 2.4.5 are signed either by its Sponsor (if a Sponsor has been appointed) or by a duly authorised officer of the Applicant. [#SRC:0dd551f7-727e-4872-9782-b54e37104017] Accordingly, for the day-of submission package, the Applicant should confirm both timely delivery to the Regulator and that the relevant Rule 2.4.5 documents bear the required signature authority. [#TGT:dc66c345-5fd8-4956-8ee4-f839e841bd7c] [#SRC:0dd551f7-727e-4872-9782-b54e37104017]

question: On the day the Regulator will look at the application, what has to be sent to the Regulator before 9:00am, and who is allowed to sign the documents required by Rule 2.4.5 (especially if the Applicant has a Sponsor)?
gold_answer: For the day the Regulator is to consider the application, the Applicant has two linked responsibilities: meeting the 9:00am submission deadline for specified final-form documents and ensuring the Rule 2.4.5 documents are signed by the correct person. [#TGT:dc66c345-5fd8-4956-8ee4-f839e841bd7c] [#SRC:0dd551f7-727e-4872-9782-b54e37104017] By no later than before 9:00am on that day, the Applicant must submit to the Regulator, in final form, a completed Shareholder statement. [#TGT:dc66c345-5fd8-4956-8ee4-f839e841bd7c] The Applicant must also submit a completed pricing statement when the application is in the case of a placing, open Offer or Offer for subscription. [#TGT:dc66c345-5fd8-4956-8ee4-f839e841bd7c] In addition to getting the documents in on time, the Applicant must ensure that the documents required by Rule 2.4.5 are signed by either (a) its Sponsor, if a Sponsor has been appointed, or (b) a duly authorised officer of the Applicant. [#SRC:0dd551f7-727e-4872-9782-b54e37104017] Practically, this means the Applicant should check both that the required statements are complete and submitted by the deadline and that the relevant Rule 2.4.5 documents carry the appropriate signature authority for that same day-of process. [#TGT:dc66c345-5fd8-4956-8ee4-f839e841bd7c] [#SRC:0dd551f7-727e-4872-9782-b54e37104017]

question: When an Authorised Person has Counterparty Risk Exposures arising from an SFT that are included in the Trading Book, under what conditions may it treat those Exposures as collateralised, and what scope of eligible financial Collateral may it recognise for those Exposures?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may treat Exposures as collateralised only if it satisfies the conditions set out in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.8 (which are identified as relating to CRM). [#SRC:558596ee-af40-4c07-8067-9c5c25eebaa5] Where the Exposures are Counterparty Risk Exposures described in Rules 4.13.5 and 4.13.6 and they arise from an SFT that is included in the Trading Book, the scope of eligible financial Collateral is broad: it includes all instruments that the Authorised Person may include in its Trading Book. [#TGT:cacd95d6-558b-4d84-93f1-e1d5664a1d01] In practical terms, the Trading Book inclusion and SFT origin determine the collateral eligibility set, but the ability to treat the Exposure as collateralised still depends on meeting the CRM conditions across Rules 4.13.5 through 4.13.8. [#SRC:558596ee-af40-4c07-8067-9c5c25eebaa5] [#TGT:cacd95d6-558b-4d84-93f1-e1d5664a1d01] This means the Authorised Person must first confirm the Exposure falls within the relevant Counterparty Risk Exposures in Rules 4.13.5 and 4.13.6 and is from an SFT in the Trading Book, and then apply the CRM conditions to determine whether it can recognise collateralisation for that Exposure. [#TGT:cacd95d6-558b-4d84-93f1-e1d5664a1d01] [#SRC:558596ee-af40-4c07-8067-9c5c25eebaa5]

question: If an Authorised Person has an SFT exposure in the Trading Book, what does it need to check before calling the exposure “collateralised,” and what kinds of collateral can count for that Trading Book SFT exposure?
gold_answer: Before an Authorised Person can treat any Exposure as collateralised, it must ensure the conditions in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.8 (described as relating to CRM) are met. [#SRC:558596ee-af40-4c07-8067-9c5c25eebaa5] If the Exposure is a Counterparty Risk Exposure covered by Rules 4.13.5 and 4.13.6 and it comes from an SFT that is included in the Trading Book, then the eligible financial Collateral it may recognise includes every instrument the Authorised Person is allowed to include in its Trading Book. [#TGT:cacd95d6-558b-4d84-93f1-e1d5664a1d01] Put together, the Trading Book/SFT condition tells you what collateral types are eligible, while the CRM conditions across Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.8 determine whether the Exposure can actually be treated as collateralised at all. [#TGT:cacd95d6-558b-4d84-93f1-e1d5664a1d01] [#SRC:558596ee-af40-4c07-8067-9c5c25eebaa5] So the Authorised Person should (i) identify that the Exposure is within the Counterparty Risk Exposures in Rules 4.13.5 and 4.13.6 and arises from an SFT in the Trading Book, and (ii) apply the CRM conditions in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.8 before treating it as collateralised. [#TGT:cacd95d6-558b-4d84-93f1-e1d5664a1d01] [#SRC:558596ee-af40-4c07-8067-9c5c25eebaa5]

question: When calculating and paying an initial annual fee that is payable on an annual basis, how must the proration for the remainder of the calendar year be determined, and by when must the prorated amount be paid in full to the Regulator?
gold_answer: For an initial annual fee payable on an annual basis, the amount due must be prorated by reference to the portion of the year remaining, and the resulting prorated fee must then be paid in full to the Regulator within the specified payment window. [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37] The proration methodology is that the portion due is calculated based on the number of months remaining until the end of the calendar year, so the remaining-month count drives the reduced amount for the rest of that year. [#SRC:94b3f85d-c033-41a3-a884-c873899c049f] Once the fee becomes due, the initial annual fee (as prorated for the remainder of the calendar year using that remaining-month approach) must be paid in full to the Regulator within twenty days of the due date. [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37] In practical terms, compliance requires (i) identifying how many months are left to the calendar year-end to compute the portion due, and (ii) ensuring the full prorated amount reaches the Regulator no later than the twentieth day after the fee becomes due. [#SRC:94b3f85d-c033-41a3-a884-c873899c049f] [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37]

question: When an Authorised Person is a clearing member with Trade Exposure to a Non-QCCP (including acting as an intermediary between a client and the Non-QCCP), how should it determine the applicable calculation approach for exposure and the risk-weighting treatment, taking into account the SA-CCR requirement for derivatives and long settlement transactions and the corporate asset class CRW requirement for the Non-QCCP?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that acts as a clearing member and has Trade Exposure to a Non-QCCP must (i) calculate the relevant exposure measure using the required counterparty credit risk approach for derivatives/long settlement transactions, and (ii) apply the specified corporate-asset-class risk weight for the Non-QCCP when determining Credit RWA. [#SRC:d16634fb-97c2-470f-9bd9-a92049293eba] Specifically, for Derivative transactions (whether OTC or exchange-traded) and for long settlement transactions, the exposure at default (EAD) must be calculated under the Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR), unless the Authorised Person has permission from the Regulator to use an internal model instead. [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff] In parallel, where the Authorised Person is acting as a clearing member either for its own purposes or as an intermediary between a client and a Non-QCCP, it must calculate Credit RWA for its Trade Exposure to that Non-QCCP in accordance with Rule A4.6.14 and apply an appropriate CRW based on the corporate asset class of the Non-QCCP as set out in Rule 4.12.13. [#SRC:d16634fb-97c2-470f-9bd9-a92049293eba] Accordingly, the EAD methodology (SA-CCR unless internal-model permission) informs the exposure component, while the corporate-asset-class CRW requirement governs the risk-weighting applied to that Non-QCCP exposure for Credit RWA purposes. [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff] [#SRC:d16634fb-97c2-470f-9bd9-a92049293eba]

question: If an Authorised Person clears trades with a Non-QCCP (either for itself or between a client and the Non-QCCP), what method does it use to work out the exposure amount for derivatives/long settlement transactions, and what risk weight does it then apply for Credit RWA?
gold_answer: For a clearing member’s Trade Exposure to a Non-QCCP, the Authorised Person needs to combine the exposure-calculation rule for derivatives/long settlement transactions with the risk-weighting rule for the Non-QCCP. [#SRC:d16634fb-97c2-470f-9bd9-a92049293eba] For Derivative transactions (OTC and exchange-traded) and long settlement transactions, the exposure at default (EAD) must be calculated using the Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR), unless the Regulator has granted the Authorised Person permission to use an internal model. [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff] Once the exposure is being treated as a Trade Exposure to a Non-QCCP in the clearing-member context (including where the Authorised Person acts as an intermediary between a client and the Non-QCCP), the Authorised Person must calculate Credit RWA for that Trade Exposure in accordance with Rule A4.6.14. [#SRC:d16634fb-97c2-470f-9bd9-a92049293eba] It must also apply an appropriate CRW that corresponds to the corporate asset class of the Non-QCCP, as set out in Rule 4.12.13. [#SRC:d16634fb-97c2-470f-9bd9-a92049293eba] In short, SA-CCR (or an approved internal model) determines EAD, and the corporate-asset-class CRW determines the risk weight used in the Credit RWA calculation for the Non-QCCP exposure. [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff] [#SRC:d16634fb-97c2-470f-9bd9-a92049293eba]

question: If an Authorised Person wants to trade something as a Spot Commodity, what two sets of information does it need to give the Regulator so the Regulator can decide if it is an Accepted Spot Commodity—one about what the item is (goods, prompt delivery, not a future or a Financial Instrument) and one about how it is sourced and how the market works?
gold_answer: To support the Regulator’s decision, the Authorised Person needs to cover both (1) why the item qualifies as a Spot Commodity and (2) why it should be treated as an Accepted Spot Commodity for the intended Regulated Activity. [#TGT:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338] On the “what it is” side, it should describe the item as a good sold for cash with prompt delivery when the transaction is settled, and confirm it is not a contract requiring delivery at a future date beyond the standard delivery period generally accepted in that market. [#SRC:34ccda9d-76c5-45f3-af56-56834f25f068] It should also confirm the item is not a Financial Instrument involving conventional assets (for example, Securities or Derivatives) and is not a service or other non-good/intangible item such as currencies or rights in real estate. [#SRC:34ccda9d-76c5-45f3-af56-56834f25f068] On the “accepted” side, it should provide the Regulator with information about responsible and sustainable sourcing standards (including internationally recognised certification standards where applicable) and the market fundamentals, including liquidity, number of active participants, transparency, and whether the market operates fairly and orderly. [#TGT:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338] It should also be prepared to address any other factors the Regulator considers relevant to whether the Spot Commodity is appropriate for that activity. [#TGT:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338]

question: If a Person asks for a waiver or modification and the Regulator thinks the request is particularly complex or novel, when can the Regulator charge a supplementary fee, and what other kinds of work can also lead to a supplementary fee?
gold_answer: The Regulator can require a Person to pay a supplementary fee when it expects the work will involve substantial extra cost or substantial extra effort, and a waiver or modification request that is particularly complex or novel is a specific situation where it may do so. [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080] If, in the Regulator’s opinion, the waiver/modification request is especially complex or novel, it may require the Person to pay a supplementary fee for dealing with that request. [#SRC:ef45697b-2b10-450b-bacc-b9d501e87404] Beyond waiver/modification requests, the same supplementary-fee approach can apply when the Regulator is dealing with an application, an authorisation, a filing, or when it is conducting on-going supervision, provided it expects substantial additional costs or effort in those circumstances. [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080] Put together, the key points are that (1) the Regulator’s view about complexity/novelty can justify a supplementary fee for a waiver/modification request, and (2) the broader trigger is the Regulator’s expectation of substantial additional cost or effort across the listed types of regulatory work. [#SRC:ef45697b-2b10-450b-bacc-b9d501e87404] [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]

question: Where a Framework Contract permits the Payment Service Provider to implement proposed changes unilaterally unless the Payment Service User objects before the changes take effect, what combined pre-notification content and timing must the Payment Service Provider meet when communicating those proposed changes (including any deemed-acceptance and termination-right messaging)?
gold_answer: In this scenario, the Payment Service Provider must both (i) deliver the proposed changes within the required advance timeframe and (ii) include specific information to ensure the Payment Service User understands the consequences of not objecting and the available exit right. The proposed changes to the existing terms of the Framework Contract (and any changes to the information specified in Rule 19.2.1) must be provided to the Payment Service User no later than two months before the date the changes are intended to take effect (subject to Rule 19.2.7). [#TGT:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] In addition, where the Framework Contract allows unilateral implementation unless the Payment Service User notifies the Payment Service Provider to the contrary before the proposed entry-into-force date, the Payment Service Provider must inform the Payment Service User that the user will be treated as having accepted the changes communicated under Rule 19.2.4 if the user does not object in time. [#SRC:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1] The Payment Service Provider must also inform the Payment Service User that the user may terminate the Framework Contract without charge at any time before the proposed date the changes enter into force. [#SRC:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1] Together, these requirements mean the two-month notice must be paired with clear deemed-acceptance and no-fee pre-effective-date termination messaging for unilateral-change mechanisms. [#TGT:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] [#SRC:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1]

question: If the Framework Contract says the Payment Service Provider can change things unless the Payment Service User objects before the change starts, what does the Payment Service Provider have to tell the user, and how early must the proposed changes be sent?
gold_answer: The Payment Service Provider must do two things: send the proposed changes early enough, and include specific explanations about what happens if the Payment Service User stays silent and what the user can do before the change date. For timing, proposed changes to the existing terms of the Framework Contract (or to the information specified in Rule 19.2.1) must be provided to the Payment Service User at least two months before the date the changes are meant to take effect (subject to Rule 19.2.7). [#TGT:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] For content, when the Framework Contract allows unilateral changes unless the Payment Service User notifies the Payment Service Provider to the contrary before the proposed entry-into-force date, the Payment Service Provider must tell the Payment Service User that the user will be treated as having accepted the changes that were communicated under Rule 19.2.4. [#SRC:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1] The Payment Service Provider must also tell the Payment Service User that the user can end the Framework Contract without paying a charge at any time before the proposed date the changes start. [#SRC:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1] In practice, the two-month advance delivery and these two messages must be combined for this type of “silence means acceptance” change process. [#TGT:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] [#SRC:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1]

question: Where the Regulator issues a written notice directing an Authorised Person to submit returns in a different form, manner, or frequency than the Electronic Prudential Reporting System (EPRS) requirements (including the frequency of submission detailed in EPRS), what submission method and ongoing compliance approach must the Authorised Person follow, and when may it revert to the Rule 2.3.2 approach?
gold_answer: If the Regulator issues a written notice directing an Authorised Person to submit returns in a different form, manner, or frequency than the baseline prescribed approach, the Authorised Person must follow that direction rather than the default EPRS-based parameters. [#TGT:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b] Under the baseline rule, the Authorised Person is required to prepare returns in line with the Rules in the Chapter, relevant instructional guidelines in PRU and elsewhere, and the requirements of the Regulator’s Electronic Prudential Reporting System (EPRS), including the submission frequency specified in EPRS, and to submit those returns to the Regulator using EPRS. [#SRC:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9] However, the written notice mechanism allows the Regulator to override the prescribed form, manner, or frequency that would otherwise apply under Rule 2.3.2 (including what EPRS would otherwise require). [#TGT:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b] The Authorised Person must continue submitting returns in accordance with the Regulator’s direction on an ongoing basis, and it may only revert to the Rule 2.3.2 approach (including EPRS submission and EPRS frequency) once the Regulator issues a further written notice directing otherwise. [#TGT:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b] This means the operational submission method and cadence are governed by the most current written notice, even though the default framework is EPRS-based preparation and submission. [#SRC:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9]

question: Where Confidential Information is held by the Regulator (or its employees or agents) and is also in the hands of a primary recipient (or someone who obtained it from that primary recipient), whose prior consent is required before any disclosure can be made, and how do the two texts differ in describing the second consenting person when that person is not the original source?
gold_answer: Disclosure is prohibited unless prior consent is obtained from two categories of persons, and this applies both to the Regulator-side holders and to primary-recipient-side holders. [#SRC:fbbdae87-6f42-49d9-81a9-e75a30466d8a] Specifically, the discloser must obtain consent from (a) the person from whom the Confidential Information was obtained (described in the primary-recipient context as the person from whom the primary recipient obtained the information). [#SRC:fbbdae87-6f42-49d9-81a9-e75a30466d8a] [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866] In addition, if that person is different, a second consent is required; the SOURCE frames this as the person to whom the duty of confidentiality is owed, while the TARGET frames it as the person to whom the information relates. [#SRC:fbbdae87-6f42-49d9-81a9-e75a30466d8a] [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866] The scope of who is restricted also differs in expression but is complementary: the SOURCE expressly covers the Regulator, its employees, agents, and any person who comes into possession of Confidential Information, whereas the TARGET expressly covers a primary recipient and any person obtaining the information directly or indirectly from a primary recipient. [#SRC:fbbdae87-6f42-49d9-81a9-e75a30466d8a] [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866]

question: If someone wants to share Confidential Information and they either (1) got it from a primary recipient (directly or indirectly) or (2) is the Regulator (or its employees/agents) or otherwise came into possession of it, who must say “yes” first, and what is the extra “second person” called in each text when it’s not the same as the original source?
gold_answer: Before sharing Confidential Information, the person disclosing it must have prior consent from two people, and this requirement is stated for both the primary-recipient chain and the Regulator-side holders. [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866] [#SRC:fbbdae87-6f42-49d9-81a9-e75a30466d8a] First, consent is needed from the person the information originally came from (in the TARGET, this is the person from whom the primary recipient obtained the information; in the SOURCE, it is the person from whom the Confidential Information was obtained). [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866] [#SRC:fbbdae87-6f42-49d9-81a9-e75a30466d8a] Second, if that is a different person, consent is also needed from another person, but the two texts describe that person differently: the SOURCE calls them the person to whom the duty of confidentiality is owed, while the TARGET calls them the person to whom the information relates. [#SRC:fbbdae87-6f42-49d9-81a9-e75a30466d8a] [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866] The restriction applies broadly to the Regulator, its employees and agents, and anyone who comes into possession of the information, and also to a primary recipient and anyone who gets it from a primary recipient. [#SRC:fbbdae87-6f42-49d9-81a9-e75a30466d8a] [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866]

question: Where a Regulatory Filing is submitted after its due date, what fee must be paid, and what additional regulatory consequence is expressly contemplated beyond the fee under the late-submission framework?
gold_answer: A Regulatory Filing submitted after the due date triggers a mandatory late payment fee of $500 payable to the Regulator by the submitting entity, provided that entity is an Authorised Person, a Designated Non-Financial Business or Profession, or a Recognised Body. [#TGT:44e2c477-1fbd-46c4-9391-046045a5b105] This fee obligation sits within a broader late-submission fee framework described as covering fees payable for late submission of Regulatory Filings. [#SRC:641ef80a-a631-455c-b981-eb38f3805187] In addition to imposing the fee, the Regulator is expressly stated to have discretion to take further action in response to the late submission. [#SRC:641ef80a-a631-455c-b981-eb38f3805187] Practically, this means compliance planning should address both (i) the fixed monetary consequence for the specified categories of submitters when a filing is late and (ii) the possibility of additional steps by the Regulator beyond charging the fee. [#TGT:44e2c477-1fbd-46c4-9391-046045a5b105] [#SRC:641ef80a-a631-455c-b981-eb38f3805187]

question: If an Authorised Person files a Regulatory Filing after the due date, how much is the late fee, and does the Regulator have any stated option to do something more than just charge the fee?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person submits a Regulatory Filing after the due date, it must pay the Regulator a late payment fee of $500. [#TGT:44e2c477-1fbd-46c4-9391-046045a5b105] The same $500 fee requirement also applies when the late filer is a Designated Non-Financial Business or Profession or a Recognised Body, because those categories are listed alongside Authorised Person for late Regulatory Filings. [#TGT:44e2c477-1fbd-46c4-9391-046045a5b105] Separately from the amount of the fee, the late-submission fee framework is described as covering fees payable for late submission of Regulatory Filings and also notes that the Regulator may take further action in addition to imposing a fee. [#SRC:641ef80a-a631-455c-b981-eb38f3805187] So, the compliance takeaway is that a late filing can lead to both a defined $500 payment obligation for the specified types of filers and the possibility of additional action by the Regulator beyond the fee itself. [#TGT:44e2c477-1fbd-46c4-9391-046045a5b105] [#SRC:641ef80a-a631-455c-b981-eb38f3805187]

question: For an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, how should the prohibition on using a Client's Safe Custody Assets without the Client's prior written permission be operationalised within the Resolution Pack, including which specific record types must be included to evidence compliance?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must ensure it does not use a Client’s Safe Custody Assets for its own purpose or for another Person unless it has obtained the Client’s prior written permission, and it should be able to evidence that position through the records it places in its Resolution Pack. [#TGT:788b8b33-8176-4f23-8f1a-e6eab9427098] In practice, the Resolution Pack must include the specific record categories required for an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, including records that demonstrate whether and how any use of Client Investments is permitted. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] To align the written-permission prohibition with Resolution Pack content, the Authorised Person should include, at a minimum: (i) adequate records relating to Client Investments and the Client’s written permission regarding the use of Client Investments; (ii) master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client investments; and (iii) the most recent reconciliations of Client Investments. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] These records collectively support demonstrating that any use of assets held for clients is either not occurring or is supported by the required prior written permission, and that holdings are tracked and reconciled. [#TGT:788b8b33-8176-4f23-8f1a-e6eab9427098] The Resolution Pack also includes related client and agent records (e.g., client classification/client agreements and Third-Party Agent appropriateness/acknowledgements) that help evidence the broader control environment around client assets. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]

question: If an Authorised Person wants to use a Client’s Safe Custody Assets for itself or someone else, what permission is needed, and what Resolution Pack records should be kept to show that permission and control over the Client’s investments?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person is not allowed to use a Client’s Safe Custody Assets for its own purpose or for another Person unless it first has the Client’s written permission. [#TGT:788b8b33-8176-4f23-8f1a-e6eab9427098] To be able to demonstrate that this permission requirement is being followed, the Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must include specified records in its Resolution Pack, including records that relate directly to Client investments and permissions. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] In particular, the Resolution Pack must include: (a) adequate records and the Client’s written permission regarding the use of Client Investments; (b) master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client investments; and (c) the most recent reconciliations of Client Investments. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] These items help show whether any use of assets held for clients is supported by the required prior written permission and that the Authorised Person maintains up-to-date account lists and reconciliations for Client investments.
