[#TGT:ba1bf9ad-287d-4116-94cc-6433c0dab99a] [#SRC:d6502039-ce83-47db-bb83-74059097d005] To make the admission side demonstrably clear and transparent, the Recognised Investment Exchange should evaluate whether there is a sufficient range of Persons who already hold the Financial Instrument (or, if relevant, the underlying asset) or who are interested in dealing in it, because that breadth is tied to whether supply and demand forces will be adequate once admitted. [#SRC:d6502039-ce83-47db-bb83-74059097d005] It should also look at any limits on which Persons may hold or deal in the instrument, and any limits on the amounts that may be held, since these constraints shape how admission criteria will work in practice. [#SRC:d6502039-ce83-47db-bb83-74059097d005] In addition, it should have procedures to obtain information needed to decide whether trading should be suspended or discontinued, which supports maintaining fair and orderly trading through its procedures. [#SRC:d6502039-ce83-47db-bb83-74059097d005] [#TGT:ba1bf9ad-287d-4116-94cc-6433c0dab99a]

question: For an Authorised Person that conducts a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets and holds or controls Client Money, what are the applicable timing requirements for (i) the weekly reconciliation obligation and (ii) the deadlines for completing reconciliations under Rule 14.11.3 and Rule 14.11.4, each measured from the date to which the reconciliation relates?
gold_answer: For an Authorised Person that conducts a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets and holds or controls Client Money, the Client Account reconciliation timing is a combination of a minimum frequency requirement and specific completion deadlines tied to the reconciliation date. [#SRC:3a1b6f65-bf51-4f78-840e-f64d67f67a52] In this context, the reconciliation requirement corresponding to Rule 14.11.1 must be performed at least weekly, establishing the baseline cadence for carrying out reconciliations of Client Accounts. [#SRC:3a1b6f65-bf51-4f78-840e-f64d67f67a52] Separately, where the reconciliation being performed is the one referenced in Rule 14.11.3, it must be completed no later than ten days after the date to which that reconciliation relates. [#TGT:eb887a4e-7f25-4408-8cc8-5162893af162] Where the reconciliation being performed is the one referenced in Rule 14.11.4, it must be completed within five days after the date to which that reconciliation relates. [#SRC:3a1b6f65-bf51-4f78-840e-f64d67f67a52] Accordingly, the Authorised Person should schedule weekly reconciliations while ensuring that any Rule 14.11.4 reconciliation is finalised within five days and any Rule 14.11.3 reconciliation is finalised within ten days, each calculated from the relevant reconciliation date. [#SRC:3a1b6f65-bf51-4f78-840e-f64d67f67a52][#TGT:eb887a4e-7f25-4408-8cc8-5162893af162]

question: If an Authorised Person deals with Virtual Assets, holds or controls Client Money, and is doing Client Account reconciliations, how often do they need to do the weekly reconciliation, and how many days do they have to finish the reconciliations under Rule 14.11.3 and Rule 14.11.4 (counting from the date the reconciliation is for)?
gold_answer: When an Authorised Person conducts a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets and holds or controls Client Money, the Client Account reconciliation rules set both a minimum frequency and specific completion deadlines. [#SRC:3a1b6f65-bf51-4f78-840e-f64d67f67a52] First, the reconciliation requirement linked to Rule 14.11.1 must be done at least every week, so the Authorised Person cannot let more than a week pass between performing that reconciliation. [#SRC:3a1b6f65-bf51-4f78-840e-f64d67f67a52] Next, the time allowed to finish a reconciliation depends on which rule applies and is measured from the date to which the reconciliation relates. [#SRC:3a1b6f65-bf51-4f78-840e-f64d67f67a52] If the reconciliation is the one in Rule 14.11.3, it must be completed within ten days of that date. [#TGT:eb887a4e-7f25-4408-8cc8-5162893af162] If the reconciliation is the one in Rule 14.11.4, it must be completed within five days of that date. [#SRC:3a1b6f65-bf51-4f78-840e-f64d67f67a52] In practice, this means weekly performance is required, while completion deadlines are five days for Rule 14.11.4 and ten days for Rule 14.11.3, each counted from the relevant reconciliation date. [#SRC:3a1b6f65-bf51-4f78-840e-f64d67f67a52][#TGT:eb887a4e-7f25-4408-8cc8-5162893af162]

question: If a Customer becomes aware of an unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transaction but does not notify its Third Party Provider within twelve months after the date of execution, can the Customer still be entitled to redress, and what additional condition must be met regarding transaction information?
gold_answer: A Customer can still be entitled to redress despite missing the usual notification deadline, but only in the specific circumstance where the Third Party Provider did not provide or make available the required information about the Third Party Transaction in line with Section 20.3. [#TGT:e0ee4cf0-d2ae-4d3b-8012-62c5be6043a7] Ordinarily, the Customer’s entitlement to redress is conditional on notifying its Third Party Provider without undue delay and, at the latest, within twelve months after the date of execution once the Customer becomes aware of an unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transaction. [#SRC:d299e513-87d9-47de-9c0f-1f15cca91cbb] The linkage between these provisions is that the Target text creates an exception to the Source text’s time-based notification condition: if the Third Party Provider has failed the Section 20.3 information obligation, the Customer’s failure to notify within the Rule 20.10.1 time period does not prevent redress. [#TGT:e0ee4cf0-d2ae-4d3b-8012-62c5be6043a7] In practice, the Customer would need to establish (i) that the issue relates to an unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transaction and (ii) that the Third Party Provider failed to provide or make available the relevant transaction information as required, because only then does the missed twelve-month notification window cease to be disqualifying. [#SRC:d299e513-87d9-47de-9c0f-1f15cca91cbb] [#TGT:e0ee4cf0-d2ae-4d3b-8012-62c5be6043a7]

question: Normally, by when does a Customer have to tell its Third Party Provider about an unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transaction to get redress, and when can the Customer still get redress even if they miss that deadline?
gold_answer: Normally, a Customer only qualifies for redress if it notifies its Third Party Provider without undue delay and no later than twelve months after the date of execution, once the Customer becomes aware of an unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transaction. [#SRC:d299e513-87d9-47de-9c0f-1f15cca91cbb] However, the Customer can still be entitled to redress even if it does not notify within that time period when the Third Party Provider has failed to provide or make available information about the Third Party Transaction in accordance with Section 20.3. [#TGT:e0ee4cf0-d2ae-4d3b-8012-62c5be6043a7] Put together, this means the twelve-month (and “without undue delay”) notification condition is the default rule, but it is overridden in the specific case where the Third Party Provider did not meet the Section 20.3 information requirement for the transaction. [#SRC:d299e513-87d9-47de-9c0f-1f15cca91cbb] [#TGT:e0ee4cf0-d2ae-4d3b-8012-62c5be6043a7] To apply the exception, the situation must still involve a Third Party Transaction and the Customer’s awareness of an unauthorised or incorrectly executed transaction, but the decisive extra factor is the Third Party Provider’s failure regarding transaction information availability under Section 20.3. [#SRC:d299e513-87d9-47de-9c0f-1f15cca91cbb] [#TGT:e0ee4cf0-d2ae-4d3b-8012-62c5be6043a7]

question: For an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, how should the Resolution Pack content on reconciliations be aligned with the minimum reconciliation and counting frequencies for Client Accounts held with Third Party Agents and Safe Custody Assets, and what specific reconciliation records should be included?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business should ensure its Resolution Pack contains the most recent reconciliation records that evidence it is meeting the minimum reconciliation and counting cadence for Third Party Agent Client Accounts and Safe Custody Assets. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] In practice, this means the Resolution Pack should include the latest completed reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments, and those reconciliations should be current enough to reflect that (i) Client Accounts held with Third Party Agents are being reconciled at least monthly against the monthly statements received from those Third Party Agents, and (ii) Safe Custody Assets are being physically counted and reconciled to the Authorised Person’s records at least every six months. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] [#TGT:99a621ce-b3ab-4dbc-a9c7-eac1065776e6] The same six‑monthly minimum also applies to reconciling individual Client ledger balances to the Authorised Person’s records of Safe Custody Assets balances held in Client Accounts, so the “most recent reconciliations” included should cover that ledger-to-records reconciliation as well. [#TGT:99a621ce-b3ab-4dbc-a9c7-eac1065776e6] Overall, the Resolution Pack should therefore capture the latest reconciliation outputs that correspond to these monthly and six‑monthly processes, rather than older snapshots that would not demonstrate compliance with the stated frequencies. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] [#TGT:99a621ce-b3ab-4dbc-a9c7-eac1065776e6]

question: What reconciliation-related documents need to go into the Resolution Pack, and how often must the Authorised Person do the reconciliations and counts that those documents relate to (monthly vs every six months)?
gold_answer: The Resolution Pack must include the most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments for an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] Those “most recent” reconciliation records should line up with the minimum timing rules for the underlying processes, so they demonstrate that the Authorised Person is performing reconciliations and counts at the required intervals. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] Specifically, the Authorised Person must reconcile its records of Client Accounts held with Third Party Agents against the monthly statements received from those Third Party Agents at least every calendar month, so the Resolution Pack should contain reconciliation records reflecting that monthly cycle. [#TGT:99a621ce-b3ab-4dbc-a9c7-eac1065776e6] In addition, at least every six months the Authorised Person (or its Nominee Company) must physically count all Safe Custody Assets it holds and reconcile the count to its records, and it must also reconcile individual Client ledger balances to its records of Safe Custody Assets balances held in Client Accounts. [#TGT:99a621ce-b3ab-4dbc-a9c7-eac1065776e6] Putting these together, the Resolution Pack’s reconciliation section should be populated with the latest Client Money/Client Investments reconciliation outputs that correspond to the monthly Third Party Agent reconciliations and the six‑monthly Safe Custody Asset count and ledger reconciliations. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] [#TGT:99a621ce-b3ab-4dbc-a9c7-eac1065776e6]

question: If the Regulator discloses Confidential Information in good faith to further the Regulator's objectives, can the Regulator still require the requesting authority to accept limits on the uses of that information, and what is the relevant disclosure basis and control mechanism?
gold_answer: Yes. The Regulator may disclose Confidential Information in good faith either for the purposes of exercising the Regulator’s functions and powers or to further the Regulator’s objectives. [#TGT:c143e65b-358c-4ac8-855c-546a1c91e4d1] Separately, when the Regulator discloses Confidential Information under section 199(1), the Regulator may require the requesting authority to comply with specified conditions or to agree to restrictions on the uses to which the Confidential Information may be put, insofar as the Regulator considers appropriate. [#SRC:6b15279a-ffe6-4bc9-961d-d8d4a305ef6f] Read together, the disclosure basis (good-faith disclosure to support the Regulator’s functions/powers or objectives) explains when the Regulator may make the disclosure, while the control mechanism (conditions and use-restrictions imposed on the requesting authority) explains how the Regulator can manage the downstream handling of the information once disclosed. [#TGT:c143e65b-358c-4ac8-855c-546a1c91e4d1] [#SRC:6b15279a-ffe6-4bc9-961d-d8d4a305ef6f] The Regulator’s ability to impose such conditions is discretionary and is framed by what the Regulator considers appropriate in the circumstances. [#SRC:6b15279a-ffe6-4bc9-961d-d8d4a305ef6f]

question: For an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5 that holds Sukuk in its Trading Book, how must it treat those Sukuk when calculating its Equity Risk Capital Requirement, and which calculation approach options are available for its Trading Book transactions?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5 that holds Sukuk in its Trading Book must include those Sukuk in its Equity Risk Capital Requirement calculation by treating them as equity, rather than as a separate instrument type, for that specific capital requirement. [#SRC:8c633b61-fca7-4f77-954c-4acfa9f8d248] In addition, because the requirement is being calculated “in respect of Trading Book transactions,” the firm must use one of the permitted calculation approaches for those Trading Book transactions: either apply an internal Market Risk Model that has been approved by the Regulator for this purpose, or apply the Rules set out in Section A6.3. [#TGT:9584d41f-8a18-4d54-b6ee-8c0b40686e26] The equity treatment for Sukuk is a classification rule that determines how the position is handled within the Equity Risk Capital Requirement framework, and it must be applied when the firm performs the Trading Book calculation using whichever of the two permitted approaches it selects. [#SRC:8c633b61-fca7-4f77-954c-4acfa9f8d248] [#TGT:9584d41f-8a18-4d54-b6ee-8c0b40686e26] Finally, the firm must determine the resulting Equity Risk Capital Requirement for those Sukuk positions in accordance with PRU Rule 5.5.1, alongside using the applicable Trading Book calculation approach. [#SRC:8c633b61-fca7-4f77-954c-4acfa9f8d248]

question: If an Authorised Person (Category 1, 2 or 5) has Sukuk in its Trading Book, do those Sukuk count like equity for the Equity Risk Capital Requirement, and does the firm use an approved internal Market Risk Model or Section A6.3 rules to do the Trading Book calculation?
gold_answer: Yes. When an Authorised Person holds Sukuk in its Trading Book, it must treat those Sukuk as equity specifically for calculating its Equity Risk Capital Requirement. [#SRC:8c633b61-fca7-4f77-954c-4acfa9f8d248] For an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5, the Equity Risk Capital Requirement for Trading Book transactions must then be calculated using one of two allowed methods: either (a) apply its internal Market Risk Model, but only if that model has been approved by the Regulator for this purpose, or (b) apply the Rules set out in Section A6.3. [#TGT:9584d41f-8a18-4d54-b6ee-8c0b40686e26] Putting these together, the Sukuk’s “equity” treatment tells you how to classify the Trading Book position within the Equity Risk Capital Requirement, while the Category 1/2/5 rule tells you which calculation route you may use for Trading Book transactions (approved internal model or Section A6.3). [#SRC:8c633b61-fca7-4f77-954c-4acfa9f8d248] [#TGT:9584d41f-8a18-4d54-b6ee-8c0b40686e26] The firm must also determine the Equity Risk Capital Requirement for those Sukuk positions in accordance with PRU Rule 5.5.1. [#SRC:8c633b61-fca7-4f77-954c-4acfa9f8d248]

question: When an Authorised Person is assessing whether it may recognise the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative, how does the eligibility of an MDB provider interact with the requirement to apply a 0% risk weight to CR Exposure to specified institutions (e.g., the International Monetary Fund), and what does the Authorised Person need to verify in each case?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may recognise the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative only where the protection provider falls within one of the permitted entity categories, including an MDB referred to in Rules 4.12.7 to 4.12.9. [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] Separately, for capital treatment of certain exposures, the Authorised Person is required to apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank or the European Commission. [#TGT:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16] In practice, this means the Authorised Person must make two distinct determinations: first, whether the credit derivative’s CRM provider is eligible (for example, whether it is an MDB within the referenced rule set, or another listed entity type). [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] Second, where the exposure being risk-weighted is a CR Exposure to one of the named institutions (such as the International Monetary Fund), the Authorised Person must apply the mandated 0% risk weight to that exposure regardless of the CRM-provider eligibility analysis. [#TGT:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16] The CRM recognition test is about who provides the credit derivative protection, while the 0% risk weight rule is about the identity of the CR Exposure counterparty among the specified institutions. [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] [#TGT:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16]

question: If an Authorised Person wants to count a credit derivative as CRM, who can provide it, and how is that different from the rule that says some CR Exposures (like to the European Central Bank) get a 0% risk weight?
gold_answer: To count a credit derivative as CRM, the Authorised Person can only recognise its effects if the protection is provided by one of the allowed types of entities, such as a central government or central bank, an MDB referred to in Rules 4.12.7 to 4.12.9, an International Organisation referred to in Rule 4.12.9, a PSE, qualifying banks and Securities firms, or another entity with an external credit assessment mapping to Credit Quality Grade 3 or better. [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] This is a provider-eligibility test focused on who is giving the credit derivative protection. [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] By contrast, the 0% risk weight rule is about the exposure itself: the Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank or the European Commission. [#TGT:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16] So, even if a credit derivative provider is eligible under the CRM list, that does not change the separate requirement that a CR Exposure to one of those named institutions is risk-weighted at 0%. [#TGT:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16] The Authorised Person therefore needs to check (1) whether the CRM provider fits the permitted categories, and (2) whether the CR Exposure counterparty is one of the specifically listed institutions for 0% risk weight. [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] [#TGT:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16]

question: For an Authorised Person that is an existing ADGM licenced intermediary or MTF and wants to undertake Digital Securities activities, how do the authorisation fee consequences differ depending on whether the firm must amend the scope of its existing FSP to add a different Regulated Activity versus staying within its existing FSP scope, and how does this analysis apply where the relevant Regulated Activity is Arranging Custody, Advising on Investments or Credit, Arranging Deals in Investments, or Insurance Intermediation?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person that is an existing ADGM licenced intermediary or MTF is expanding into Digital Securities activities, the fee outcome turns on whether the firm is adding Digital Securities in connection with a different Regulated Activity (requiring a scope change) or instead providing Digital Securities-related Regulated Activities within the scope of its existing FSP. [#SRC:e793dc36-32f7-42e0-9421-773cac990928] Where the firm is seeking to expand its activities to include Digital Securities activities in relation to a different Regulated Activity, it must submit an application to amend the scope of its existing FSP, and the applicable fees are those specified in FEES Rule 3.8. [#SRC:e793dc36-32f7-42e0-9421-773cac990928] By contrast, where the firm intends to provide Regulated Activities in relation to Digital Securities within the scope of its existing FSP, no fees apply (subject to the stated cross-references), but the firm is expected to engage its FSRA Supervision Relationship Manager as early as possible due to potential broader fee or supervisory implications. [#SRC:e793dc36-32f7-42e0-9421-773cac990928] This fee/scope framework applies when the relevant Regulated Activity is one of the listed categories—Arranging Custody, Advising on Investments or Credit, Arranging Deals in Investments, or Insurance Intermediation—because those are Regulated Activities that may be conducted in relation to Digital Securities either via a scope amendment or within an existing scope. [#TGT:c49ba3cc-f21f-4336-905f-5e4ca3a8e16a]

question: Where a person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator is liable to pay compensation for an untrue or misleading statement in a Prospectus (or a material omission), how does the knowledge of the person who acquired the Securities affect whether liability is incurred under section 70(1) of the FSMR?
gold_answer: Liability to pay compensation for Prospectus-related loss can arise for any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, but that liability is not incurred under section 70(1) of the FSMR if the acquirer’s knowledge meets the specified threshold. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] In scope, the compensation regime applies where another person acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and suffered loss or damage because the Prospectus contained an untrue or misleading statement or omitted a material matter required to be included. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] However, a Person does not incur liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR if the person who incurred the loss acquired the relevant Securities with knowledge that the statement was false, misleading, or deceptive, or with knowledge of the omitted matter or of the change, or with knowledge of the new matter or inaccuracy. [#SRC:4ee654af-eec8-49f1-8813-6fb847d3eecb] Accordingly, even where the Prospectus contains an untrue or misleading statement or a required material omission that caused loss, the acquirer’s prior knowledge of the falsity/omission/change/new matter/inaccuracy operates to prevent liability being incurred under section 70(1) for that loss. [#SRC:4ee654af-eec8-49f1-8813-6fb847d3eecb] [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac]

question: If someone buys Securities linked to a Prospectus and later loses money because the Prospectus had a misleading statement or left out a required important fact, when would the person who is normally liable for that Prospectus not have liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR because of what the buyer knew?
gold_answer: A person who is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus can be required to pay compensation to a buyer who acquired Securities covered by that Prospectus and suffered loss or damage due to an untrue or misleading statement or the omission of a material matter that was required to be included. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] But section 70(1) liability is not incurred if the buyer (the person incurring the loss) bought the Securities while already knowing the relevant problem with the Prospectus content. [#SRC:4ee654af-eec8-49f1-8813-6fb847d3eecb] Specifically, there is no liability under section 70(1) if the buyer acquired the Securities with knowledge that the statement was false, misleading, or deceptive, or with knowledge of the omitted matter or of the change, or with knowledge of the new matter or inaccuracy. [#SRC:4ee654af-eec8-49f1-8813-6fb847d3eecb] This knowledge-based condition links directly to the same types of Prospectus defects that can otherwise trigger compensation—misleading statements and material omissions—so the buyer’s awareness at acquisition can block section 70(1) liability even where loss later occurs. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] [#SRC:4ee654af-eec8-49f1-8813-6fb847d3eecb]

question: How must an Authorised Person structure its Operational Risk policy so that it both governs approvals for new products, activities, processes and systems and also operationalises the requirement to identify and assess inherent Operational Risks across those same areas?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must design its Operational Risk policy so it is not only a governance document but also a mechanism that drives risk identification and assessment across the full scope of the firm’s products, activities, processes and systems. [#SRC:1af2c43c-aa79-4dbc-af29-f41f395434a2] In practice, this means the policy must include an approval process that applies to all new products, activities, processes and systems, and that approval process should be aligned with the policy’s incorporation of the requirement referenced in Rule 6.3.1(a). [#SRC:1af2c43c-aa79-4dbc-af29-f41f395434a2] To make that policy effective, the Authorised Person must ensure it identifies and assesses the Operational Risks inherent in all of its products, activities, processes and systems (not just new ones), and that the inherent risks are understood by relevant Employees. [#TGT:d260ee65-4db8-4608-abfd-17a444410052] The policy framework should also support systematic tracking of Operational Risk events and associated financial impacts, with tracking that is consistent with the Operational Risk event types described in the Basel III framework. [#TGT:d260ee65-4db8-4608-abfd-17a444410052]

question: If an Authorised Person launches something new (a product, activity, process, or system), what does its Operational Risk policy need to include, and what ongoing Operational Risk work must it do for all products, activities, processes and systems (including tracking events)?
gold_answer: When an Authorised Person introduces something new, its Operational Risk policy must include an approval process that covers all new products, activities, processes and systems, and the policy must also incorporate the requirement referenced in Rule 6.3.1(a). [#SRC:1af2c43c-aa79-4dbc-af29-f41f395434a2] Beyond the “new item” approval step, the Authorised Person must run ongoing Operational Risk management across the entire population of its products, activities, processes and systems by identifying and assessing the inherent Operational Risks in all of them. [#TGT:d260ee65-4db8-4608-abfd-17a444410052] It must also ensure those inherent risks are understood by relevant Employees, so the risk assessment is not confined to a small group. [#TGT:d260ee65-4db8-4608-abfd-17a444410052] In addition, it must systematically track Operational Risk events and any financial impact linked to those events, and it must ensure that this tracking aligns with the Operational Risk event types described in the Basel III framework. [#TGT:d260ee65-4db8-4608-abfd-17a444410052] Taken together, the policy’s approval process for new items should sit within a broader, continuous approach that assesses inherent risks and tracks events consistently. [#SRC:1af2c43c-aa79-4dbc-af29-f41f395434a2] [#TGT:d260ee65-4db8-4608-abfd-17a444410052]

question: When an Authorised Person is determining the CET1 deductions for holdings of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities under items (f), (g) and (h), on what position basis must the deductible amount be calculated, and how does that calculation instruction fit within the broader list of CET1 deduction items the Authorised Person must apply?
gold_answer: For CET1 deductions relating to holdings of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities under items (f), (g) and (h), the deductible amount must be computed using the gross long positions as the position basis, and that computation is stated to be subject to Rule 3.10.15. [#SRC:40c66431-d7b0-41ae-bc47-0ae63f4d9454] This gross-long-position calculation instruction operates within the wider CET1 deduction framework that requires an Authorised Person to deduct specified items from the calculation of its CET1 Capital, including (among others) current-year losses, goodwill and other IFRS-defined intangible assets, deferred tax assets dependent on future profitability, and defined benefit pension fund assets of the Authorised Person. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] Within that same list, the Relevant Entity holdings deductions are differentiated by context: reciprocal cross-holdings that artificially inflate the Authorised Person’s Capital Resources (item (f)), holdings where the Authorised Person does not have a significant investment (item (g), with an applicable amount referenced to Rule 3.10.13), and holdings where the Authorised Person has a significant investment (item (h), with an applicable amount referenced to Rules 3.10.13 and 3.10.18). [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] Accordingly, when applying those specific Relevant Entity holdings deductions, the Authorised Person must both (i) treat the holdings amount on a gross long position basis and (ii) apply the deduction as part of the overall CET1 deduction set required in the CET1 Capital calculation. [#SRC:40c66431-d7b0-41ae-bc47-0ae63f4d9454] [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]

question: If an Authorised Person has holdings in CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities, and those holdings fall under the deduction items about reciprocal cross-holdings or significant/non-significant investments, what kind of position (gross long or something else) should be used to work out the amount to deduct, and what other kinds of things are also deducted from CET1 Capital in the same list?
gold_answer: Where the Authorised Person’s deductions relate to holdings of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities that are captured by the deduction items for reciprocal cross-holdings (item (f)) or for holdings where the Authorised Person does or does not have a significant investment (items (g) and (h)), the amount to be deducted is calculated using gross long positions, and that calculation is stated to be subject to Rule 3.10.15. [#SRC:40c66431-d7b0-41ae-bc47-0ae63f4d9454] Those Relevant Entity holdings deductions sit inside a broader list of items that an Authorised Person must deduct from the calculation of its CET1 Capital. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] In that same list, the Authorised Person must also deduct items such as losses for the current financial year, goodwill and other intangible assets as defined in the International Financial Reporting Standards, deferred tax assets that rely on future profitability, and defined benefit pension fund assets of the Authorised Person. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] The list further includes deductions for certain holdings of the Authorised Person’s own CET1 Capital instruments (including instruments creating an actual or contingent obligation to purchase under an existing contractual obligation), and other specified deduction categories (e.g., certain excess AT1-related deductions and certain exposures deducted as an alternative to applying a 1000% risk weight). [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] So, for the Relevant Entity holdings items, the key position basis is gross long positions, applied within the overall CET1 deduction list. [#SRC:40c66431-d7b0-41ae-bc47-0ae63f4d9454] [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]

question: If the Regulator chooses not to send the notice under Rule 3.2.4(a) because it thinks the Fund Manager or the Public Fund is (or might later be) non-compliant, or because holding back helps meet its objectives, what does it have to tell the Fund Manager and how fast?
gold_answer: When the Regulator decides it will not transmit a notice under Rule 3.2.4(a), it must inform the Fund Manager of that decision. [#TGT:02c6d009-e171-41d6-adac-aaaaf2b66e5a] The timing is not flexible: the Regulator must notify the Fund Manager immediately once it has made the decision not to transmit a notice in accordance with Rule 3.2.5. [#SRC:de227401-76fb-48e7-90c5-1fe0553a4657] The reasons that can lead to the “do not transmit” decision include the Regulator considering that the Fund Manager or the Public Fund does not comply with applicable legislation (including these Rules), or that there are reasonable grounds to think the Fund Manager or the Public Fund may in the future not comply. [#TGT:02c6d009-e171-41d6-adac-aaaaf2b66e5a] Another permitted reason is that the Regulator considers it necessary and appropriate to refrain from transmitting the notice in order to meet its objectives. [#TGT:02c6d009-e171-41d6-adac-aaaaf2b66e5a] In all such cases, the required action is immediate notification to the Fund Manager that the notice will not be transmitted. [#SRC:de227401-76fb-48e7-90c5-1fe0553a4657]

question: In the context of an Exempt Offeror that wishes to voluntarily comply with the Listing Rules to include its Securities on the Official List and seek admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, what is the Regulator’s role in modifying chapter requirements, and how does that interact with the Recognised Investment Exchange’s prohibition on permitting trading unless the Securities are admitted to (and not suspended from) the Official List, including any stated exception?
gold_answer: For an Exempt Offeror seeking to have its Securities included in the Official List as a route to admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, the Regulator has discretion to modify one or more requirements of the relevant chapter to facilitate that voluntary compliance with the Listing Rules. [#SRC:46cdf9d3-2ae0-4bc2-8b02-87f68e832ddc] The practical significance is that, absent such a modification, the Exempt Offeror cannot achieve inclusion of its Securities on the Official List. [#SRC:46cdf9d3-2ae0-4bc2-8b02-87f68e832ddc] This matters because a Recognised Investment Exchange is prohibited from permitting trading of Securities on its facilities unless those Securities are admitted to, and not suspended from, the Official List. [#SRC:46cdf9d3-2ae0-4bc2-8b02-87f68e832ddc] In addition, the trading prohibition is framed with an explicit carve-out: the Recognised Investment Exchange may depart from the prohibition only where otherwise prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator. [#TGT:76d81d0b-f659-47be-bcb8-a99a24187cac] Accordingly, the Regulator’s modification power (for the Exempt Offeror’s voluntary Listing Rules compliance) and the Regulator-made Rules exception (for the Recognised Investment Exchange’s trading restriction) together define both the pathway to listing and the limited circumstances in which trading might be permitted without meeting the admitted-and-not-suspended condition. [#SRC:46cdf9d3-2ae0-4bc2-8b02-87f68e832ddc] [#TGT:76d81d0b-f659-47be-bcb8-a99a24187cac]

question: Where an Issuer makes an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM and therefore must publish a Prospectus, what defence is available to a person alleged to have contravened section 66(1) in relation to misleading or deceptive statements or omissions in that Prospectus, and what must be proven to rely on it?
gold_answer: In the context of an Issuer making an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM—where the offer regime includes an obligation to publish a Prospectus—the defence to an alleged contravention of section 66(1) for misleading or deceptive statements or omissions is available if the person can prove both reasonable-enquiry and reasonable-belief elements. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] Specifically, the person must demonstrate that they made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances, and that, after completing those enquiries, they believed on reasonable grounds that the Prospectus was not misleading or deceptive. [#TGT:39f7e2de-b1d8-46de-8603-e33e4cf70eaf] This defence is framed as an exception to committing the contravention: if the proof is made out, the person does not commit the contravention of section 66(1). [#TGT:39f7e2de-b1d8-46de-8603-e33e4cf70eaf] The linkage to the offer framework matters because the Prospectus is a required publication when an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, so the defence operates in relation to that Prospectus within the offer process. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd]

question: For purposes of determining whether the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement applies, how should an ADGM Green Portfolio treat an asset that qualifies as an Eligible Green Portfolio Asset because it is included in or otherwise tracks an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark, and how does that compare to the taxonomy-based eligibility route that requires only one Acceptable Green Taxonomy to be used by an ADGM Green Portfolio?
gold_answer: An asset that is treated as an Eligible Green Portfolio Asset specifically because it is included in or otherwise tracks an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark should be handled as exempt from the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement, because Rule 3.8.6 states that the attestation requirement does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark in accordance with Rule 3.8.4(b). [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86] To apply that exemption correctly, you must first confirm that the asset meets the eligibility condition of being included in or otherwise tracking an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark, since that is one of the defined ways an asset can be an Eligible Green Portfolio Asset. [#TGT:d2c4557a-05a9-47ae-90b5-b819cedfd9de] By contrast, an asset can also be an Eligible Green Portfolio Asset if it is considered environmentally sustainable (or equivalent) under an Acceptable Green Taxonomy, but that route is conditioned on the ADGM Green Portfolio using only one Acceptable Green Taxonomy. [#TGT:d2c4557a-05a9-47ae-90b5-b819cedfd9de] The exemption described above is tied to the EU Paris Aligned Benchmark pathway (and the Rule 3.8.4(b) linkage), not to the taxonomy-based pathway, so the taxonomy condition does not itself establish an attestation exemption in these passages. [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86] [#TGT:d2c4557a-05a9-47ae-90b5-b819cedfd9de]

question: If an asset is treated as “Eligible” because it tracks an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark, do you still need the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement, and what extra check applies when you instead rely on an Acceptable Green Taxonomy to make the asset eligible?
gold_answer: If the asset is eligible on the EU Paris Aligned Benchmark basis, the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to it, because Rule 3.8.6 removes the attestation requirement for Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark (linked to Rule 3.8.4(b)). [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86] You still need to confirm that the asset actually fits the definition of an Eligible Green Portfolio Asset by meeting that benchmark condition (i.e., it is included in or otherwise tracks an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark). [#TGT:d2c4557a-05a9-47ae-90b5-b819cedfd9de] If you are not using the benchmark route and instead want the asset to be eligible because it is considered environmentally sustainable (or equivalent) under an Acceptable Green Taxonomy, there is an additional constraint: only one Acceptable Green Taxonomy may be used by an ADGM Green Portfolio. [#TGT:d2c4557a-05a9-47ae-90b5-b819cedfd9de] The passages only describe the attestation exemption for the EU Paris Aligned Benchmark pathway, so you should not assume the same exemption applies just because the asset is eligible under a taxonomy. [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86] [#TGT:d2c4557a-05a9-47ae-90b5-b819cedfd9de]

question: When a Specified Benchmark is determined solely from information obtained from a market operated by a Recognised Body, a Multilateral Trading Facility or an Organised Trading Facility, and the Benchmark Administrator for that Specified Benchmark is also that same entity, how may the Benchmark Administrator satisfy its obligation to develop rules and practice standards setting out responsibilities for Specified Benchmark Information Providers, other Persons providing information from outside the ADGM, and the Benchmark Administrator itself?
gold_answer: In the scenario where the Specified Benchmark is calculated only using information from a market operated by a Recognised Body, a Multilateral Trading Facility, or an Organised Trading Facility, and the Benchmark Administrator is that same entity, the Benchmark Administrator can meet its rules-and-standards obligations by embedding the required rules and practice standards into that market operator’s own rulebook, provided this does not impair the Benchmark Administrator’s ability to meet its regulatory obligations. [#SRC:61e2c835-b6ed-4251-af9c-d261a5364a28] The underlying obligation is that, for each Specified Benchmark it administers, the Benchmark Administrator must develop rules and practice standards that allocate responsibilities, including those applicable under the Rules, across (i) Specified Benchmark Information Providers, (ii) other Persons who provide information in relation to a Specified Benchmark from outside the ADGM, and (iii) the Benchmark Administrator itself. [#TGT:4737f4ff-3c18-4805-ac10-40d295d242ac] Accordingly, where the market-operator conditions are met, the Benchmark Administrator may choose an “incorporation” approach rather than maintaining a separate standalone set of documents, but it must still ensure the incorporated content covers all required responsibility categories and remains compatible with its regulatory compliance. [#SRC:61e2c835-b6ed-4251-af9c-d261a5364a28] [#TGT:4737f4ff-3c18-4805-ac10-40d295d242ac]

question: If a Specified Benchmark uses only information from a market run by a Recognised Body, a Multilateral Trading Facility or an Organised Trading Facility, and that same entity is also the Benchmark Administrator, can it put its required rules and practice standards into the market’s own rules? What responsibilities still need to be covered?
gold_answer: Yes. When the Specified Benchmark is determined solely from information obtained from a market operated by a Recognised Body, a Multilateral Trading Facility, or an Organised Trading Facility, and the Benchmark Administrator is also that same entity, the Benchmark Administrator may choose to fold the required rules and practice standards into the rules of that market operator. [#SRC:61e2c835-b6ed-4251-af9c-d261a5364a28] This option is conditional: the incorporation must not undermine the Benchmark Administrator’s ability to comply with its regulatory obligations. [#SRC:61e2c835-b6ed-4251-af9c-d261a5364a28] Even if the rules are placed inside the market’s rulebook, the Benchmark Administrator still must have rules and practice standards for the Specified Benchmark it administers that clearly set out responsibilities (including those applicable under the Rules) for three groups: Specified Benchmark Information Providers, other Persons providing information in relation to a Specified Benchmark from outside the ADGM, and the Benchmark Administrator itself. [#TGT:4737f4ff-3c18-4805-ac10-40d295d242ac] In practice, the “where” conditions determine whether incorporation is available, while the responsibility categories determine what the incorporated rules must cover. [#SRC:61e2c835-b6ed-4251-af9c-d261a5364a28] [#TGT:4737f4ff-3c18-4805-ac10-40d295d242ac]

question: Where an issue of, or agreement to issue, Securities was made without approval under Rule 9.7.1 but later receives holder approval, how should the Listed Entity determine whether those Securities are counted as approved or instead counted within Relevant Issues under Rule 9.7.1, including the effect of any lapse of approval and the three‑month issuance condition?
gold_answer: For Rule 9.7.1 counting purposes, the Listed Entity must treat the Securities as approved only if the conditions for treating a non-approved issue as approved are satisfied and the approval has not lapsed. [#TGT:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6] Specifically, an issue (or agreement to issue) made without approval under Rule 9.7.1 is treated as having been made with approval for Rule 9.7.1 only when (i) the issue or agreement stayed within the Rule 9.7.1 limit, (ii) the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities subsequently approve it, and (iii) the Securities are issued within three months after that approval date. [#TGT:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6] However, if the approval under Rule 9.7.5 lapses, the Securities can no longer be counted as Securities issued with approval under Rule 9.7.5 for the purposes of Rule 9.7.1. [#SRC:76970fb8-577b-4a21-8996-4c8bde4ef2d2] In that lapse scenario, those Securities must instead be counted within Relevant Issues under Rule 9.7.1. [#SRC:76970fb8-577b-4a21-8996-4c8bde4ef2d2] Accordingly, the entity should apply the three-month issuance timing and other subsequent-approval conditions to determine whether the issue is treated as approved, and separately ensure that any lapse of Rule 9.7.5 approval triggers reclassification into Relevant Issues for Rule 9.7.1 counting. [#TGT:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6] [#SRC:76970fb8-577b-4a21-8996-4c8bde4ef2d2]

question: If a Listed Entity issues (or agrees to issue) Securities without Rule 9.7.1 approval, what has to happen for it to be treated as approved, and what changes if the approval under Rule 9.7.5 later lapses when you are counting it under Rule 9.7.1?
gold_answer: To count the Securities as approved for Rule 9.7.1 even though the issue (or agreement) was made without Rule 9.7.1 approval, the Listed Entity must meet all the later-approval conditions and also avoid any later loss of the relevant approval status. [#TGT:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6] The later-approval pathway applies only if the issue or agreement stayed within the Rule 9.7.1 limit, the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities later approve it, and the Securities are actually issued within three months after the approval date. [#TGT:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6] Separately, if the approval under Rule 9.7.5 lapses, the Securities stop being counted as Securities issued with approval under Rule 9.7.5 for Rule 9.7.1 purposes. [#SRC:76970fb8-577b-4a21-8996-4c8bde4ef2d2] When that lapse happens, those Securities must be counted within Relevant Issues under Rule 9.7.1 instead of being treated as approved under Rule 9.7.5. [#SRC:76970fb8-577b-4a21-8996-4c8bde4ef2d2] In practice, you determine whether the later-approval conditions (including the three-month issuance timing) are satisfied for Rule 9.7.1 treatment, and you also check whether any Rule 9.7.5 approval has lapsed because that changes the counting category to Relevant Issues. [#TGT:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6] [#SRC:76970fb8-577b-4a21-8996-4c8bde4ef2d2]

question: If an Authorised Person wants to use a Client’s Safe Custody Assets for itself or someone else, what must it do first and what proof has to be kept in the Resolution Pack, including any checks on Client Investments?
gold_answer: Before using a Client’s Safe Custody Assets for its own purpose or for another Person, an Authorised Person must have systems and controls that ensure it gets the Client’s prior written permission. [#TGT:82a79456-0923-48f0-8521-17b43774e939] Those systems and controls must also ensure it keeps adequate records to protect the Safe Custody Assets when they are used (including where they are applied as collateral or used for stock lending), returns equivalent assets to the Client’s Client Account, and ensures the Client is not disadvantaged by the use. [#TGT:82a79456-0923-48f0-8521-17b43774e939] To make this auditable in a resolution scenario, the Resolution Pack for an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must include records covering adequate records and the Client’s written permission regarding the use of Client Investments, which provides documentary evidence of the permission and recordkeeping aspects of using client-held assets. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] The Resolution Pack must also include the most recent reconciliations of Client Investments, which supports demonstrating that holdings are tracked and can be aligned with returning equivalent assets to the Client Account. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]

question: If an auditor or actuary breaks these Regulations, what can the Regulator do about stopping them from working for an Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity, and what things does the Regulator look at to decide how broad that ban should be?
gold_answer: If the Regulator considers an auditor or actuary has committed a contravention of these Regulations, it may disqualify that person from being the auditor of, or acting as an actuary for, any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity, or it may limit the disqualification to a particular class of those entities. [#TGT:5cca9150-8e16-41b4-a5ef-74950916d06e] To decide both whether to use this power and how wide the disqualification should be, the Regulator takes account of all the circumstances of the case and applies a multi-factor assessment. [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22] That assessment includes how serious the contravention is and what impact it has had, and whether the contravention (or a failure to disclose information to the Regulator) has caused or is likely to cause loss to customers, harm the reputation of the ADGM, or raise the risk that a firm, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity could be used for financial crime. [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22] The Regulator also considers what the auditor or actuary has done to fix the issue, whether a relevant professional body has taken (or will take) disciplinary action and whether that action is sufficient, and the person’s past compliance record including any relevant prior sanctions. [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22]

question: Where an application concerns activities relating to Spot Commodities that will be carried on by a Recognised Body (whether a Recognised Investment Exchange or Recognised Clearing House), how should the applicant determine the applicable application fee when the applicant is also an Applicant for a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Principal (but not as a Matched Principal)?
gold_answer: If the application is framed as one concerning activities relating to Spot Commodities to be carried on by a Recognised Body (either a Recognised Investment Exchange or a Recognised Clearing House), the fee basis is the one identified as applying under Section 4.1 for that type of application. [#SRC:19820def-9e05-4e0c-8343-22a9bad586f1] Separately, where the same applicant is an Applicant for a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Principal (and explicitly not as a Matched Principal), the applicant has a stated obligation to pay the Regulator an application fee of $40,000. [#TGT:957c813c-93ef-4a38-aacd-a92bd99e168c] In practical terms, the applicant should identify whether the application “concerns” the Spot Commodities activities to be carried on by the Recognised Body (which triggers the Section 4.1 fee framework) and also confirm whether it is applying for the specified Financial Services Permission (which triggers the $40,000 fee). [#SRC:19820def-9e05-4e0c-8343-22a9bad586f1] [#TGT:957c813c-93ef-4a38-aacd-a92bd99e168c] The two passages together indicate that fee determination depends on both (i) the nature of the activities and the actor (Recognised Body) and (ii) whether the applicant is seeking permission for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as a Matched Principal) with the associated $40,000 payment to the Regulator. [#SRC:19820def-9e05-4e0c-8343-22a9bad586f1] [#TGT:957c813c-93ef-4a38-aacd-a92bd99e168c]

question: If an application is about Spot Commodities activities that will be carried on by a Recognised Body (a Recognised Investment Exchange or Recognised Clearing House), and the same applicant is also applying for Financial Services Permission to deal in investments as principal (not as a matched principal), what fee information do they need to use from each passage to work out what they must pay?
gold_answer: You need to use both passages because each points to a different fee trigger based on what the application covers. If the application concerns activities relating to Spot Commodities that will be carried on by a Recognised Body (either a Recognised Investment Exchange or a Recognised Clearing House), then the fees that apply are the ones in Section 4.1 for that situation. [#SRC:19820def-9e05-4e0c-8343-22a9bad586f1] In addition, if the applicant is an Applicant for a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Principal (and not as a Matched Principal), the applicant must pay the Regulator an application fee of $40,000. [#TGT:957c813c-93ef-4a38-aacd-a92bd99e168c] To work out what they must pay, the applicant should (1) confirm whether their application is the kind that “concerns” Spot Commodities activities carried on by a Recognised Body (which points them to Section 4.1 fees), and (2) confirm whether they are applying for the specific Dealing in Investments as Principal permission (which carries the $40,000 fee). [#SRC:19820def-9e05-4e0c-8343-22a9bad586f1] [#TGT:957c813c-93ef-4a38-aacd-a92bd99e168c] Together, these details show that fee obligations depend on both the Spot Commodities/Recognised Body context and the specific Financial Services Permission being sought. [#SRC:19820def-9e05-4e0c-8343-22a9bad586f1] [#TGT:957c813c-93ef-4a38-aacd-a92bd99e168c]

question: Where a Relevant Person is maintaining the record categories listed for CDD/due diligence, transaction reconstruction, suspicious activity notifications/reports, FIU communications, and other required matters for the stated retention period, may those records be kept electronically, and what accessibility standard applies when the Regulator requests information?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person may keep the records it is required to maintain—including CDD/due diligence materials, transaction and account records, suspicious activity notifications and reports, FIU communications, and other expressly required matters—in electronic format, but only if the electronic records are readily accessible and can be produced promptly when the Regulator asks for information. [#SRC:54721870-44ed-4aad-a842-fe0cd9ded618] The scope of what must be maintained (where relevant) includes: copies of documents and information obtained for initial and ongoing CDD or due diligence on business partners; original documents or certified copies for the customer business relationship (including business correspondence, transaction records sufficient to reconstruct individual transactions, and internal findings/analysis for unusual or suspicious activity whether or not a Suspicious Activity/Transaction Report is filed); internal notifications to its MLRO; Suspicious Activity/Transaction Reports with supporting materials; communications with the FIU; the documents in Rule 4.6.1; and any other matter expressly required to be recorded under the Rules. [#TGT:2bb23374-a3ae-4dd1-af3e-7222ecda1e98] Those records must be kept for at least six years, measured from the latest of: the date a notification or report was made, the end of the business relationship, or completion of the Transaction. [#TGT:2bb23374-a3ae-4dd1-af3e-7222ecda1e98] The electronic-format permission does not remove the obligation to ensure rapid responsiveness to Regulator information requests. [#SRC:54721870-44ed-4aad-a842-fe0cd9ded618]

question: When the Fund Manager of a Passported Fund (or the governing body or trustee) notifies the Regulator of a material event—such as an amended Prospectus or the commencement of winding-up—what subsequent notification must the Regulator make, and what timing standard applies to that onward notification, given the Regulator’s duty upon receiving a notification described in Rule 6.6.2?
gold_answer: Where the Fund Manager of a Passported Fund (or the governing body or trustee) gives the Regulator a notification of a material event of the kind specified (including, for example, an amended or replaced Prospectus or the commencement of winding-up), the Regulator is then required to pass that change on to the relevant Host Regulator. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] The timing standard for the Regulator’s onward step is that, upon receiving a notification described in Rule 6.6.2, it must notify the relevant Host Regulator “without undue delay.” [#SRC:f1c064bd-93c8-459f-b7fa-fd9ed79b4669] In practice, this creates a two-stage notification chain: - First, the Fund Manager (or the governing body or trustee) must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable of material events, and for the listed events must do so as soon as practicable and no later than seven days after becoming aware. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] - Second, once the Regulator receives such a notification (as described in Rule 6.6.2), it must notify the relevant Host Regulator without undue delay of the changes. [#SRC:f1c064bd-93c8-459f-b7fa-fd9ed79b4669] Accordingly, the Fund Manager’s “as soon as practicable” (and, for specified events, seven-day) deadline governs the initial report to the Regulator, while the Regulator’s obligation is an immediate onward notification standard framed as “without undue delay.” [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] [#SRC:f1c064bd-93c8-459f-b7fa-fd9ed79b4669]

question: When a Third Party Provider is required to make dispute resolution service details available to the Customer in a clear, comprehensive and easily accessible form, through which specific channels must that information be made available, given the Rule 20.13.3 availability locations?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider must provide the Customer with details of the dispute resolution services that can handle disputes about rights and obligations arising under this Chapter, and it must do so in a manner that is clear, comprehensive, and easily accessible. [#TGT:08650621-06b8-481f-8650-2c5ebdb06be0] To meet the required accessibility standard using the specified availability locations, the information must be made available through all of the following channels: on the Third Party Provider’s website, at the Third Party Provider’s main office and any branches, and within the general terms and conditions of the Governing Contract. [#SRC:055fc91a-22c6-4511-9508-b90212a4d414] In practice, this means the Third Party Provider should ensure the same dispute resolution service details are presented to the Customer across each of these locations so the Customer can readily find and use them. [#TGT:08650621-06b8-481f-8650-2c5ebdb06be0] [#SRC:055fc91a-22c6-4511-9508-b90212a4d414] The obligation is framed as a “must” requirement on the Third Party Provider, and it is specifically tied to disputes concerning rights and obligations arising under this Chapter, rather than unrelated complaints. [#TGT:08650621-06b8-481f-8650-2c5ebdb06be0]

question: If a Customer asks where they can find the dispute resolution service details, what places does the Third Party Provider have to put that information so it is easy to access?
gold_answer: The Third Party Provider must make available to the Customer the details of the dispute resolution services that can deal with disputes about the rights and obligations arising under this Chapter, and those details must be provided in a clear, comprehensive, and easily accessible way. [#TGT:08650621-06b8-481f-8650-2c5ebdb06be0] The required availability locations for information made available under Rule 20.13.3 indicate that the information must be accessible in three concrete places: (a) on the website of the Third Party Provider, (b) at the main office and any branches of the Third Party Provider, and (c) in the general terms and conditions of the Governing Contract. [#SRC:055fc91a-22c6-4511-9508-b90212a4d414] Putting the dispute resolution service details in each of these locations supports the requirement that the Customer can access the information easily, including online, in-person at offices/branches, and within the contract terms they receive. [#TGT:08650621-06b8-481f-8650-2c5ebdb06be0] [#SRC:055fc91a-22c6-4511-9508-b90212a4d414] The content that must be made available is specifically the details of dispute resolution services that are able to handle disputes tied to rights and obligations under this Chapter. [#TGT:08650621-06b8-481f-8650-2c5ebdb06be0]

question: For an SFT in which both the Exposure and the Collateral are Securities issued by central governments, when may an Authorised Person set HE, HC and HS to zero, and how does the required risk-weighting for a CR Exposure in the central government and central bank asset class (including the Credit Quality Grade 1 outcome) support that determination?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may set HE, HC and HS to zero for an SFT only where (i) both the Exposure and the Collateral are Securities issued by central governments, (ii) the banking regulator in the relevant jurisdiction has prescribed a value of zero for that treatment, and (iii) Exposures to that jurisdiction’s central government have a Credit Quality Grade of 1 under the referenced table. [#SRC:ed63c9d6-51da-4984-9431-9a2ca8dc0d03] The Credit Quality Grade condition is reinforced by the central government and central bank asset class risk-weight table, which assigns a 0% risk weight to Credit Quality Grade 1 exposures (and higher risk weights to lower grades and unrated exposures). [#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6] Practically, the Authorised Person should confirm that the exposure being considered is to the relevant central government and that it qualifies as Credit Quality Grade 1, because the zero-HE/HC/HS option is explicitly tied to that grade rather than to other grades or unrated status. [#SRC:ed63c9d6-51da-4984-9431-9a2ca8dc0d03][#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6] If the exposure is not Credit Quality Grade 1 (or is unrated), the risk-weight table indicates it would not receive the 0% outcome, and the SFT would not meet the stated condition for applying zero to HE, HC and HS. [#SRC:ed63c9d6-51da-4984-9431-9a2ca8dc0d03][#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6]

question: If an Authorised Person has an SFT where both the Exposure and the Collateral are central government Securities, what exact conditions must be true to use zero for HE, HC and HS, and what does the central government/central bank risk-weight table say about Credit Quality Grade 1 that links to that choice?
gold_answer: Zero can be used for HE, HC and HS in this SFT scenario only when all of the following are met: the Exposure and the Collateral are both Securities issued by central governments; the banking regulator of that jurisdiction has prescribed a value of zero for that case; and Exposures to that jurisdiction’s central government are Credit Quality Grade 1 under the relevant table. [#SRC:ed63c9d6-51da-4984-9431-9a2ca8dc0d03] The link to Credit Quality Grade 1 is meaningful because the central government and central bank asset class table assigns a 0% risk weight to Credit Quality Grade 1 exposures, while other grades and unrated exposures receive higher risk weights (including 20%, 50%, 100%, 150%, or 100% for unrated). [#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6] In other words, the SFT zero-HE/HC/HS option is not a general rule for all central government exposures; it is specifically tied to the jurisdictional “zero prescribed” condition and to the exposure being Credit Quality Grade 1, which aligns with the 0% risk-weight outcome shown in the table. [#SRC:ed63c9d6-51da-4984-9431-9a2ca8dc0d03][#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6] If the exposure is not Credit Quality Grade 1 (including if it is unrated), the table does not show a 0% risk weight, so the stated precondition for setting HE, HC and HS to zero would not be satisfied. [#SRC:ed63c9d6-51da-4984-9431-9a2ca8dc0d03][#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6]

question: If a Payment Service Provider intends to amend the Framework Contract’s disclosure of charges payable by the Payment Service User (including any breakdown of amounts), what is the minimum advance notice period for providing that proposed amendment to the Payment Service User, and why does that charges disclosure qualify as information whose change triggers the notice requirement?
gold_answer: A proposed amendment to the Framework Contract’s charges disclosure must be provided by the Payment Service Provider to the Payment Service User no later than two months before the date the amendment is intended to take effect. [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] This timing applies because the notice rule covers proposed changes to both the existing terms of the Framework Contract and the information that is specified as required contract content. [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] The charges disclosure qualifies as such specified information because a Framework Contract must include details of all charges payable by the Payment Service User to the Payment Service Provider, including charges connected to information that is provided or made available, and (where applicable) a breakdown of the amounts of all charges. [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] Accordingly, changing the charges disclosure is not merely a commercial update; it is a change to information that the Framework Contract is required to contain, which brings it within the category of changes that must be communicated in advance. [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] The operational compliance outcome is that the Payment Service Provider should plan the effective date of any revised charges (and any revised breakdown) to allow at least a two-month lead time for delivering the proposed change to the Payment Service User. [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5]

question: When a Recognised Clearing House determines whether it holds capital at least equal to the required sum of risk-based components, how must it source and treat the operational-expense figures used for (i) the six months’ gross operational expenses element and (ii) the minimum floor tied to annual gross operational expenses for business risk?
gold_answer: A Recognised Clearing House must ensure its total capital is at least the sum of the specified risk components, including an amount for winding down or restructuring equal to six months’ gross operational expenses and a business-risk amount that cannot be below 25% of its annual gross operational expenses. [#TGT:fedb7b40-56a0-4cc6-97c6-fef115fc6c1b] To populate the operational-expense figures used in both of those components, it must use the most recent audited information from its annual financial statement. [#SRC:6d70e8b6-10a0-4b13-b3be-912e662e25b0] In addition, when identifying and treating operational expenses for these calculations, it must consider operational expenses in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS), so that the expense base used for the six-month measure and the annual-expense minimum floor is determined on an IFRS basis. [#SRC:6d70e8b6-10a0-4b13-b3be-912e662e25b0] Separately, for business risk it must submit its own estimate of capital needed to cover losses from business risk to the Regulator for approval, and the resulting capital requirement equals that approved estimate but remains subject to the 25% annual gross operational-expense minimum. [#TGT:fedb7b40-56a0-4cc6-97c6-fef115fc6c1b]

question: In calculating the capital sum a Recognised Clearing House must hold, how do the operational-expense inputs used for the winding-down/restructuring component interact with the business-risk minimum, and what specific source and accounting basis must be applied to those operational-expense inputs?
gold_answer: The capital a Recognised Clearing House must hold must be no less than the sum of capital calculated for multiple risks, including (i) winding down or restructuring activities measured as six months’ gross operational expenses and (ii) business risk, where the capital requirement equals the Regulator-approved estimate but is subject to a minimum of 25% of annual gross operational expenses. [#TGT:fedb7b40-56a0-4cc6-97c6-fef115fc6c1b] Because both components depend directly on operational-expense amounts (six months of gross operational expenses and a percentage of annual gross operational expenses), the Recognised Clearing House must ensure those operational-expense inputs are derived consistently from the most recent audited information in its annual financial statement. [#SRC:6d70e8b6-10a0-4b13-b3be-912e662e25b0] It must also treat operational expenses in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS), meaning the operational-expense base used to compute both the six-month amount and the annual-expense minimum floor is determined on an IFRS basis. [#SRC:6d70e8b6-10a0-4b13-b3be-912e662e25b0] This linkage ensures that the operational-expense figures feeding into the required capital sum are both audited and IFRS-consistent while still meeting the distinct quantitative requirements for winding down/restructuring and the business-risk minimum. [#TGT:fedb7b40-56a0-4cc6-97c6-fef115fc6c1b]

question: If a reconciliation is done under Rule 15.9.1, who has to review it, and what written statement must the individual referred to in Rule 15.9.4 provide about how the reconciliation was done?
gold_answer: When the reconciliation is one that is performed in accordance with Rule 15.9.1, it must be reviewed by a member of the Authorised Person who has adequate seniority. [#TGT:60712e89-ce53-445d-81a8-f2d744fc8851] In addition to that review step, the individual referred to in Rule 15.9.4 has a separate documentation duty: they must provide a written statement. [#SRC:bcd90aa9-d7d1-47be-b4cb-45b877ddba30] The content of that written statement is specific—it must confirm that the reconciliation has been undertaken in accordance with the requirements of the section. [#SRC:bcd90aa9-d7d1-47be-b4cb-45b877ddba30] Putting the two passages together, the reconciliation process for a Rule 15.9.1 reconciliation includes both (i) a review by an adequately senior member of the Authorised Person and (ii) a written confirmation from the Rule 15.9.4 individual that the reconciliation was carried out as required by the section. [#TGT:60712e89-ce53-445d-81a8-f2d744fc8851] [#SRC:bcd90aa9-d7d1-47be-b4cb-45b877ddba30] These are distinct requirements: one addresses who must review the reconciliation, and the other addresses who must provide written confirmation and what that confirmation must cover. [#TGT:60712e89-ce53-445d-81a8-f2d744fc8851] [#SRC:bcd90aa9-d7d1-47be-b4cb-45b877ddba30]

question: If a Listed Entity wants to issue Shares with Weighted Voting Rights, what does it need to do about Regulator approval, and how does the Board’s rule about treating holders of the same class or type of Securities equally fit with the fact that weighted voting changes voting power and equity interest?
gold_answer: The Listed Entity may issue Shares with Weighted Voting Rights only if it first obtains approval from the Regulator, because the rule allowing weighted voting is expressly conditional on that approval. [#SRC:12f21edd-7868-4706-b1f4-3b2e9af8d6aa] Those Shares are described as changing the equality and proportionality of Shareholder voting power and equity interest (as established in Rule 9.3.3), so the Listed Entity is intentionally altering how voting power and equity interest relate among shareholders. [#SRC:12f21edd-7868-4706-b1f4-3b2e9af8d6aa] Separately, the Board must ensure equality of treatment for all holders of Securities within the same class or type, covering all rights that attach to that class or type. [#TGT:194cf07e-3ce5-429a-9d01-6e1c25bef4ae] Putting these together, the Board should approach the weighted voting feature as part of the rights attached to the relevant Shares and then ensure that, within that class or type, holders are treated equally in respect of those attached rights, even though the weighted voting structure itself is a permitted mechanism (with approval) that alters equality and proportionality of voting power and equity interest. [#TGT:194cf07e-3ce5-429a-9d01-6e1c25bef4ae] [#SRC:12f21edd-7868-4706-b1f4-3b2e9af8d6aa]

question: When an Authorised Person is considering recognising the effects of CRM for a guarantee provided by an MDB, what condition must be met for the guarantee to be eligible for CRM recognition, and how must the Authorised Person risk-weight any CR Exposure to a qualifying MDB such as the Asian Development Bank (ADB)?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may only treat a guarantee as eligible CRM where the guarantor falls within the permitted categories for recognising the effects of CRM of a guarantee, which expressly includes an MDB (as referenced in the relevant MDB rule cross-reference). [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d] Separately, for credit risk purposes, the Authorised Person is required to apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to a qualifying MDB listed in the MDB asset class provision, and that list includes the Asian Development Bank (ADB). [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] In practice, this means the CRM-recognition question for a guarantee turns on whether the guarantor is an eligible entity type (here, an MDB), while the exposure risk-weighting question turns on whether the MDB is one of the specifically enumerated qualifying institutions (such as ADB). [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d] [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4]

question: If a guarantee is provided by a member of The World Bank Group, how should an Authorised Person determine (i) whether the guarantee’s CRM effects may be recognised and (ii) whether a 0% risk weight applies to a CR Exposure to that institution, taking into account that The World Bank Group includes IBRD, MIGA, and IFC?
gold_answer: For CRM purposes, an Authorised Person may recognise the effects of CRM of a guarantee only where the guarantor is one of the specified eligible entity types, which include an MDB (as referenced in the MDB rule cross-reference). [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d] For risk-weighting of exposures, the Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to the qualifying MDBs listed in the MDB asset class provision. [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] The World Bank Group is explicitly identified as a qualifying MDB for this purpose, and it is defined there as comprising the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA), and the International Finance Corporation (IFC). [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] Accordingly, if the guarantor is IBRD, MIGA, or IFC, the guarantee can be assessed for CRM recognition under the eligible-guarantor categories (including MDBs), and any CR Exposure to that institution must be assigned a 0% risk weight because it is within the listed qualifying MDB set. [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d] [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4]

question: Where a Recognised Investment Exchange’s Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to operate an MTF, how should the Recognised Investment Exchange determine which rulebook applies to (i) the MTF function when it is operated using Virtual Assets and (ii) the remainder of its operations, given that COBS applies to the MTF/OTF function only?
gold_answer: If a Recognised Investment Exchange’s Recognition Order contains the required stipulation, it may carry on the Regulated Activity of operating an MTF (and, where relevant, an OTF), but the applicable requirements must be allocated by function. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388] For the MTF function specifically, the Recognised Investment Exchange must apply the specific rules on MTFs and OTFs in COBS to that function, and only to that function. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388] Where the stipulation relates to operating an MTF using Virtual Assets, the Recognised Investment Exchange must also meet the requirements of the Virtual Asset Framework in relation to operating that MTF (using Virtual Assets). [#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb] In parallel, the remainder of the Recognised Investment Exchange’s operations (i.e., activities outside the MTF function) must continue to be operated in compliance with the MIR Rules. [#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb] Accordingly, the compliance approach is to (1) confirm the Recognition Order stipulation permitting operation of the MTF, (2) treat the MTF function as the scope for COBS MTF/OTF rules, and (3) where Virtual Assets are used in operating the MTF, apply the Virtual Asset Framework to that MTF operation while maintaining MIR Rules compliance for all other operations. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388] [#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb]

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange is allowed by its Recognition Order to run an MTF, what rules apply to the MTF part (especially if it uses Virtual Assets) and what rules apply to everything else it does?
gold_answer: When a Recognised Investment Exchange’s Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to operate an MTF (and potentially an OTF), it may carry on that regulated function, but it must separate which requirements apply to which part of its business. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388] For the MTF function itself, the specific COBS rules on MTFs and OTFs apply, and they apply only to that function rather than to the Recognised Investment Exchange’s other activities. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388] If the stipulation is granted for operating an MTF using Virtual Assets, then, for that MTF operation using Virtual Assets, the Recognised Investment Exchange must meet the requirements of the Virtual Asset Framework. [#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb] At the same time, the rest of the Recognised Investment Exchange’s operations (outside the MTF using Virtual Assets function) must continue to be run in compliance with the MIR Rules.
