[#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb] Practically, this means the Recognised Investment Exchange should (i) confirm the Recognition Order stipulation exists, (ii) apply COBS to the MTF function, (iii) apply the Virtual Asset Framework to the MTF when it uses Virtual Assets, and (iv) keep all remaining operations aligned with the MIR Rules. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388] [#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb]

question: Before publishing a financing proposal for a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, what due diligence must a PFP Operator carry out to support the disclosure requirements, and what records of that due diligence and related materials must the PFP Operator retain (and for how long)?
gold_answer: A PFP Operator must complete due diligence on the PFP Prospect before it publishes a financing proposal on a Private Financing Platform, and it must then retain records evidencing both the disclosures and the due diligence for at least six years. [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] The precondition for the due diligence is that the PFP Operator is about to publish a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect; the purpose is to enable the PFP Operator to meet the disclosure requirements imposed on it by Rule 18.5.1. [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] The due diligence must include (and is not limited to) reviewing information provided by the PFP Prospect covering: management details and background (including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers), the PFP Prospect’s background (including financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status if relevant), and the financing proposal itself to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, the content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading. [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] For record-keeping, the PFP Operator must maintain and keep, for a minimum of six years, records of all disclosures made under Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2 and the due diligence undertaken under Rule 18.4.1, as well as documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7]

question: If an Authorised Person runs an MTF for Virtual Assets, what MIR Chapter 5 rules do they have to follow, and what extra point does COBS Rule 17.7.4 make about notifications/information and paragraph 29 on additional Accepted Virtual Assets?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets must follow certain MIR Chapter 5 rules, and COBS Rule 17.7.4 adds that specific notification and information requirements (originally framed for Recognised Investment Exchanges) also apply to MTFs using Virtual Assets as additional requirements. [#TGT:7404ef72-3a2f-4c07-a166-0dfd8a480e8d] [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8] From the MIR side, the required rules are: (a) Rules 5.1–5.3; and (b) Rule 5.4.1, but only when the circumstances match the specific Items listed (including Items 19, 20, 24(a) and (b), 27, 28, 32, 33, 35, 37–41, 43, 45–50, 52–55, and 57–62). [#TGT:7404ef72-3a2f-4c07-a166-0dfd8a480e8d] From the COBS/GUIDANCE side, COBS Rule 17.7.4 states that certain notification requirements under MIR Rules 5.1 and 5.3 and certain information requirements under MIR Rule 5.4.1 that apply to Recognised Investment Exchanges are also applied to MTFs (using Virtual Assets), and it describes these as additional requirements for MTFs using Virtual Assets. [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8] It also indicates that MTFs using Virtual Assets must comply with any other applicable notification requirements, including those referenced in paragraph 29 of the Guidance about using additional Accepted Virtual Assets. [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure under Rule 11.9.1 that includes forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, how should it structure the required assumptions and Production Target content so that the overall disclosure also meets the “fair and balanced” representation expectation for information drawn from a separate report annexed under Rule 11.6.2, without attempting to summarise the entire annexure?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity should present the Rule 11.9.1 forecast-financial-information package (assumptions plus the underlying Production Target) in a way that remains fair and balanced when read alongside the separate report that must be annexed, while avoiding an unnecessary full summary of that annexure. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:b8cb4fdb-f627-43ae-90bf-801a549f8d63] Specifically, the disclosure must include all material economic assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, and it must also include all other material assumptions used. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions commercially sensitive, it must say so and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In addition, the disclosure must include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including all information required by Rule 11.8.3. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] To align this with the Rule 11.6.1 “fair and balanced” expectation, the information included in the disclosure should fairly reflect the information in the separate report prepared under Rule 11.6.2 (annexed to the disclosure), but the FSRA expects only material information needed to understand the estimates of Mineral Resources in that separate report—where that material information is not already in the body of the disclosure—to be included, rather than a comprehensive summary. [#TGT:b8cb4fdb-f627-43ae-90bf-801a549f8d63]

question: If a Passported Fund’s Fund Manager becomes aware that the Prospectus has been amended or replaced, how quickly does it have to tell the Regulator, and what information and documents must be included with that notice?
gold_answer: If the Prospectus relating to a Passported Fund is amended or replaced, the Fund Manager must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable, and it must do so no later than seven days after it becomes aware of the change. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] The notice must be submitted in the prescribed form that the Regulator directs from time to time, so the Fund Manager should follow the Regulator’s current format instructions. [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f] The notice also has minimum content requirements: it must include reasonable detail about the event, explaining what happened and why it is being reported. [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f] Because the event is specifically a Prospectus amendment or replacement, the notice must also be accompanied by a copy of the new Prospectus, not just a description of the change. [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f] This combination of timing (as soon as practicable and within seven days of awareness) and submission package (prescribed form, reasonable detail, and the new Prospectus) is what completes the notification for this Passported Fund event. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f]

question: When seeking to have an investment treated as a Security for an Offer of Digital Securities to the public, what specific submission does the FSRA indicate it will review as key to deciding whether it can use its deeming power, and how does that relate to the Regulator’s ability to deem a non-Security to be a Security by written notice (including any conditions)?
gold_answer: For an Offer of Digital Securities to the public, the FSRA indicates that the information required to be submitted as part of a Securities Note is the key material it will review when considering whether to use its power to deem a Security. [#SRC:b77f9697-b690-4a8b-9139-913a81e95aed] This links directly to the Regulator’s power to deem an investment that is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and the Rules, which must be exercised by written notice and may be made subject to terms and conditions the Regulator considers appropriate. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] In practical compliance terms, the Securities Note functions as the evidentiary package the FSRA expects to assess before it can decide whether to issue such a written notice deeming treatment. [#SRC:b77f9697-b690-4a8b-9139-913a81e95aed] If the Securities Note information is not available or is not completed appropriately, the FSRA states it is most likely not in a position to utilise its deeming power, meaning the written-notice deeming outcome (and any associated terms and conditions) is unlikely to be available. [#SRC:b77f9697-b690-4a8b-9139-913a81e95aed] [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]

question: If you want the Regulator to treat something that is not a Security as a Security, what document information does the FSRA say it needs for an Offer of Digital Securities, and what form can the Regulator use to do the deeming (and with what kind of extra conditions)?
gold_answer: To support deeming treatment in the context of an Offer of Digital Securities to the public, the FSRA says the information that must be submitted as part of a Securities Note is the key information it will review when deciding whether it can use its deeming power. [#SRC:b77f9697-b690-4a8b-9139-913a81e95aed] The Regulator’s deeming power itself includes the ability to treat an investment that is not a Security as a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and the Rules made under them, and it does this by issuing a written notice. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] The same written notice can be made subject to whatever terms and conditions the Regulator considers appropriate, so the deeming outcome is not necessarily unconditional. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] The FSRA also warns that if the Securities Note information is missing or not properly completed, it is most likely that the FSRA will not be able to use its deeming power at all, which would prevent reaching the written-notice stage. [#SRC:b77f9697-b690-4a8b-9139-913a81e95aed] Taken together, this means completing the Securities Note information is a practical prerequisite for the FSRA to be able to consider issuing a written notice that deems the investment to be a Security (potentially with conditions). [#SRC:b77f9697-b690-4a8b-9139-913a81e95aed] [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]

question: When applying the Chapter’s requirement to recognise and measure an Insurer’s assets and liabilities using the basis of accounting referenced in Rule 5.3.2, which accounting standards must the Insurer adopt for the purposes of Rule 5.3.1, and how does that differ for a Takaful Insurer versus any other Insurer?
gold_answer: An Insurer must recognise and measure its assets and liabilities using the basis of accounting specified in Rule 5.3.2, unless the Chapter itself states an alternative approach. [#TGT:35397bd0-0c01-4dec-8eba-1b904df8b4d4] For the purposes of Rule 5.3.1, the Insurer’s adopted basis of accounting depends on whether it is a Takaful Insurer or not. [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0] Specifically, if the Insurer is a Takaful Insurer, it must use the standards issued by the Accounting and Auditing Organisation for Islamic Financial Institutions as its basis of accounting. [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0] If the Insurer is not a Takaful Insurer, it must instead use International Financial Reporting Standards as its basis of accounting. [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0] In practical compliance terms, the Chapter’s recognition and measurement requirement operates by tying the accounting treatment of assets and liabilities to the Rule 5.3.2 basis, while Rule 5.3.1 clarifies which accounting framework the Insurer must adopt depending on its type. [#TGT:35397bd0-0c01-4dec-8eba-1b904df8b4d4] [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0]

question: If an Insurer is measuring and recording its assets and liabilities under the Chapter using the basis of accounting in Rule 5.3.2, what accounting standards does it have to use for Rule 5.3.1 if it is (1) a Takaful Insurer or (2) not a Takaful Insurer?
gold_answer: For an Insurer’s assets and liabilities, the Chapter requires recognition and measurement to follow the basis of accounting set out in Rule 5.3.2, unless the Chapter says otherwise. [#TGT:35397bd0-0c01-4dec-8eba-1b904df8b4d4] Separately, for the purposes of Rule 5.3.1, the Insurer must choose its basis of accounting by reference to what type of Insurer it is. [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0] If the Insurer is a Takaful Insurer, the required basis of accounting is the standards of the Accounting and Auditing Organisation for Islamic Financial Institutions. [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0] If the Insurer is any other type (i.e., not a Takaful Insurer), the required basis of accounting is International Financial Reporting Standards. [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0] Putting these together, the Chapter’s rule on how to recognise and measure assets and liabilities points you to the Rule 5.3.2 basis, and Rule 5.3.1 tells you which accounting framework that basis must be built on depending on whether the Insurer is Takaful or not. [#TGT:35397bd0-0c01-4dec-8eba-1b904df8b4d4] [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0]

question: When an Authorised Person prepares or publishes Investment Research and identifies an actual or potential conflict of interest, what form and level of detail must any conflict disclosure have so that the relevant Client can make an informed decision in the context of the service?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that prepares or publishes Investment Research must have adequate procedures and controls for that activity, and this sits alongside its obligation to take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest and then prevent or manage them. [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759] Where the Authorised Person makes a conflicts disclosure under Rule 3.3.23 in connection with the service in which the conflict arises, that disclosure must be delivered in a durable medium and must contain enough information for the Client to make an informed decision. [#TGT:448d19a7-728b-491f-9eb2-284dc92112e9] In practice, this means the Authorised Person should (i) identify the conflict as part of its conflicts process and address it through prevention or management measures, and (ii) if disclosure is used, ensure the disclosure is appropriately communicated and sufficiently detailed for the particular Client. [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759] The required level of detail is not fixed; it must be assessed by reference to the nature of the Client and must be framed so the Client can decide, on an informed basis, whether to proceed with the relevant service notwithstanding the conflict. [#TGT:448d19a7-728b-491f-9eb2-284dc92112e9]

question: Where an Offer in or from the ADGM is structured so that different tranches rely on different prescribed Exempt Offer circumstances (e.g., one tranche directed at no more than 50 Persons in a 12-month period and another tranche meeting a $100,000 minimum consideration threshold), under what condition can the Offer still be treated as an Exempt Offer notwithstanding that it falls partly within more than one circumstance?
gold_answer: An Offer can continue to be treated as an Exempt Offer even if it is split across multiple prescribed Exempt Offer circumstances, provided that every part of the Offer is covered by at least one of those circumstances. [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0] In applying that principle, the relevant “circumstances” are those prescribed by the Regulator for section 61(3)(a) of the FSMR, including (among others) an Offer in or from the ADGM directed at no more than 50 Persons in any 12-month period (with specified exclusions for certain Professional Clients), and an Offer where the total consideration paid by a Person is at least $100,000 (or equivalent). [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] Practically, this means you may rely on different prescribed circumstances for different portions of the same overall Offer (for example, a limited-number-of-persons limb for one portion and a minimum-consideration limb for another), but you must check that there is no residual portion that falls outside all prescribed circumstances. [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0] If any part of the Offer is not within at least one prescribed circumstance, the condition for maintaining Exempt Offer status is not met. [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0]

question: For Securities admitted to trading on an MTF under an Exempt Offer, what combined arrangements are required to ensure users can access information (including Offer documents and Inside Information) while also meeting the Recognised Investment Exchange obligation to assist users in obtaining access to information made public under disclosure obligations?
gold_answer: When Securities from an Exempt Offer are admitted to trading on an MTF, the operator must put in place information-access arrangements that satisfy both the Exempt Offer-specific requirement to provide market users with relevant inside and offer-related materials and the broader obligation to help users access information made public under disclosure obligations. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215] On the Exempt Offer side, the MTF must have effective systems and controls that allow users of its market to obtain Inside Information, and this expressly includes any Offer documents prepared under MKT Rule 4.3.5 that are relevant to the Securities. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] Separately, the Recognised Investment Exchange framework for admission to trading requires maintaining arrangements to assist users of a market it operates to obtain access to information that is made public under its disclosure obligations. [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215] Read together, the practical expectation is that the MTF’s user-access mechanisms should cover (i) the Inside Information and Exempt Offer documentation relevant to the admitted Securities and (ii) the channels or processes by which users can obtain information that has been made public under the applicable disclosure obligations. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215] This combined approach ensures the information-access control is not limited to offer materials but also supports the broader disclosure-information access objective for market users. [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215]

question: For a Third Party Provider’s Governing Contract, how should the contract’s required exchange-rate disclosures and any agreed approach to changing exchange rates be structured so that the provider can apply exchange-rate changes immediately and without notice only in the permitted cases?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider should draft the Governing Contract so that (i) it includes the required baseline disclosures on exchange rates and (ii) it only permits immediate, no-notice exchange-rate changes in the limited situations allowed. The contract must, where relevant, state the exchange rates to be applied or, if Reference Exchange Rates are used, explain how the relevant date is determined for those Reference Exchange Rates. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] Where relevant and if agreed, it must also address how changes in Reference Exchange Rates will be applied and what information will be provided in relation to those changes. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] Against that disclosure framework, immediate application without notice is only appropriate where the Governing Contract expressly grants that right and the exchange-rate changes are based on Reference Exchange Rate information that has already been provided to the Customer in accordance with Rule 20.2.2, or where the change is more favourable to the Customer. [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] In practice, this means the contract’s “changes” provisions should be aligned with its exchange-rate/Reference Exchange Rate disclosures so the no-notice mechanism is not broader than these two permitted cases. [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]

question: If a Third Party Provider wants to change exchange rates right away without telling the Customer first, what must be written into the Governing Contract about exchange rates and Reference Exchange Rates, and when is the “no notice” change allowed?
gold_answer: The Governing Contract should both explain the exchange-rate basis up front and narrowly define when an exchange-rate change can happen immediately without notice. Where relevant, the contract must include details of the exchange rates to be applied, or—if Reference Exchange Rates will be used—the method for calculating the relevant date used to determine those Reference Exchange Rates. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] Where relevant and if agreed, it must also cover how changes in Reference Exchange Rates will be applied and the information requirements tied to those changes. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] Even with those disclosures, an immediate, no-notice exchange-rate change is only allowed in two cases: (1) the Governing Contract includes an agreed right to do so and the change is based on Reference Exchange Rate information that has already been provided to the Customer in line with Rule 20.2.2; or (2) the change is more favourable to the Customer. [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] So the contract needs both the required exchange-rate/Reference Exchange Rate information and a tightly scoped “immediate change” clause that matches these permitted triggers. [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]

question: If someone is worried that a message they send could count as an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market, what changes if the Regulator has prescribed that kind of message as an Exempt Communication under section 59(c) of the FSMR, given the Regulations’ ban on making an Offer of Securities (and on admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange)?
gold_answer: If the Regulator has prescribed the message as an Exempt Communication, the message is treated as not being an “Offer of Securities,” which means the Regulations’ ban that is triggered by making an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market is not activated by that message. [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f] The Regulations set a general rule that a person must not make an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market and must not have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, unless an exception applies under the Regulations. [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a] Separately, the Regulator has power under section 59(c) of the FSMR to prescribe certain communications as Exempt Communications, and those prescribed communications are not subject to the prohibition in section 58(1) of the FSMR because they fall outside the definition of an “Offer of Securities” in section 59 of the FSMR. [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f] Putting these together, the key compliance consequence is that a prescribed Exempt Communication is not treated as an Offer of Securities, so the specific prohibition in the Regulations that is framed around making an “Offer of Securities” in the Abu Dhabi Global Market does not apply to that communication. [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f] [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a]

question: If you’re working out an Authorised Person’s Leverage Ratio, what do you add up to get the Tier 1 Capital used in the Capital Measure, and what do you divide it by?
gold_answer: To calculate an Authorised Person’s Leverage Ratio, you start by identifying the Capital Measure and the Exposure Measure and then apply the required division. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] The Capital Measure is the Authorised Person’s Tier 1 Capital, and Tier 1 capital must be calculated as the total of Common Equity Tier 1 capital (CET1 Capital) plus Additional Tier 1 capital (AT1 Capital). [#TGT:a2ce8a2e-9188-4d44-8582-42abbadc4f11] Once you have that Tier 1 Capital amount, you use it as the numerator in the Leverage Ratio formula. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] You then divide it by the Exposure Measure, which is defined as the value of the Authorised Person’s Exposures calculated under the specified exposure calculation rules referenced for that purpose. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] In other words, the ratio is Tier 1 Capital (made up of CET1 Capital and AT1 Capital) divided by the Exposure Measure (the value of Exposures). [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] [#TGT:a2ce8a2e-9188-4d44-8582-42abbadc4f11]

question: Where a person has failed to comply with a requirement under Part 17 of FSMR and is certified in default, what must the Court of First Instance be satisfied about before it may treat the Defaulter as if in contempt, and who else may be dealt with in that way if the Defaulter is a Body Corporate?
gold_answer: If a person fails to comply with a requirement under Part 17 of FSMR and is certified in default, the Court of First Instance may only proceed to treat the Defaulter as if in contempt once it is satisfied of the relevant non-compliance condition described for that step. [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf] Specifically, the Court must be satisfied that the Defaulter failed to comply with the requirement without reasonable excuse before it may deal with the Defaulter as if he were in contempt. [#TGT:91865998-c73a-45ec-8cec-23c36750808a] In addition, when the Defaulter is a Body Corporate, the Court’s contempt-style treatment may extend beyond the entity itself to include any Director or other Officer of that Body Corporate. [#TGT:91865998-c73a-45ec-8cec-23c36750808a] Separately from the Court’s contempt-style handling, the same failure to comply with Part 17 requirements may also expose the person to being found to have committed a contravention of FSMR. [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf] These consequences operate on the basis of the failure to comply with the Part 17 requirement and the Court’s satisfaction as to the absence of reasonable excuse for the contempt-style response. [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf] [#TGT:91865998-c73a-45ec-8cec-23c36750808a]

question: If someone doesn’t follow a requirement under Part 17 of FSMR and gets certified in default, what does the Court of First Instance need to believe before treating them like they’re in contempt, and if the Defaulter is a Body Corporate, who else can the Court treat that way?
gold_answer: When a person does not comply with a requirement under Part 17 of FSMR, that person can be certified in default and then may face Court of First Instance action that treats them as if they were in contempt of court. [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf] For the Court to take that contempt-style step, it is not enough that there was non-compliance; the Court must be satisfied that the Defaulter failed to comply without reasonable excuse. [#TGT:91865998-c73a-45ec-8cec-23c36750808a] If the Defaulter is a Body Corporate, the Court’s ability to deal with parties as if in contempt can also reach individuals connected to the company—namely any Director or other Officer—rather than being limited to the corporate entity alone. [#TGT:91865998-c73a-45ec-8cec-23c36750808a] In parallel with the Court’s contempt-style handling, the same failure to comply with a Part 17 requirement may also result in the person being found to have committed a contravention of FSMR. [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf] Taken together, the process links certification in default for Part 17 non-compliance with a Court assessment focused on whether there was a reasonable excuse, and it clarifies who may be dealt with when the Defaulter is a Body Corporate. [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf] [#TGT:91865998-c73a-45ec-8cec-23c36750808a]

question: If a Host Regulator asks the Regulator to do an on-site inspection about a Passported Fund, what is the normal response, and when is the Regulator allowed to say no because there is already enforcement action or a court case about the same conduct and the same Persons?
gold_answer: Normally, when the Regulator gets a request from a Host Regulator for an on-site inspection that relates to a Passported Fund, the Regulator is expected to allow the inspection and to go along during the on-site inspection. [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6] Even so, the Regulator is permitted to refuse to act on a Host Regulator’s request for cooperation for an inspection if the situation matches one of the listed refusal grounds tied to the same conduct and the same Persons. [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c] To apply this, the Regulator should first check that the request is indeed for an on-site inspection and that it is in relation to a Passported Fund, because that is the scenario where permitting and accompanying the inspection is the baseline expectation. [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6] The Regulator may then refuse if it has already begun or finished enforcement action about the same conduct and the same Persons, or if judicial proceedings have already begun or finished about the same conduct and the same Persons. [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c] If those conditions are not present, the Regulator should proceed by permitting and accompanying the inspection. [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6]

question: When an Applicant is seeking admission of Shares to the Official List, how should the Applicant frame its demonstration to the Regulator that it (and any Subsidiaries) has sufficient working capital for its present requirements, including the relevant time horizon the Regulator uses for assessing those present requirements and what must be addressed if working capital is not sufficient?
gold_answer: An Applicant seeking admission of Shares to the Official List must be prepared to satisfy the Regulator that it and any Subsidiaries have enough working capital available for its present requirements, and the Regulator’s benchmark for what counts as “present requirements” is that they are sufficient to support projected normal operations for 12 months starting from the date of admission to the Official List. [#TGT:c5ff4069-f284-4bb2-a504-11cf3694aa2e] [#SRC:b6eba295-6fe5-41d7-9392-46287b03796c] In practice, this means the Applicant’s working-capital case should be framed around a 12-month forward-looking period measured from admission, rather than an undefined or shorter interval. [#SRC:b6eba295-6fe5-41d7-9392-46287b03796c] The Applicant must cover both the Applicant itself and any Subsidiaries in that sufficiency assessment. [#TGT:c5ff4069-f284-4bb2-a504-11cf3694aa2e] If the Applicant cannot demonstrate sufficient working capital for those present requirements, it must instead explain to the Regulator how it proposes to provide the additional working capital needed, which necessarily ties back to meeting the 12-month projected normal operations horizon from admission. [#TGT:c5ff4069-f284-4bb2-a504-11cf3694aa2e] [#SRC:b6eba295-6fe5-41d7-9392-46287b03796c]

question: If a company applies to list Shares, what does it need to show the Regulator about working capital for itself and any Subsidiaries, and over what time period does the Regulator treat “present requirements” as covering from the admission date?
gold_answer: For an Applicant seeking admission of Shares to the Official List, the core requirement is to satisfy the Regulator that the Applicant and any Subsidiaries have sufficient working capital available for the Applicant’s present requirements. [#TGT:c5ff4069-f284-4bb2-a504-11cf3694aa2e] The Regulator’s view of what “present requirements” means is not open-ended: it is treated as being enough to support projected normal operations for a 12-month period starting on the date of admission to the Official List. [#SRC:b6eba295-6fe5-41d7-9392-46287b03796c] Put together, the Applicant’s working-capital showing should be aligned to that 12-month-from-admission horizon and should cover both the Applicant and any Subsidiaries. [#TGT:c5ff4069-f284-4bb2-a504-11cf3694aa2e] [#SRC:b6eba295-6fe5-41d7-9392-46287b03796c] If the Applicant cannot show that working capital is sufficient for those present requirements, it must instead tell the Regulator how it proposes to provide the additional working capital needed, which is the alternative path to addressing the same 12-month operational sufficiency expectation. [#TGT:c5ff4069-f284-4bb2-a504-11cf3694aa2e] [#SRC:b6eba295-6fe5-41d7-9392-46287b03796c]

question: If a Mining Production Reporting Entity is doing its quarterly report and needs to cover the Summary of Reserves and Resources at least once every 12 months (unless it’s in the annual report), what must it say about the timing of the last and next Summary disclosure, and how recent must the date be for the MKT Form 11-1 table inside that Summary?
gold_answer: In the quarterly report, the Mining Production Reporting Entity must manage the Summary of Reserves and Resources on a 12‑month cycle: it must provide that Summary at least once every 12 months unless the Summary is included in the Mining Reporting Entity’s annual report instead. [#SRC:a24b4f51-4c48-4846-bd22-d5f98dbad55b] To make that cycle transparent, the quarterly report must also indicate when the previous disclosure of the required Summary was made and when the next disclosure will be made. [#SRC:a24b4f51-4c48-4846-bd22-d5f98dbad55b] When the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed (whether through the quarterly reporting stream or via the annual report), the Mining Reporting Entity must include a table in the form of MKT Form 11-1 within that Summary. [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd] The “as of” date used for that MKT Form 11-1 table must be no earlier than one month before the Summary is disclosed, so the table’s date must be within the month leading up to the disclosure. [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd]

question: When designing the strategy’s system for controlling Liquidity Risk that enables the Authorised Person to implement the requirements in Rule 9.2.6, what specific capabilities and governance/approval features must that system include for the Authorised Person’s Governing Body and senior management, including in relation to limits set under Rule 9.2.7 and operating procedures?
gold_answer: The system for controlling Liquidity Risk that is included in the strategy must be built so it both supports implementation of the requirements in Rule 9.2.6 and contains the specific governance and control features described for the system referenced in Rule 9.2.1(5). [#TGT:5c690bca-7ecd-4950-8e21-6c4cb9357647] In particular, the Authorised Person must ensure the system enables the Authorised Person’s Governing Body and senior management to review whether the Authorised Person is complying with limits that are set in accordance with Rule 9.2.7 and with the relevant operating procedures. [#SRC:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988] The Authorised Person must also ensure the system has appropriate approval processes, limits, and other mechanisms that are designed to provide reasonable assurance that the Authorised Person’s Liquidity Risk management processes are followed in practice. [#SRC:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988] Taken together, this means the strategy-level system is not merely descriptive: it must be capable of enabling implementation of Rule 9.2.6 while also embedding review capability for the Governing Body and senior management and incorporating approvals and control mechanisms tied to the Rule 9.2.7 limit-setting and operating procedures. [#TGT:5c690bca-7ecd-4950-8e21-6c4cb9357647] [#SRC:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988]

question: If the strategy has to include a system for controlling Liquidity Risk so the Authorised Person can carry out Rule 9.2.6, what does that system need to let the Governing Body and senior management do, and what kinds of approval/limit controls must it have (including around limits set under Rule 9.2.7 and operating procedures)?
gold_answer: The strategy must contain a Liquidity Risk control system that enables the Authorised Person to implement the requirements in Rule 9.2.6, and the Authorised Person must ensure that system has the specific review and control features described for the relevant system. [#TGT:5c690bca-7ecd-4950-8e21-6c4cb9357647] The system must allow the Authorised Person’s Governing Body and senior management to review compliance with limits that are set in accordance with Rule 9.2.7 and to review compliance with operating procedures. [#SRC:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988] It must also include appropriate approval processes, limits, and other mechanisms that are designed to give reasonable assurance that the Authorised Person’s Liquidity Risk management processes are actually being followed. [#SRC:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988] In practice, this links the strategy requirement (a system that enables implementation of Rule 9.2.6) with concrete governance expectations: the system must support oversight by the Governing Body and senior management and must embed approvals and control mechanisms aligned to the Rule 9.2.7 limit framework and operating procedures. [#TGT:5c690bca-7ecd-4950-8e21-6c4cb9357647] [#SRC:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988]

question: If an Authorised Person has foreign currency and gold risk under an Islamic Contract, can it ever skip calculating the Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement? If yes, what numbers does it have to check and how are they measured?
gold_answer: Yes. Even where an Authorised Person is exposed to the risk of foreign currencies and gold under any Islamic Contract (a situation that would otherwise require it to calculate its Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement under PRU Rule 5.6.2), it can skip that calculation if it satisfies both exemption tests. [#SRC:6a51fe1f-d0d3-42f6-b369-4e9345775696] The tests are framed by reference to Capital Resources (as defined in Chapter 3) and require specific position measures. [#TGT:79d3cd2f-93a5-4f25-af68-c67e7fd4cb97] The Authorised Person must first determine its “Foreign Currency business,” defined as the greater of the sum of its gross long positions and the sum of its gross short positions in all Foreign Currencies, and ensure that this amount is no more than 100% of its Capital Resources. [#TGT:79d3cd2f-93a5-4f25-af68-c67e7fd4cb97] It must also check that its overall net open position (as defined in Rule A6.4.4) is no more than 2% of its Capital Resources. [#TGT:79d3cd2f-93a5-4f25-af68-c67e7fd4cb97] If it fails either check, it cannot rely on the exemption and must calculate the Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement in accordance with PRU Rule 5.6.2 for the exposure under the Islamic Contract. [#SRC:6a51fe1f-d0d3-42f6-b369-4e9345775696]

question: When an Authorised Person chooses to reduce the value of its Exposures using Collateral, how must it determine the Collateral amount to recognise if the Collateral’s value under a stress scenario is below the value otherwise applied under Rule 4.15.12 for purposes of this Section?
gold_answer: When an Authorised Person elects to reduce the value of its Exposures by recognising Collateral for purposes of this Section, it must ensure the recognised Collateral amount reflects the stress-scenario constraint described for Collateral valuation. [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3] Specifically, if the Collateral’s value under the stress scenario is lower than the value that would otherwise be applied under Rule 4.15.12, the Authorised Person must use the lower stress-scenario value when determining the Exposure value for this Section. [#SRC:50586097-115d-49d1-9dd6-462b2d08e3f3] This linkage matters because the TARGET provision permits discretionary exposure reduction by “the amount of Collateral held against its Exposures” (subject to the Collateral being of a listed type under the FCSA and FCCA approaches and meeting Section 4.13 requirements), but the SOURCE provision constrains the valuation input used in the Exposure value calculation when stress-scenario Collateral values are lower. [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3] Accordingly, even where Collateral is otherwise eligible to be recognised as a credit risk mitigation under this Section, the amount that effectively reduces the Exposure value must be based on the lower of the stress-scenario Collateral value and the value applied under Rule 4.15.12. [#SRC:50586097-115d-49d1-9dd6-462b2d08e3f3]

question: If an Authorised Person decides to lower its Exposures using Collateral, what value should it use for the Collateral when the stress-scenario value is lower than the value it would otherwise use under Rule 4.15.12?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person chooses to reduce the value of its Exposures by taking credit for Collateral under this Section, it can do so as a form of credit risk mitigation (alongside other options like specific provisions, netting, eligible guarantees, credit derivatives, or securitisation effects). [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3] However, when it is using Collateral to determine the Exposure value for this Section, it must apply the stress-scenario valuation rule for Collateral. [#SRC:50586097-115d-49d1-9dd6-462b2d08e3f3] That means: if the Collateral’s value under the stress scenario is lower than the value that would be applied under Rule 4.15.12, the lower stress-scenario value is the one that should be used in determining the Exposure value. [#SRC:50586097-115d-49d1-9dd6-462b2d08e3f3] This connects directly to the Collateral-based reduction described in the Section because the reduction is by “the amount of Collateral held against its Exposures,” but the amount that can be reflected in the Exposure value calculation is constrained by the requirement to use the lower stress-scenario value when it is below the Rule 4.15.12 value. [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3]

question: How must an Authorised Person align its systems-and-controls responsibilities for operating and monitoring a Spot Commodity Auction Platform with the participant safeguards that require transparent rules, transaction recording, information availability, and measures against Market Abuse or Financial Crime?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must combine operational capability and risk/monitoring controls with participant-facing safeguards so that the Spot Commodity Auction Platform is both technically well-run and conducted in an orderly manner that protects participants. [#SRC:4056cfbb-4512-4279-a074-7577632f9653] [#TGT:1970af23-583d-4eee-8691-1db4637d6329] In practice, this means the Authorised Person’s arrangements must demonstrate it can operate the platform, manage risks, and monitor participant bids and transactions, while also ensuring the business conducted on the platform is orderly and protective through specified safeguards. [#SRC:4056cfbb-4512-4279-a074-7577632f9653] [#TGT:1970af23-583d-4eee-8691-1db4637d6329] The required alignment includes: (i) operating and being responsible for the full technical operation (including contingency arrangements for disruption) in a way that supports fair and orderly auctions under transparent rules and procedures; (ii) monitoring bids and transactions alongside arrangements for recording executed transactions; (iii) managing platform risks while adopting measures that reduce use of the facilities for purposes connected with Market Abuse or Financial Crime and facilitate detection/monitoring of their influence; and (iv) ensuring arrangements exist for relevant information to be made available to participants, consistent with the Authorised Person’s overall responsibility for platform operation. [#SRC:4056cfbb-4512-4279-a074-7577632f9653] [#TGT:1970af23-583d-4eee-8691-1db4637d6329]

question: When an Authorised Person is responsible for the full technical operation of a Spot Commodity Auction Platform (including contingency arrangements for disruption), what participant-protection outcomes must its rules, procedures, and related arrangements deliver regarding auctions, execution criteria, settlement/title transfer, information availability, transaction recording, and fee transparency?
gold_answer: Because the Authorised Person must perform the full technical operation of the Spot Commodity Auction Platform and maintain contingency arrangements for disruption, it must ensure that the platform’s business is conducted in an orderly manner that affords proper protection to participants through specified safeguards. [#SRC:4056cfbb-4512-4279-a074-7577632f9653] [#TGT:1970af23-583d-4eee-8691-1db4637d6329] The technical-operation responsibility (including disruption contingencies) must be implemented so that participant-facing rules and arrangements achieve concrete outcomes, not merely internal resilience. [#SRC:4056cfbb-4512-4279-a074-7577632f9653] [#TGT:1970af23-583d-4eee-8691-1db4637d6329] Specifically, the Authorised Person must ensure transparent rules and procedures are in place to provide for fair and orderly auctions, set objective criteria for efficient execution of transactions, and address settlement of the Accepted Spot Commodity or transfer of the Spot Commodity Title. [#TGT:1970af23-583d-4eee-8691-1db4637d6329] It must also have arrangements for relevant information to be made available to participants and for recording transactions executed by participants, which complements its duty to monitor bids and transactions on the platform. [#TGT:1970af23-583d-4eee-8691-1db4637d6329] [#SRC:4056cfbb-4512-4279-a074-7577632f9653] In addition, it must adopt measures to reduce use of the platform’s facilities for purposes connected with Market Abuse or Financial Crime and facilitate detection/monitoring, and it must provide details of fees, costs, and other charges and the basis for imposing them. [#TGT:1970af23-583d-4eee-8691-1db4637d6329]

question: If an Authorised Person submits a Regulatory Filing after it becomes due, what are the compliance consequences, including the specific late payment fee amount and any additional regulatory response beyond the fee?
gold_answer: Submitting a Regulatory Filing after the date it is due results in a breach by the Authorised Person, and it also triggers a mandatory late payment fee payable to the Regulator. [#SRC:2932ae57-5946-46b4-8ac2-e41d4d145bcc] Specifically, when the filing is submitted after the due date, the Authorised Person must pay the Regulator $500 as a late payment fee relating to that Regulatory Filing. [#TGT:44e2c477-1fbd-46c4-9391-046045a5b105] In addition to that fee (which is imposed under Rule 1.2.7), the Regulator is not limited to charging the fee and may take further action in response to the late submission. [#SRC:2932ae57-5946-46b4-8ac2-e41d4d145bcc] The key precondition for both outcomes is the same timing condition: the Regulatory Filing is submitted after the due date (i.e., after it becomes due). [#SRC:2932ae57-5946-46b4-8ac2-e41d4d145bcc] [#TGT:44e2c477-1fbd-46c4-9391-046045a5b105]

question: If an Authorised Person is Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA, and it also has a Large Exposure in its Non Trading Book (or Trading Book), what percentage limits apply, and what do those limits get measured against (Tier 1 vs Capital Resources) including when the PSIA limit can be 25% or 40%?
gold_answer: Two different limits can apply, and they use different measurement bases. For Large Exposures, an Authorised Person must not incur a Large Exposure in its Non Trading Book (and, under the stated Trading Book condition) that exceeds 25% of its Tier 1 once the effect of any eligible CRM has been included. [#SRC:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] For exposures arising when the Authorised Person is Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA, the Authorised Person must keep its Exposure to a Counterparty (including Connected Counterparty and closely related/connected groupings) within set percentages of its Capital Resources, and the percentage depends on how the exposure is financed. [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] Specifically: - Large Exposures are capped at 25% of Tier 1, calculated after eligible CRM is taken into account. [#SRC:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] - For Unrestricted PSIA exposures, the cap is 25% of Capital Resources if the exposure is financed by the Authorised Person’s Capital Resources or Unrestricted PSIAs. [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] - The Unrestricted PSIA cap becomes 40% of Capital Resources if the exposure is financed by a combined pool (an aggregate) of the Authorised Person’s own Capital Resources and Unrestricted PSIAs. [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] So, you must check both: the Tier 1-based 25% Large Exposures ceiling (after eligible CRM) and the Capital Resources-based PSIA exposure ceiling (25% or 40% depending on financing). [#SRC:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f]

question: Where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, how may the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider contractually modify the rule on withdrawal of consent for an individual Payment Transaction, and how does that modification interact with the point in time tied to revocation under Rule 19.14.3?
gold_answer: If the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider can, by written agreement, disapply the specified withdrawal-of-consent provisions (Rule 19.10.1 (3) and (4)). [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] In that case, the default position described for consent withdrawal—namely that the Payer may withdraw consent to an individual Payment Transaction up to the point when the Payment Order is no longer capable of being revoked under Rule 19.14.3—would not apply to the extent it depends on those disapplied provisions. [#TGT:31fb705e-a65c-4024-99d4-fadfe13f8f32] The timing reference in the consent-withdrawal rule is explicitly anchored to the revocation boundary under Rule 19.14.3, so any contractual approach to withdrawal of consent should be assessed against that same “no longer revocable” point. [#TGT:31fb705e-a65c-4024-99d4-fadfe13f8f32] Separately, the same written agreement mechanism also permits the parties to disapply Rule 19.14.3 itself (revocation of a Payment Order), which would affect the practical meaning of the revocation-based timing boundary used in the consent-withdrawal rule. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]

question: If the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, can the parties agree in writing that the usual withdrawal-of-consent rule does not apply, and what is the time limit for withdrawing consent in the rule that links it to revocation under Rule 19.14.3?
gold_answer: Yes. When the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider may agree in writing that certain listed rules do not apply, including the withdrawal-of-consent provisions in Rule 19.10.1 (3) and (4). [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] The withdrawal-of-consent rule for an individual Payment Transaction states that the Payer can withdraw consent at any time up to the point when the Payment Order can no longer be revoked under Rule 19.14.3. [#TGT:31fb705e-a65c-4024-99d4-fadfe13f8f32] Because that timing limit is defined by the revocation cut-off under Rule 19.14.3, any decision to disapply the withdrawal-of-consent provisions should be considered alongside how the revocation boundary operates in practice. [#TGT:31fb705e-a65c-4024-99d4-fadfe13f8f32] In addition, the same written agreement option also allows the parties to disapply Rule 19.14.3 itself, which would change the reference point used to determine when consent can no longer be withdrawn under the linked timing concept. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]

question: Where Confidential Information is sought for use as evidence in civil litigation by a party other than a governmental or regulatory authority, what consents are required before the Regulator may permit disclosure, and how do those consents align with the consent requirements imposed on a primary recipient (and downstream recipients) before any disclosure can occur?
gold_answer: In the civil-litigation scenario described—where Confidential Information is requested by a party that is not a governmental or regulatory authority—the Regulator should only permit disclosure if the required prior consents are obtained, and those consents mirror the consent gate that applies to a primary recipient and anyone receiving the information from them. [#SRC:d5f06cc2-641f-47b8-979d-9a02192e7343] Specifically, the Regulator requires prior consent from (a) the person from whom the Confidential Information was obtained and (b) where different, the person to whom the duty of confidentiality is owed. [#SRC:d5f06cc2-641f-47b8-979d-9a02192e7343] In parallel, the disclosure prohibition applicable to a primary recipient (and any person who obtains the information directly or indirectly from that primary recipient) is lifted only with prior consent from (a) the person from whom the primary recipient obtained the information and (b) if different, the person to whom the information relates. [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866] Practically, this means the compliance check is two-pronged in both passages: identify the original source of the information and identify the separate person who is protected by the confidentiality obligation/relationship to the information, and secure both consents before any disclosure is allowed. [#SRC:d5f06cc2-641f-47b8-979d-9a02192e7343] [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866]

question: If someone wants Confidential Information for a civil court case (not a government or regulator request), who has to say “yes” before it can be shared, and does the same “two-consent” idea apply when the information is held by a primary recipient or someone who got it from them?
gold_answer: For a request connected to civil litigation made by a party that is not a governmental or regulatory authority, the Regulator will only allow the Confidential Information to be used or shared if it first gets the required consents. [#SRC:d5f06cc2-641f-47b8-979d-9a02192e7343] Those consents must come from two places: (a) the person from whom the Confidential Information was obtained and (b) if that is a different person, the person to whom the duty of confidentiality is owed. [#SRC:d5f06cc2-641f-47b8-979d-9a02192e7343] The same two-step consent structure also governs disclosure by a primary recipient and by anyone who receives the information from a primary recipient (whether directly or indirectly): they must not disclose unless they have prior consent from (a) the person from whom the primary recipient obtained the information and (b) if different, the person to whom the information relates. [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866] So, in both settings, you must identify the original provider of the information and also identify the separate person protected by the confidentiality duty/relationship to the information, and obtain both consents before disclosure. [#SRC:d5f06cc2-641f-47b8-979d-9a02192e7343] [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation and relies on the carve-out from Rule 11.2.1(1), what specific disclosures must it include in its Summary of Reserves and Resources if it has previously disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates under Rule 11.7.3 that have not later been disclosed as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard, including the additional disclosures triggered after three years from first disclosure under Rule 11.7.4?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity that discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation may avoid complying with Rule 11.2.1(1) only if it instead complies with Rules 11.7.2, 11.7.3, 11.7.4, and 11.7.6. [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] Where the entity has previously disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates in compliance with Rule 11.7.3 and those estimates have not subsequently been disclosed as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard, it must include specified information in its Summary of Reserves and Resources. [#TGT:18d4dbe3-8555-4fe0-94e6-91c8b92b5907] Specifically, it must disclose the steps taken to evaluate the previously disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates, the status of any further evaluation and/or exploration work needed to verify and disclose them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under the Mining Reporting Standard, and the status of the proposed source of funding for that evaluation and/or exploration work (including the funding status referenced to Rule 11.7.6(1)(b)). [#TGT:18d4dbe3-8555-4fe0-94e6-91c8b92b5907] In addition, if more than three years have passed since the first disclosure of the Non-Equivalent Estimates under Rule 11.7.4 and they still have not been verified and disclosed as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard, the Summary must also explain why verification and disclosure have not occurred and state the entity’s intention, proposed timetable, and proposed source of funding for verifying and disclosing them. [#TGT:18d4dbe3-8555-4fe0-94e6-91c8b92b5907]

question: Under what conditions may a letter of credit be treated as a qualifying letter of credit and included as eligible capital, and what specific characteristics must the instrument and issuing bank have to satisfy the referenced Rule 3.1.4(2) requirements?
gold_answer: A letter of credit may be treated as a qualifying letter of credit only if two conditions are met: it must satisfy the detailed requirements in Rule 3.1.4(2), and the Regulator must allow it to be included as eligible capital under Rule 2(2)(a). [#SRC:09531ba6-44f7-4113-bdf4-943582ecc05c] To meet Rule 3.1.4(2), the letter of credit must be unconditional and irrevocable, must not include any subordination clause, and must be legally enforceable in ADGM or another jurisdiction the Regulator approves for this purpose. [#TGT:27f296e6-bc33-466d-b0c3-d6ff38a741d3] It also must not be cancellable or amendable without the consent of all parties, must be for a fixed amount, and must be renewable annually. [#TGT:27f296e6-bc33-466d-b0c3-d6ff38a741d3] In addition, the terms of the agreement between the bank and the Captive Insurer must not require the Captive Insurer to provide collateral to the bank for issuing the letter of credit. [#TGT:27f296e6-bc33-466d-b0c3-d6ff38a741d3] Finally, the bank providing the letter of credit must be rated at least BBB+ by Standard & Poor’s (or equivalent by another Approved Rating Agency) at issuance and thereafter, and must be regulated in ADGM or another jurisdiction approved by the Regulator for this purpose. [#TGT:27f296e6-bc33-466d-b0c3-d6ff38a741d3]

question: When can a letter of credit count as eligible capital as a “qualifying letter of credit”? List what the Regulator must do and the key features the letter of credit and the bank must have.
gold_answer: A letter of credit can count as a qualifying letter of credit for eligible capital only when it both meets the Rule 3.1.4(2) conditions and the Regulator allows it to be included as eligible capital under Rule 2(2)(a). [#SRC:09531ba6-44f7-4113-bdf4-943582ecc05c] The Rule 3.1.4(2) conditions focus on the letter’s terms and the standing of the issuing bank. [#TGT:27f296e6-bc33-466d-b0c3-d6ff38a741d3] The letter of credit must be unconditional and irrevocable, must not contain a subordination clause, and must be legally enforceable in ADGM or another jurisdiction the Regulator approves for this purpose. [#TGT:27f296e6-bc33-466d-b0c3-d6ff38a741d3] It must also be fixed in amount, renewable each year, and not capable of being cancelled or amended unless all parties consent. [#TGT:27f296e6-bc33-466d-b0c3-d6ff38a741d3] The agreement between the bank and the Captive Insurer must not require the Captive Insurer to post collateral to the bank for issuing the letter of credit. [#TGT:27f296e6-bc33-466d-b0c3-d6ff38a741d3] The bank must be rated at least BBB+ (or equivalent) at issue and afterwards, and be regulated in ADGM or another jurisdiction approved by the Regulator for this purpose. [#TGT:27f296e6-bc33-466d-b0c3-d6ff38a741d3]

question: When an Authorised Person conducts a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, how must references to “Client Investments” in GEN be interpreted, and what is the practical compliance effect of that interpretation on the scope of FSRA Rulebook provisions (including any specific COBS chapters identified) that use the term “Client Investments”?
gold_answer: For an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, any reference to “Client Investments” in GEN must be treated as including “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets”, as applicable. [#TGT:8a2c66a4-0927-4dc2-ab8b-2b5985961c3d] The practical compliance effect is that rules across the FSRA Rulebooks that rely on the term “Client Investments” are expanded so they also apply to Virtual Assets, because COBS Rule 17.1.3 operates to read “Client Investments” in GEN as including Virtual Assets in this context. [#SRC:e2ff5c54-c76a-4e57-b74c-a8458fc98a54] As a result, the regulated firm should treat Virtual Assets as within the scope of the various rules that use “Client Investments” throughout the FSRA Rulebooks, rather than limiting those rules to non-virtual asset holdings. [#SRC:e2ff5c54-c76a-4e57-b74c-a8458fc98a54] This expansion is highlighted as capturing Virtual Assets in particular within the rules contained in Chapters 3 and 6 of COBS, meaning those COBS chapter requirements that are triggered by “Client Investments” should be applied on the basis that Virtual Assets are included. [#SRC:e2ff5c54-c76a-4e57-b74c-a8458fc98a54] In short, the GEN term-mapping for “Client Investments” to Virtual Assets is mandatory for the Authorised Person’s virtual-asset regulated activity, and it drives broader rule applicability across the FSRA Rulebooks, including the specified COBS chapters. [#TGT:8a2c66a4-0927-4dc2-ab8b-2b5985961c3d] [#SRC:e2ff5c54-c76a-4e57-b74c-a8458fc98a54]

question: If an Authorised Person is doing a Regulated Activity involving Virtual Assets, what should they treat “Client Investments” in GEN as meaning, and how does that change which FSRA Rulebook rules (including any named COBS chapters) apply to Virtual Assets?
gold_answer: In this situation, “Client Investments” in GEN must be read to include “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets”, depending on what fits the reference. [#TGT:8a2c66a4-0927-4dc2-ab8b-2b5985961c3d] That interpretation matters because COBS Rule 17.1.3 is described as operating so that “Client Investments” in GEN (and also “Financial Instruments” in CMC) are read to include Virtual Assets, which expands the reach of rules that use those terms across the FSRA Rulebooks. [#SRC:e2ff5c54-c76a-4e57-b74c-a8458fc98a54] Practically, the Authorised Person should not treat Virtual Assets as outside the scope of requirements that are triggered by “Client Investments”; instead, those requirements are captured for Virtual Assets as well. [#SRC:e2ff5c54-c76a-4e57-b74c-a8458fc98a54] The text specifically points out that this expansion includes, in particular, the rules in Chapters 3 and 6 of COBS, so any obligations in those chapters that depend on the “Client Investments” concept should be applied on the basis that Virtual Assets are included. [#SRC:e2ff5c54-c76a-4e57-b74c-a8458fc98a54] This is the direct compliance consequence of the GEN reading rule for “Client Investments” when the regulated activity relates to Virtual Assets. [#TGT:8a2c66a4-0927-4dc2-ab8b-2b5985961c3d]

question: If a Third Party Provider wants to change what the Governing Contract says about charges (like the details of all charges payable by the Customer), how early does it have to send the proposed change to the Customer before it starts?
gold_answer: The Governing Contract must include specific information about charges, including details of all charges payable by the Customer to the Third Party Provider and, where applicable, a breakdown of those charges. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] If the Third Party Provider proposes to change that required charges information, the change is treated as a proposed change to information that must be provided to the Customer. [#SRC:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f] In that situation, the Third Party Provider must provide the proposed change to the Customer no later than two months before the date the change is intended to take effect. [#SRC:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f] The same two-month advance timing applies whether the proposed update is framed as a change to the existing terms of the Governing Contract or as a change to the specified contractual information that the contract must contain. [#SRC:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f] So, when updating the contract’s charges section (for example, revising the list of charges or the breakdown), the practical requirement is to send the Customer the proposed revised charges information at least two months before the new charges terms are meant to begin. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] [#SRC:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f]

question: When an Authorised Person is applying the arrears-day thresholds for classifying Exposures (special mention, substandard, doubtful, loss), how must the Authorised Person ensure that any Evergreening exercise involving refinancing of past due credits does not inappropriately improve the classification category, including for impaired credits?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person should classify Exposures using the stated arrears-day bands for the four categories and, when considering Evergreening treatment, must ensure refinancing does not lead to an upgrade in classification. [#SRC:2dd83781-93a2-4d56-a3fc-bf4665f983d5] Specifically, the classification framework contemplates that loans contractually in arrears for at least 30, 60, 90–120, and 120–180 days are treated as special mention, substandard, doubtful, and loss, respectively, and the Authorised Person is expected to apply those thresholds when determining the category. [#SRC:2dd83781-93a2-4d56-a3fc-bf4665f983d5] In parallel, where the Authorised Person undertakes an Evergreening exercise that involves refinancing past due credits, that refinancing must not cause the credits to be placed into a higher (i.e., better) classification category than would otherwise apply under the arrears-based approach. [#TGT:fc4bcf60-fc4a-4cd8-9848-a2bbcaaef228] This constraint is particularly strict for impaired credits: they cannot be refinanced for the purpose of reclassifying them as standard or special mention credits. [#TGT:fc4bcf60-fc4a-4cd8-9848-a2bbcaaef228] Accordingly, the Authorised Person should apply the arrears-day classification and then check that any refinancing done as Evergreening does not override that outcome by producing an upward reclassification, including any attempt to move impaired credits into standard or special mention. [#SRC:2dd83781-93a2-4d56-a3fc-bf4665f983d5] [#TGT:fc4bcf60-fc4a-4cd8-9848-a2bbcaaef228]

question: If a loan is past due and you are classifying it based on how many days it is in arrears (30, 60, 90–120, 120–180), what should you do if the credit is refinanced as part of an Evergreening exercise—can that refinancing move it into a better category, especially if it is impaired?
gold_answer: You should first classify the Exposure using the arrears-day thresholds and then ensure that any Evergreening refinancing does not improve that classification. [#SRC:2dd83781-93a2-4d56-a3fc-bf4665f983d5] The arrears-based approach indicates that loans contractually in arrears for at least 30 days fall into special mention, at least 60 days into substandard, 90–120 days into doubtful, and 120–180 days into loss, and Authorised Persons are expected to use these bands when classifying Exposures. [#SRC:2dd83781-93a2-4d56-a3fc-bf4665f983d5] If the past due credit is refinanced as part of an Evergreening exercise, that refinancing is not allowed to result in the credit being classified in a higher (better) category than it would otherwise be in. [#TGT:fc4bcf60-fc4a-4cd8-9848-a2bbcaaef228] There is also a clear prohibition for impaired credits: they cannot be refinanced with the goal of reclassifying them as standard or special mention credits. [#TGT:fc4bcf60-fc4a-4cd8-9848-a2bbcaaef228] In practice, this means refinancing cannot be used to “reset” the arrears-driven classification outcome, and any attempt to use Evergreening to upgrade an impaired credit into standard or special mention would be inconsistent with the stated restriction. [#SRC:2dd83781-93a2-4d56-a3fc-bf4665f983d5] [#TGT:fc4bcf60-fc4a-4cd8-9848-a2bbcaaef228]

question: When the Regulator is considering whether to give a direction to a Recognised Body in matters relating to its Controllers to advance one or more operational objectives, what information and factors must the Regulator take into account in deciding whether it is appropriate to exercise its direction-giving powers under Rule 6.6.1 or Rule 6.7.2?
gold_answer: Where the Regulator is contemplating giving a direction to a Recognised Body on matters relating to its Controllers, it may do so if it considers the direction desirable to advance one or more of its operational objectives. [#TGT:1c3cd986-8007-416b-9fb1-e4600d1b1c81] In deciding whether it would be appropriate to exercise its powers to issue directions under Rule 6.6.1 or Rule 6.7.2 in that context, the Regulator must assess all relevant information and factors, rather than relying on a single consideration. [#SRC:c6a75fa0-e9f4-459e-972a-a06f6236f8c6] Specifically, its assessment includes considering the Rules contained in MIR, the results of its routine supervision of the Recognised Body concerned, and how far any failure or likely failure to satisfy one or more Recognition Requirements may affect the Regulator’s objectives. [#SRC:c6a75fa0-e9f4-459e-972a-a06f6236f8c6] This means the operational-objectives rationale for a Controllers-related direction should be evaluated alongside the MIR rule framework and supervisory findings, and with attention to the potential impact of (actual or likely) non-compliance with Recognition Requirements on the Regulator’s objectives. [#TGT:1c3cd986-8007-416b-9fb1-e4600d1b1c81] [#SRC:c6a75fa0-e9f4-459e-972a-a06f6236f8c6]

question: If the Regulator wants to direct a Recognised Body about its Controllers because it thinks the direction would help meet one or more operational objectives, what should it look at before deciding it is appropriate to use its direction powers under Rule 6.6.1 or Rule 6.7.2?
gold_answer: The Regulator can give a direction to a Recognised Body on matters relating to its Controllers when it considers doing so is desirable to advance one or more of its operational objectives. [#TGT:1c3cd986-8007-416b-9fb1-e4600d1b1c81] Before deciding it is appropriate to use its powers to issue directions under Rule 6.6.1 or Rule 6.7.2 in that situation, the Regulator must take into account all relevant information and factors. [#SRC:c6a75fa0-e9f4-459e-972a-a06f6236f8c6] The factors it must consider include: (1) the Rules contained in MIR; (2) what it has learned from routine supervision of the Recognised Body concerned; and (3) how much any failure or likely failure to meet one or more Recognition Requirements could affect the Regulator’s objectives. [#SRC:c6a75fa0-e9f4-459e-972a-a06f6236f8c6] Put together, this means the “operational objectives” reason for a Controllers-related direction should be supported by a broader review that also weighs the MIR rules, supervisory results, and the potential objectives-impact of (likely) non-compliance with Recognition Requirements. [#TGT:1c3cd986-8007-416b-9fb1-e4600d1b1c81] [#SRC:c6a75fa0-e9f4-459e-972a-a06f6236f8c6]

question: For an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, how must GEN Rule 5.2.14 be applied and interpreted, and how does that interpretation fit within the broader set of rulebooks and additional requirements that the Authorised Person must comply with (including the scenario where it is also Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets)?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets must apply GEN Rule 5.2.14 to its activity, and when doing so it must treat any reference in that rule to “Investment” as meaning “Virtual Asset”. [#TGT:726a7101-d094-4454-93b6-5e5561582705] This GEN Rule 5.2.14 application sits within a broader compliance package that applies in addition to the general requirements for an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets under Rules 17.1–17.6. [#SRC:24637efb-9ce5-40ee-bec4-7e5066d40d24] Specifically, the Authorised Person Operating the Multilateral Trading Facility must comply with requirements set out in COBS, MIR and GEN as described in Rules 17.7.2–17.7.6, which is the context in which GEN Rule 5.2.14 is being applied and interpreted for Virtual Assets. [#SRC:24637efb-9ce5-40ee-bec4-7e5066d40d24] If the same Authorised Person is also Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets, it must additionally comply with Rule 17.8, alongside the GEN Rule 5.2.14 interpretation described above. [#SRC:24637efb-9ce5-40ee-bec4-7e5066d40d24]

question: If an Authorised Person uses the FCSA and has eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure, what numbers does it plug into the RWA(CR) = E x CRW formula for the secured part and the unsecured part, and how does that fit into the overall process for calculating total RWA for CR Exposures?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person is using the FCSA and has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure, it can recognise the collateral’s CRM effect by dividing the exposure into a collateralised portion and an uncollateralised portion. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] This division matters because the overall RWA method requires the firm to determine E and CRW for each CR Exposure and then compute RWA(CR) as E multiplied by CRW, before adding up the RWA amounts across all CR Exposures. [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368] For the collateralised portion, E is set equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and the CRW used is the risk weight that applies to that collateral as if the firm had a direct exposure to it. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] For the uncollateralised portion, E equals the E of the CR Exposure minus the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and the CRW used is the risk weight that applies to the obligor. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] The firm then applies the same RWA(CR) = E x CRW calculation to each portion and includes those results when summing RWA amounts for all CR Exposures. [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368]

question: When the Investigator issues a written notice requiring production of Specified Documents at a Specified time and place, what forms of documents may be demanded and what authority does the Investigator have to keep originals after production?
gold_answer: Where the Investigator uses a written notice to require the Person Under Investigation or any other person to produce Specified Documents (or Documents of a Specified description) at a Specified time and place, the notice-based power establishes the mechanism and logistics for production (including the specified time/place and the scope of documents). [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] In addition, the Investigator’s document-production power includes the ability to require either original documents or copies, so the recipient may be directed to provide originals rather than reproductions (or vice versa) depending on what is required. [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3] If originals are produced in response to the notice, the Investigator is permitted to keep possession of any original document for as long as is necessary for the purpose for which it was requested, meaning retention is tied to necessity and purpose rather than a fixed period. [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3] Accordingly, compliance should address both (i) meeting the specified time-and-place production requirement in the written notice and (ii) readiness for the Investigator to insist on originals and to retain them when necessary for the stated investigative purpose. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3]

question: If the Investigator requires a person (including someone not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to permit entry to business premises during normal business hours to inspect and copy Documents, how does that interact with the Investigator’s power to require production of specified documents, including originals or copies and retention of originals?
gold_answer: The Investigator may require, by written notice, the Person Under Investigation or any other person (even if not connected) to allow the Investigator to enter that person’s business premises during normal business hours to inspect and copy Documents located there. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] Separately, the Investigator also has authority to require a person to produce (or procure the production of) specified documents or documents of a specified description, and that requirement can be framed as production of originals or copies. [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3] Read together, the premises-entry/inspection route focuses on on-site access for inspection and copying during normal business hours, while the production route allows the Investigator to compel delivery of documents (including originals) rather than relying only on on-site copying. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3] If originals are produced under the production power (whether following an on-site inspection or independently), the Investigator may keep possession of any original document for as long as necessary for the purpose for which it was requested. [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3] Therefore, a person receiving such requirements should be prepared both for on-premises inspection/copying during normal business hours and for compelled production that may involve surrender and temporary retention of originals. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3]
