question: If a Person applies for an ADGM Green Bond (or any other designation in the list), what fee do they pay when applying, and what fee do they pay later if the Regulator grants the designation (including how the first year is handled and when later years are due)?
gold_answer: When a Person applies for a designation in the listed set (including ADGM Green Bond), they must pay the Regulator an application fee of $2,000. [#TGT:a0e78247-fd29-4fda-8fdc-07ce6c83f37b] If the Regulator grants the designation, the Person must then pay an annual designation fee of $2,000 to the Regulator, with different treatment for the first year versus later years. [#SRC:aa8d419c-7982-47cd-833b-4ae9bd269fbc] In the first year after the designation is initially granted, the annual designation fee is not necessarily the full-year amount; it is prorated for the remainder of that calendar year. [#SRC:aa8d419c-7982-47cd-833b-4ae9bd269fbc] For each later calendar year that starts on 1 January, the Person must pay the annual designation fee in full, and the payment must be made on or before 31 January of the calendar year the fee covers. [#SRC:aa8d419c-7982-47cd-833b-4ae9bd269fbc] So, the process is: pay $2,000 to apply for the listed designation type, and if granted, pay $2,000 per year thereafter, with proration in the initial year and a 31 January deadline for subsequent years. [#TGT:a0e78247-fd29-4fda-8fdc-07ce6c83f37b] [#SRC:aa8d419c-7982-47cd-833b-4ae9bd269fbc]

question: For Units already admitted to trading on another Recognised Investment Exchange or Regulated Exchange (the Other Market), what specific conditions must be met to use the section 61 FSMR exemption for admission to trading, and what overarching requirement applies to the trading of all Units in the class (including those specified under Rule 3.3.5) once admitted?
gold_answer: To rely on the section 61 FSMR exemption for admitting Units that are already admitted to trading on an Other Market, the Units of the same class must have been admitted to trading and continuously traded on that Other Market for more than 18 months, the on‑going obligations for trading on that Other Market must have been complied with, and an English summary document must be approved by the Regulator and published with specified content (including Key Information required under Rule 4.5.2(1)(b), where the most recent/current Prospectus (if any) can be obtained, and where the Issuer’s financial information published under the Other Market’s on‑going disclosure obligations is available). [#TGT:3a7c96c9-65c9-422f-b480-4592229e0ace] This exemption is also stated to apply only subject to the requirement in Rule 3.3.6. [#TGT:3a7c96c9-65c9-422f-b480-4592229e0ace] Separately, the Exempt Offers rule for Units imposes a class-wide trading venue constraint: all Units in a class of Securities admitted to trading—including those specified under Rule 3.3.5—must be traded on a Recognised Investment Exchange. [#SRC:8304d78c-757e-45d8-a9b6-fd855e1513ab] Accordingly, even where the Other Market pathway conditions and documentation are satisfied for admission, the resulting admitted class must still trade on a Recognised Investment Exchange, and this requirement explicitly extends to the Rule 3.3.5 Units within that class. [#SRC:8304d78c-757e-45d8-a9b6-fd855e1513ab]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a compliant disclosure about Non-Equivalent Estimates, what does it need to do in a later update so it doesn’t have to repeat the Rule 11.7.3 information, and how does that fit with the rule that lets it skip Rule 11.2.1(1) for material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation?
gold_answer: For material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, a Mining Reporting Entity can avoid having to comply with Rule 11.2.1(1) only by complying with the alternative set of rules listed for that situation, which includes Rule 11.7.3. [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] Once the entity has made a Non-Equivalent Estimates disclosure that meets Rule 11.7.3, a later disclosure about those same estimates can leave out the Rule 11.7.3 information, but only if the later disclosure follows the specific conditions for doing so. [#TGT:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] In the later update, the Mining Reporting Entity must: - Point back to the earlier disclosure that complied with Rule 11.7.3. [#TGT:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] - Confirm that the earlier Rule 11.7.3 information still applies and that there is no new material information or data that affects either (i) the reliability or interpretation of the Non-Equivalent Estimates or (ii) the entity’s ability to verify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard. [#TGT:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] - Add an at least equally prominent and nearby statement that addresses the matters covered by Rule 11.7.3(1). [#TGT:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] Doing this preserves the initial pathway where Rule 11.2.1(1) is not required because the entity is complying with the specified Rule 11.7 requirements (including Rule 11.7.3). [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26]

question: Where a Recognised Investment Exchange is permitted by the FSRA (and within the scope of its Recognition Order) to operate a separate MTF, OTF and/or MTF using Virtual Assets, what additional market must it also operate, and how do the Recognition Requirements apply in that combined operating model?
gold_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange that is operating an MTF or an OTF must, in addition, operate a market that meets the Recognition Requirements. [#TGT:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d] This obligation applies even where the Recognised Investment Exchange is permitted by the FSRA to operate a separate MTF, OTF and/or MTF using Virtual Assets under its Recognition Order (and within the described framework for operating markets relating to the trading of Financial Instruments, including Digital Securities). [#SRC:fa3cde4e-a388-4d88-bb14-8242a2758cc0] In practical terms, the permission to run a separate venue using Virtual Assets does not remove the need to maintain a compliant market alongside the MTF/OTF activity; rather, the Recognised Investment Exchange must ensure that its overall operating model includes (i) the MTF and/or OTF (which may be separate and may involve Virtual Assets where permitted) and (ii) a market that satisfies the Recognition Requirements. [#SRC:fa3cde4e-a388-4d88-bb14-8242a2758cc0] [#TGT:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d] The key linkage is that the FSRA-permitted operation of a separate MTF/OTF/MTF using Virtual Assets under a Recognition Order sits alongside, and does not substitute for, the requirement to operate a Recognition Requirements-compliant market when operating an MTF or OTF. [#SRC:fa3cde4e-a388-4d88-bb14-8242a2758cc0] [#TGT:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d]

question: Where the parties have agreed that Rule 19.11.1(3) does not apply because a Low Value Payment Instrument does not allow for the stopping or prevention of its use, what ongoing capability must the Payment Service Provider still maintain for Payment Service Users regarding reporting loss, theft, misappropriation, or unauthorised use of the Payment Instrument?
gold_answer: Even if the parties agree to disapply the specific rule on notifying loss of a Payment Instrument for a Low Value Payment Instrument that cannot be stopped or prevented from being used, the Payment Service Provider must still maintain a continuous reporting channel for the Payment Service User. [#SRC:1db4fdad-1fa0-4aae-ad68-56d8705902d9] In practice, the Payment Service Provider’s baseline obligation is to ensure that appropriate means are available at all times for a Payment Service User to notify the Payment Service Provider when the Payment Instrument is lost, stolen, misappropriated, or used without authorisation. [#TGT:9b652a81-4dfa-4909-b738-a9285f01f41a] The disapplication described is limited to the identified rules (including Rule 19.11.1(3) and Rule 19.20.1(4)) and only in the stated circumstance that the Low Value Payment Instrument does not allow stopping or prevention of its use. [#SRC:1db4fdad-1fa0-4aae-ad68-56d8705902d9] Accordingly, regardless of whether the parties have agreed that Rule 19.11.1(3) does not apply in that scenario, the Payment Service Provider must still keep always-on, appropriate notification means so the Payment Service User can report the relevant events to the Payment Service Provider. [#TGT:9b652a81-4dfa-4909-b738-a9285f01f41a]

question: If a Low Value Payment Instrument can’t be stopped and the parties agree that the rule about notifying loss (Rule 19.11.1(3)) doesn’t apply, does the Payment Service Provider still need to keep a way for users to report loss or unauthorised use at any time? What exactly has to be available?
gold_answer: Yes. Even where the parties agree that certain rules do not apply for a Low Value Payment Instrument because it does not allow stopping or preventing its use—including the rule dealing with notification of loss of a Payment Instrument (Rule 19.11.1(3))—the Payment Service Provider still has an ongoing operational duty to support user reporting. [#SRC:1db4fdad-1fa0-4aae-ad68-56d8705902d9] Specifically, the Payment Service Provider must ensure that appropriate means are available at all times so that a Payment Service User can notify the Payment Service Provider of the loss, theft, misappropriation, or unauthorised use of the Payment Instrument. [#TGT:9b652a81-4dfa-4909-b738-a9285f01f41a] The agreement described in the Low Value Payment Instrument provision is limited to disapplying the listed rules (Rule 19.11.1(3) and Rule 19.20.1(4)) and only in the stated condition that the instrument cannot be stopped or prevented from being used. [#SRC:1db4fdad-1fa0-4aae-ad68-56d8705902d9] That limitation does not remove the separate requirement that reporting channels exist continuously and cover the four types of events (loss, theft, misappropriation, and unauthorised use). [#TGT:9b652a81-4dfa-4909-b738-a9285f01f41a]

question: Where an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and is using the FCCA, how should the firm determine and apply E* in the credit risk weighted exposure calculation, and what haircut methodology options are available when calculating E* for such a collateralised transaction (other than an OTC Derivative transaction or a long settlement transaction)?
gold_answer: In this scenario, the Authorised Person must compute an adjusted exposure value (E*) and use it in place of the unadjusted exposure (E) when determining the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for the relevant CR Exposure. [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de] This substitution requirement applies where the firm has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT, the SFT is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, and the firm is using the FCCA. [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de] The firm must calculate E* in accordance with the specified App4 rules (A4.3.2 to A4.3.6) referenced for this purpose. [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de] When calculating E* for collateralised transactions other than OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions, the Authorised Person must determine the appropriate haircuts to apply using one of two permitted approaches: standard supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts. [#TGT:19b5846d-b958-4e12-a8d2-ffe1b2dd7ed8] Accordingly, for the described SFT exposure, E* is calculated under the referenced App4 framework and then used as the exposure input for credit risk weighting, with haircuts selected via one of the two allowed haircut methodologies. [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de] [#TGT:19b5846d-b958-4e12-a8d2-ffe1b2dd7ed8]

question: When calculating RWA for securitisation Exposures, how must an Authorised Person use the Exposure measurement methodology, and how does that methodology’s stated purpose (covering both Credit RWA for Credit Risk Exposures under Rule 4.8.3 and securitisation Exposures under Rule 4.8.4) connect to the step in which the Exposure value is determined under Section 4.9?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must determine the Exposure value for each of its SE Exposures using the Exposure measurement methodology specified in Section 4.9, and it must do so in a way that recognises the effects of any applicable CRM. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] This reliance on Section 4.9 aligns with the stated purpose of the measurement methodology, which prescribes how Exposures are calculated for determining Credit RWA for Credit Risk (CR) Exposures under Rule 4.8.3 and for securitisation (SE) Exposures under Rule 4.8.4. [#SRC:84ee9ffb-686e-47d9-b971-908e8cec77f1] After establishing the Exposure value under Section 4.9, the Authorised Person must allocate an applicable Credit Quality Grade for the SE Exposure under Section 4.11 and then compute the RWA amount for each SE Exposure using the formula RWA(SE) = SE x CRW, where SE is the Exposure value calculated under the Section 4.9 methodology and CRW is the risk weight determined from the Credit Quality Grade. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] SE Exposures that must be included as deductions from any component of Capital Resources are excluded from this per-exposure RWA calculation step. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646]

question: If an Authorised Person is working out RWA for securitisation Exposures, what are the main steps they must follow, and how does the Exposure measurement methodology’s stated role for both Credit Risk (Rule 4.8.3) and securitisation (Rule 4.8.4) explain why they start by measuring the Exposure under Section 4.9?
gold_answer: To calculate RWA for securitisation Exposures, an Authorised Person must start by calculating the Exposure value for each SE Exposure using the Exposure measurement methodology in Section 4.9 and taking into account any applicable CRM. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] This starting point is consistent with the stated function of the measurement methodology, which sets out how to calculate Exposures for determining Credit RWA for Credit Risk (CR) Exposures under Rule 4.8.3 and for securitisation (SE) Exposures under Rule 4.8.4. [#SRC:84ee9ffb-686e-47d9-b971-908e8cec77f1] After the Exposure value is measured, the Authorised Person must assign a Credit Quality Grade for the SE Exposure under Section 4.11 and then calculate the RWA amount for each SE Exposure using RWA(SE) = SE x CRW, where SE is the Exposure value from the Section 4.9 step and CRW is the risk weight that follows from the Credit Quality Grade. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] The Authorised Person does not apply that formula to any SE Exposures that it is required to include as deductions from any component of Capital Resources. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] Finally, it must add up the RWA amounts for all SE Exposures and combine them with the RWA amounts calculated under Rule 4.8.5 for Early Amortisation Exposures. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646]

question: Where a RIE settles Digital Securities without engaging a RCH and instead uses a DSF, what written confirmation must the RIE provide to the FSRA/Regulator about its arrangements, and what additional compliance condition is imposed on the DSF in that scenario?
gold_answer: A RIE that does not engage a RCH for the settlement of Digital Securities and instead uses a DSF must provide the FSRA, in writing, with details of the satisfactory arrangements it has made for that settlement approach. [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] This aligns with the broader requirement that, when a Recognised Investment Exchange engages a party that is not a Recognised Clearing House or a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Clearing House, it must confirm to the Regulator in writing the satisfactory arrangements made under Rule 3.8.1. [#TGT:58de7c59-691a-427d-b34d-d7fd9baf874e] In the specific Digital Securities/DSF context, the written submission is not only a confirmation that arrangements are satisfactory, but must include the details of those arrangements. [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] Additionally, the FSRA requires that using a DSF for settlement purposes is conditional on the DSF complying with the requirements of MIR Rule 4.3.3, with any references in that rule to a RCH read as references to a DSF. [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] Accordingly, the RIE’s written confirmation to the Regulator/FSRA about satisfactory arrangements must be paired with ensuring the engaged non-RCH party (the DSF) meets the MIR Rule 4.3.3 standard as adapted for DSFs. [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] [#TGT:58de7c59-691a-427d-b34d-d7fd9baf874e]

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange uses a Digital Settlement Facility (DSF) to settle Digital Securities instead of using a Recognised Clearing House, what does it need to send in writing to the Regulator/FSRA, and what rule does the DSF have to meet (with any needed wording change)?
gold_answer: In this situation, the Recognised Investment Exchange must make a written submission to the Regulator/FSRA about the settlement arrangements it has put in place with the non-RCH party. [#TGT:58de7c59-691a-427d-b34d-d7fd9baf874e] For Digital Securities where the RIE or MTF does not engage a RCH and uses a DSF, the written submission must include the details of the satisfactory arrangements made for settlement. [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] This is the Digital Securities-specific way of meeting the general obligation to confirm, in writing, satisfactory arrangements when engaging a party that is not a Recognised Clearing House or a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Clearing House. [#TGT:58de7c59-691a-427d-b34d-d7fd9baf874e] Beyond describing the arrangements, the FSRA requires that the DSF used for settlement must comply with MIR Rule 4.3.3, and that any references in that rule to a RCH are treated as references to a DSF. [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] Practically, the RIE’s written confirmation and the DSF’s compliance with the adapted MIR Rule 4.3.3 condition operate together: the RIE documents the satisfactory arrangements in writing, and the DSF must meet the specified rule standard as if it were a RCH for that purpose. [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] [#TGT:58de7c59-691a-427d-b34d-d7fd9baf874e]

question: When an Authorised Person acts as a clearing member intermediary between a client and a CCP, how should it determine the exposure measure it uses to calculate Credit RWA for its Trade Exposure to that client, and when would a different method be permitted for derivatives or long settlement transactions?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that is acting as a clearing member intermediary between a client and a CCP must calculate Credit RWA for its Trade Exposure to the client using the specific credit risk framework referenced for that Trade Exposure, including the associated treatment of any client-posted Collateral where applicable. [#SRC:57fed3b7-e493-4c49-9c2d-c8c8194bbac8] Where the Trade Exposure arises from Derivative transactions (whether OTC or exchange-traded) or from long settlement transactions, the exposure-at-default input to that calculation must be determined using the Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR) as set out for those transaction types, unless the Authorised Person has received permission from the Regulator to use an internal model instead. [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff] In practical terms, this means the firm should (i) identify that it is acting in the clearing member intermediary capacity and therefore has a Trade Exposure to the client, (ii) calculate Credit RWA for that exposure under the referenced rule set and apply the relevant provisions for any Collateral posted by the client, and (iii) for any derivatives or long settlement components, compute EAD under SA-CCR unless an internal-model permission has been granted by the Regulator. [#SRC:57fed3b7-e493-4c49-9c2d-c8c8194bbac8] [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff]

question: If an Authorised Person is a clearing member between a client and a CCP, what does it have to do to work out Credit RWA for its Trade Exposure to the client, and how does the EAD rule for derivatives/long settlement deals change if the Regulator allows an internal model?
gold_answer: In this clearing-member intermediary setup, the Authorised Person must calculate Credit RWA for its Trade Exposure to the client using the specified approach for that Trade Exposure, and it must also apply the relevant provisions for any Collateral the client has posted (if there is any). [#SRC:57fed3b7-e493-4c49-9c2d-c8c8194bbac8] If the exposure comes from Derivative transactions (OTC or exchange-traded) or from long settlement transactions, the exposure at default (EAD) used in the calculation must be worked out under the Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR). [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff] The only stated way this EAD method changes is if the Authorised Person has been granted permission by the Regulator to use an internal model; in that case, the SA-CCR requirement does not apply for those transactions. [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff] So the combined compliance steps are: confirm the clearing member intermediary role and the existence of Trade Exposure to the client, calculate Credit RWA under the referenced framework while reflecting any client Collateral, and determine EAD for derivatives/long settlement transactions under SA-CCR unless an internal-model permission has been granted. [#SRC:57fed3b7-e493-4c49-9c2d-c8c8194bbac8] [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff]

question: How should a Third Party Provider demonstrate that its professional indemnity insurance is sufficient to reimburse Customers for operational risk events while also complying with the Transaction Limits requirement tied to the average daily value of Third Party Transactions over the past ninety calendar days?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider should treat “sufficient” professional indemnity insurance as a dual obligation: it must be adequate to reimburse Customers if operational risk events occur, and it must continuously satisfy the Transaction Limits coverage-to-activity threshold. [#SRC:c9a29acd-37bb-40cb-9516-3121dbf18b53] [#TGT:aaaa3ad8-9dea-490e-bd62-04177ed8aa0b] In practice, this means the Third Party Provider must maintain professional indemnity insurance coverage and monitor it against its transaction activity so that the remaining coverage is always more than thirty times the average daily value of all Third Party Transactions calculated over the past ninety calendar days. [#TGT:aaaa3ad8-9dea-490e-bd62-04177ed8aa0b] At the same time, the coverage level must be maintained with the purpose of reimbursing Customers if an operational risk event occurs, so the Third Party Provider should not allow coverage to fall below a level that would undermine that reimbursement objective. [#SRC:c9a29acd-37bb-40cb-9516-3121dbf18b53] Accordingly, compliance requires ongoing maintenance of coverage and ongoing calculation of the ninety-day average daily transaction value to confirm the “greater than thirty times” condition is met at all times. [#TGT:aaaa3ad8-9dea-490e-bd62-04177ed8aa0b]

question: If a Third Party Provider wants to be sure customers can be repaid after an operational risk event, what insurance level must it keep when you also factor in the rule that compares remaining coverage to the last 90 days of Third Party Transactions?
gold_answer: The Third Party Provider must keep professional indemnity insurance coverage that is sufficient to reimburse Customers if operational risk events happen, and it must also ensure that the remaining amount of that coverage stays above a specific transaction-based threshold. [#SRC:c9a29acd-37bb-40cb-9516-3121dbf18b53] [#TGT:aaaa3ad8-9dea-490e-bd62-04177ed8aa0b] Concretely, the Transaction Limits requirement means the Third Party Provider must ensure its remaining professional indemnity insurance coverage is always greater than thirty times the average daily value of all Third Party Transactions over the past ninety calendar days. [#TGT:aaaa3ad8-9dea-490e-bd62-04177ed8aa0b] Separately, the insurance must be maintained with the aim of reimbursing Customers if an operational risk event occurs, so the Third Party Provider should view the coverage as serving that customer reimbursement purpose, not merely meeting a numeric ratio. [#SRC:c9a29acd-37bb-40cb-9516-3121dbf18b53] Putting both together, the Third Party Provider needs to (1) maintain coverage for customer reimbursement in operational risk events and (2) continuously check that the remaining coverage exceeds the “30×” threshold based on the ninety-day average daily transaction value. [#SRC:c9a29acd-37bb-40cb-9516-3121dbf18b53] [#TGT:aaaa3ad8-9dea-490e-bd62-04177ed8aa0b]

question: What capabilities must a Recognised Investment Exchange have to determine whether a participant or Member has exceeded a position limit set for a Derivative or class of Derivatives, and what specific categories of positions must it include in that determination (including any Derivative-equivalent treatment for Options)?
gold_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange must be able to assess whether a participant or Member has gone beyond any position limit that has been set for a Derivative or a class of Derivatives under the relevant rule framework, and it must have capabilities that support making that determination. [#SRC:eadea557-36b4-4076-8a57-1d53f951f4a8] In performing the determination for a position limit imposed in respect of a Derivative, the Recognised Investment Exchange must aggregate more than the participant’s or Member’s own direct holdings. [#TGT:24094c9c-2c15-4682-bda2-38f4934fbe17] Specifically, it must take into account positions held by other Persons that are directly or indirectly controlled by the participant or Member, so that controlled entities’ positions are included in the exceedance test. [#TGT:24094c9c-2c15-4682-bda2-38f4934fbe17] It must also include positions held by other Persons who, under an express or implied agreement or understanding, act as if the position were held by the participant or Member. [#TGT:24094c9c-2c15-4682-bda2-38f4934fbe17] In addition, it must include positions relating to an Option on the Derivative contract, and those option positions must be calculated on a Derivative-equivalent basis for purposes of determining whether the limit has been exceeded. [#TGT:24094c9c-2c15-4682-bda2-38f4934fbe17] These aggregation and calculation elements are part of what the exchange’s capabilities must support when determining exceedance of the applicable position limit. [#SRC:eadea557-36b4-4076-8a57-1d53f951f4a8]

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange is checking whether a participant or Member has gone over a position limit for a Derivative (or a class of Derivatives), what must the exchange be able to do, and whose positions does it need to count—including how it should treat Options on the Derivative?
gold_answer: The Recognised Investment Exchange must have the capability to work out whether a participant or Member has exceeded a position limit that has been set for a Derivative or for a class of Derivatives under the applicable rule. [#SRC:eadea557-36b4-4076-8a57-1d53f951f4a8] When it makes that exceedance check for a position limit imposed in respect of a Derivative, it cannot look only at the participant’s or Member’s own position in isolation. [#TGT:24094c9c-2c15-4682-bda2-38f4934fbe17] The exchange must include positions held by any other Person that the participant or Member directly or indirectly controls, so controlled Persons’ holdings are counted toward the limit. [#TGT:24094c9c-2c15-4682-bda2-38f4934fbe17] It must also include positions held by any other Person who is acting—based on an express or implied agreement or understanding—as if the position were held by the participant or Member. [#TGT:24094c9c-2c15-4682-bda2-38f4934fbe17] Finally, if there is an Option on the Derivative contract, the exchange must count the position held in respect of that Option, but it must do so by converting it into a Derivative-equivalent amount (a Derivative equivalent basis) for the exceedance calculation. [#TGT:24094c9c-2c15-4682-bda2-38f4934fbe17] These counting rules describe what the exchange’s capability must support when determining whether the limit has been breached. [#SRC:eadea557-36b4-4076-8a57-1d53f951f4a8]

question: When an Authorised Person calculates the Exposure value for SFTs as on-balance sheet items using IFRS and the applicable netting requirements, what must it be able to demonstrate to the Regulator is in place for netting to be recognised, including the legal and procedural elements and the failure events covered?
gold_answer: For on-balance sheet SFTs, the Exposure value is determined using IFRS together with the applicable netting requirements, so netting can only be relied on where the Authorised Person can substantiate to the Regulator that its netting framework meets the specified contractual, legal-review, and ongoing-review conditions. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] In practice, this means the Authorised Person must be able to show: (1) it has a netting contract or other agreement that creates a single legal obligation across all transactions included in the netting set, so that if the counterparty fails to perform due to default, bankruptcy, liquidation, or similar circumstances, the Authorised Person has only a right to receive or duty to pay the net sum of positive and negative mark-to-market values; (2) it has written, reasoned legal reviews supporting that courts and administrative authorities would treat the exposure as a net amount under the counterparty’s chartering jurisdiction (and branch jurisdiction where relevant), the law governing the individual transactions, and the law governing any contract needed to effect netting; and (3) it maintains procedures to keep the legal characteristics of the netting arrangements under review as relevant law may change. [#TGT:2d7c2f1d-0a70-43b7-b68c-a2e4ca99c15a]

question: If an Authorised Person is working out the Exposure value for on-balance sheet SFTs using IFRS and netting, what paperwork and ongoing checks does it need so it can prove to the Regulator that netting is valid, and in what counterparty failure situations does the net amount apply?
gold_answer: Because the Exposure value for on-balance sheet SFTs is calculated using IFRS together with the applicable netting requirements, the Authorised Person should only treat exposures on a net basis where it can demonstrate to the Regulator that the required netting arrangements are in place. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] Specifically, it must be able to evidence a netting contract (or similar agreement) that creates a single legal obligation covering all included transactions, so that if the counterparty fails to perform due to default, bankruptcy, liquidation, or similar circumstances, the Authorised Person is exposed only to the net sum of the positive and negative mark-to-market values of those transactions. [#TGT:2d7c2f1d-0a70-43b7-b68c-a2e4ca99c15a] It must also have written and reasoned legal reviews supporting that, if challenged, courts and administrative authorities would recognise the exposure as net under the counterparty’s chartering law (and branch law where relevant), the law governing the individual transactions, and the law governing any contract needed to make netting effective. [#TGT:2d7c2f1d-0a70-43b7-b68c-a2e4ca99c15a] Finally, it needs procedures to keep the legal characteristics of the netting arrangements under review as relevant law may change. [#TGT:2d7c2f1d-0a70-43b7-b68c-a2e4ca99c15a]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure under Rule 11.9.1 that includes forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, how must it address (i) the material economic assumptions (including any claim of commercial sensitivity) and (ii) the need to disclose key underlying assumptions and outcomes from a relevant Technical Study used to support confidence in modifying factors for Ore Reserves?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity’s Rule 11.9.1 disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target must be supported by transparent assumptions, and it must also align with the expectation that key assumptions and outcomes from any relevant Technical Study underpinning Ore Reserves confidence are disclosed. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:30cf9cda-951e-48ba-9be2-61a889a87464] Specifically, the disclosure must include all material economic assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity considers those material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, it must state that view and explain the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions (rather than omitting them without explanation). [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] It must also include all other material assumptions utilised. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In addition, because achieving the required level of confidence in modifying factors for an Ore Reserves estimate requires a relevant Technical Study (preliminary feasibility study or feasibility study), the key underlying assumptions and outcomes of that Technical Study are also to be disclosed. [#TGT:30cf9cda-951e-48ba-9be2-61a889a87464] Finally, the disclosure must identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including the information required by Rule 11.8.3. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity publishes forecast financial information based on a Production Target, what details does it need to include about its assumptions (including if it says they are commercially sensitive), and what extra Technical Study information must also be disclosed to support confidence in modifying factors for Ore Reserves?
gold_answer: For forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, the Mining Reporting Entity must provide a complete assumptions package and also disclose the key assumptions and outcomes from the Technical Study that supports confidence in modifying factors for Ore Reserves. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:30cf9cda-951e-48ba-9be2-61a889a87464] On the forecast side, the disclosure must cover: (i) all material economic assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, and (ii) all other material assumptions utilised. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity believes the material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it cannot stop at that label; it must state that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] The disclosure must also identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, and include the information required by Rule 11.8.3 as part of that Production Target disclosure. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] Separately, to reach the required level of confidence in the modifying factors used to estimate Ore Reserves, the Mining Reporting Entity needs to have carried out a relevant Technical Study (a preliminary feasibility study or feasibility study), and the key underlying assumptions and outcomes of that Technical Study are also to be disclosed. [#TGT:30cf9cda-951e-48ba-9be2-61a889a87464]

question: If a Payment Order for one Payment Transaction is sent using a Payment Instrument under a Framework Contract, what information can the Payment Service Provider skip because another Payment Service Provider covers it under Section 19.2, and what information must still be given right after the Payment Order is initiated?
gold_answer: In this situation, the Payment Service Provider for the single Payment Transaction is allowed to leave out only the general information that would otherwise be provided under Rule 19.5.1, but only when that general information has been provided or will be provided under Section 19.2 by another Payment Service Provider for the Framework Contract. [#SRC:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2] Even with that carve‑out, the provider must still give the post‑initiation details immediately after the Payment Order is initiated, to the Payer and (if relevant) the Payee. [#TGT:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622] Those immediate details include: confirmation that the Payment Order was successfully initiated with the Payer’s Payment Service Provider; a reference that lets the Payer and Payee identify the Payment Transaction (including the Payer and Payee and, where appropriate, information transferred with the Payment Order); the amount and currency; any charges and, where applicable, a breakdown of those charges in the Payment Order currency; any exchange rate used (or a reference) and the amount after conversion; the date the Payment Service Provider received the Payment Order; and the Credit Value Date. [#TGT:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622] The key boundary is that the “skip” applies only to general information already handled at the Framework Contract level by another provider, not to the immediate transaction‑specific items required after initiation. [#SRC:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2]

question: When a Prospectus by a Mining Reporting Entity contains a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets, what preparation standards and additional content must be met, including any cross-referenced rule and sustainability-related disclosures?
gold_answer: A Prospectus by a Mining Reporting Entity that contains a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets must satisfy both (i) the general preparation framework for such disclosures and (ii) Prospectus-specific inclusions and cross-references. [#SRC:ac70dcf0-7928-4d1c-9561-1b88ff273cb9] [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d] Specifically, because the Prospectus includes one of those statements, it must comply with Rule 11.2.1 in addition to the requirements of Chapter 4. [#SRC:ac70dcf0-7928-4d1c-9561-1b88ff273cb9] In parallel, the disclosure containing that statement must be prepared in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard and also in accordance with this chapter. [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d] The Prospectus must also include details of the Mining Reporting Entity’s policies and practices for operating sustainably, including its policy on environmental and social issues, the impact of its business practices on the environment and the communities where it operates, and the environmental and social risks it faces. [#SRC:ac70dcf0-7928-4d1c-9561-1b88ff273cb9] Taken together, the preparation standards (Mining Reporting Standard plus this chapter) and the Prospectus content requirements (Rule 11.2.1, Chapter 4 compliance, and sustainability disclosures) must all be addressed for the same statement-driven disclosure. [#SRC:ac70dcf0-7928-4d1c-9561-1b88ff273cb9] [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity’s Prospectus talks about Exploration Targets (or similar items like Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves), what rules does it have to follow to prepare that disclosure, and what extra sustainability information has to be included in the Prospectus?
gold_answer: If the Prospectus includes a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets, the Mining Reporting Entity has to treat that content as a regulated disclosure and meet both preparation and Prospectus content requirements. [#SRC:ac70dcf0-7928-4d1c-9561-1b88ff273cb9] [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d] On preparation, the disclosure that contains the statement must be prepared in line with a Mining Reporting Standard and also in line with this chapter. [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d] On Prospectus-specific obligations, the Prospectus must comply with Chapter 4 and, because it contains that kind of statement, it must also comply with Rule 11.2.1. [#SRC:ac70dcf0-7928-4d1c-9561-1b88ff273cb9] In addition, the Prospectus must include details about the Mining Reporting Entity’s policies and practices for operating sustainably, covering (i) its policy on environmental and social issues, (ii) how its business practices affect the environment and the communities where it operates, and (iii) the environmental and social risks it faces. [#SRC:ac70dcf0-7928-4d1c-9561-1b88ff273cb9] In practice, you should ensure the same statement-driven disclosure is both prepared under the Mining Reporting Standard/this chapter framework and accompanied by the Prospectus sustainability disclosures and cross-referenced compliance items. [#SRC:ac70dcf0-7928-4d1c-9561-1b88ff273cb9] [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d]

question: Where a Recognised Clearing House makes provision as allowed under Rule 4.5.8, how must its procedures address (i) the designation and ongoing review of Persons or descriptions of person and (ii) the substantive market-operation risk test that determines whether a Person or description should not be, or should not remain, designated?
gold_answer: A Recognised Clearing House that makes provision as allowed under Rule 4.5.8 must maintain procedures that both manage the designation lifecycle and apply a market-operation impact test to prevent inappropriate designations. [#TGT:242b0395-19a9-4471-85cb-e31dac7eae5d] In particular, the procedures must be adequate to (a) designate the relevant Persons or descriptions of person in respect of whom action may be taken, (b) keep under review which Persons or descriptions should be or remain designated, and (c) withdraw a designation when appropriate. [#TGT:242b0395-19a9-4471-85cb-e31dac7eae5d] Those designation, review, and withdrawal steps must be designed so that a Person is not, or does not remain, designated if that Person’s failure to meet obligations in respect of one or more Market Contracts would adversely affect the operation of the market. [#SRC:55576d4c-9a95-4fb8-8fd6-9462a2a1153b] The same design requirement applies at the category level: a description of persons must not be, or remain, designated if failure by a Person of that description to meet obligations in respect of one or more Market Contracts would affect market operation. [#SRC:55576d4c-9a95-4fb8-8fd6-9462a2a1153b] Accordingly, the ongoing review and any withdrawal decision should be driven by whether the relevant Market Contract obligation failures would impact market operation, ensuring the designation set remains aligned with that risk threshold. [#SRC:55576d4c-9a95-4fb8-8fd6-9462a2a1153b]

question: If the Recognised Clearing House uses the option allowed under Rule 4.5.8, what should its procedures cover for choosing and removing designated Persons (or descriptions of person), and what market-impact check must those procedures be designed to apply about failures to meet obligations under one or more Market Contracts?
gold_answer: When the Recognised Clearing House makes provision as allowed under Rule 4.5.8, it must have procedures that cover the full process for designation and also embed a specific market-impact safeguard. [#TGT:242b0395-19a9-4471-85cb-e31dac7eae5d] On process, the procedures must be adequate for (a) designating the Persons or descriptions of person in respect of whom action may be taken, (b) keeping under review which Persons or descriptions should be or remain designated, and (c) withdrawing a designation. [#TGT:242b0395-19a9-4471-85cb-e31dac7eae5d] On the safeguard, those procedures must be designed so that a Person is not, or does not remain, designated if that Person’s failure to meet obligations in respect of one or more Market Contracts would adversely affect the operation of the market. [#SRC:55576d4c-9a95-4fb8-8fd6-9462a2a1153b] The same design principle applies to a description of persons: it must not be, or remain, designated if failure by a Person within that description to meet obligations in respect of one or more Market Contracts would affect market operation. [#SRC:55576d4c-9a95-4fb8-8fd6-9462a2a1153b] Practically, the review and withdrawal parts of the procedure should be used to ensure designations do not continue where that market-operation impact condition would be met. [#TGT:242b0395-19a9-4471-85cb-e31dac7eae5d]

question: When the Regulator receives the notice referred to in Rule 3.1.2 and is considering whether to send the notice of intent to use passporting procedures to Host Regulator(s) within five Business Days, in what circumstances must it refrain from transmitting the notice under Rule 3.1.4(a), and what downstream steps (including publication and notification) are tied to Host Regulator confirmation if the process proceeds?
gold_answer: The Regulator is required to withhold transmitting a notice under Rule 3.1.4(a) if it concludes either that the Fund Manager or the Private Fund is not compliant with applicable legislation (including these Rules), or that there are reasonable grounds to determine the Fund Manager or the Private Fund may become non-compliant in the future. [#SRC:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c] It must also refrain where it considers doing so is necessary and appropriate to advance one or more of its objectives. [#SRC:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c] If those withholding conditions do not apply and the process proceeds, then within five Business Days after receiving the notice described in Rule 3.1.2 (and subject to Rule 3.1.5), the Regulator must provide notice of its intent to use the passporting procedures to the Host Regulator(s) in each relevant Host Jurisdiction where the Passported Fund is intended to be Promoted. [#TGT:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7] After the relevant Host Regulator(s) confirm their Register of Passported Funds has been updated to include the Passported Fund’s details, the Regulator must then promptly publish the Passported Fund’s details on the Register of Passported Funds and notify the Fund Manager that registration is complete. [#TGT:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7]

question: When the Regulator is considering granting a waiver from Rule 3.5.1 for an order on a Recognised Investment Exchange market on the basis that it is “large in scale compared with normal market size,” what specific threshold and classification method must be used to determine whether the order qualifies?
gold_answer: To assess whether a waiver from Rule 3.5.1 may be granted on the “large in scale compared with normal market size” basis, the relevant qualifying concept is the category of “orders that are large in scale compared with normal market size” referenced for waivers, which is tied to Rule 3.5.11. [#TGT:aa29640b-f2f9-435b-8e56-31e99fff54e6] For the purpose of applying that large-in-scale concept (in the context referenced by Rule 3.5.7(c)), an order is treated as large in scale if its size is at least the minimum order size specified in Rule 3.5.11. [#SRC:12e55ccd-cd6e-4509-aaf7-b0985942d627] In addition, when determining whether an order is large in scale compared with normal market size, all Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange market must be classified according to their average daily turnover, following Rule 3.5.12. [#SRC:12e55ccd-cd6e-4509-aaf7-b0985942d627] Accordingly, the waiver analysis must combine (i) the Rule 3.5.11 minimum-size threshold with (ii) the required turnover-based classification framework for instruments admitted to trading on the Recognised Investment Exchange market, because the waiver category depends on the “large in scale” determination. [#TGT:aa29640b-f2f9-435b-8e56-31e99fff54e6] [#SRC:12e55ccd-cd6e-4509-aaf7-b0985942d627]

question: If someone wants a waiver from Rule 3.5.1 because an order is “large in scale,” how do you decide if it is big enough, and what extra step applies to Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange market?
gold_answer: A waiver from Rule 3.5.1 can be granted by the Regulator for “orders that are large in scale compared with normal market size,” and that waiver category is linked to Rule 3.5.11. [#TGT:aa29640b-f2f9-435b-8e56-31e99fff54e6] To decide whether an order is large in scale for the relevant large-in-scale concept (referenced for Rule 3.5.7(c)), you treat the order as large in scale when its size is equal to or above the minimum order size set out in Rule 3.5.11. [#SRC:12e55ccd-cd6e-4509-aaf7-b0985942d627] There is also an additional step that applies across the market: for the purpose of making the large-in-scale determination, all Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange market must be classified based on their average daily turnover, using the approach in Rule 3.5.12. [#SRC:12e55ccd-cd6e-4509-aaf7-b0985942d627] Putting these together, you cannot rely only on the waiver label; you must apply the Rule 3.5.11 minimum-size threshold and the turnover-based classification method for instruments admitted to trading on the Recognised Investment Exchange market to support that the order fits the waiver category. [#TGT:aa29640b-f2f9-435b-8e56-31e99fff54e6] [#SRC:12e55ccd-cd6e-4509-aaf7-b0985942d627]

question: When FSRA assesses whether a Spot Commodity Settlement Facility (SCSF) has satisfactory arrangements to secure timely discharge of parties’ rights and liabilities under MIR Rule 4.3.3, how should that assessment be reconciled with the statement that a Recognised Clearing House is not treated as breaching its Recognition Requirement solely because it cannot arrange settlement of a specific transaction?
gold_answer: FSRA’s assessment of an SCSF under MIR Rule 4.3.3 focuses on whether the SCSF has satisfactory arrangements and procedures designed to secure timely discharge of parties’ rights and liabilities, rather than guaranteeing that every individual transaction will in fact settle. [#SRC:b5d36396-57ff-473e-8ff9-0e392516e731] In practice, the SCSF should be able to demonstrate a coherent framework covering (among other things) clearing and settlement rules and practices (including any outsourcing to another Person), trade matching to confirm agreement on trade details, delivery and payment arrangements across relevant jurisdictions, and mechanisms to detect, manage, and respond to settlement failures by a Member (or participant). [#SRC:b5d36396-57ff-473e-8ff9-0e392516e731] That arrangements-based focus aligns with the principle that a Recognised Clearing House is not automatically regarded as non-compliant with its Recognition Requirement merely because it cannot arrange settlement for a particular transaction. [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e] Accordingly, an inability to settle a specific trade should not, by itself, negate an otherwise satisfactory set of default rules, default procedures, monitoring of Members’ settlement performance, and “step-in” arrangements to take action to settle when a Member (or participant) does not. [#SRC:b5d36396-57ff-473e-8ff9-0e392516e731] The key is whether the SCSF’s documented arrangements exist and operate to manage settlement risk and failures, not whether settlement is invariably achievable in every case. [#SRC:b5d36396-57ff-473e-8ff9-0e392516e731][#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e]

question: If a Relevant Person wants to use a Person in (1) to do parts of CDD, what checks does it need to do about the other country’s AML/TFS rules being FATF-equivalent, and what must it get right away from the third party?
gold_answer: The Relevant Person can only rely on a Person in (1) for CDD elements if it satisfies specific reliance conditions and confirms the third party is regulated and supervised for AML/TFS compliance by a Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator or other competent authority in a country whose AML/TFS rules match the FATF Recommendations’ standards. [#TGT:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275] To judge whether that country’s AML/TFS regulations are equivalent to FATF standards, the Relevant Person must consider multiple factors, such as mutual evaluations and assessment or follow-up reports published by FATF and other International Organisations like the IMF, World Bank, or OECD, and whether the country is part of FATF or regional groups such as MENAFATF or the Gulf Co-operation Council. [#SRC:06794d47-81ee-49d0-bf3a-58e87a031da4] It also needs to weigh contextual issues like political stability and corruption, and look for recent criticism (for example FATF advisory notices, public assessments by those organisations, or reports from relevant NGOs or specialist commercial organisations). [#SRC:06794d47-81ee-49d0-bf3a-58e87a031da4] Operationally, it must immediately obtain the necessary CDD information from the third party and take adequate steps to ensure certified copies of the documents used for the relevant CDD work can be provided on request without delay. [#TGT:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275] It must also ensure the third party did not rely on an exception for any CDD element being relied on and that the information is up to date. [#TGT:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275]

question: Where an Offer is directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients (and the Securities are offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility), how does this interact with an Issuer’s ability to make a simultaneous Exempt Offer to an unlimited number of Professional Clients when the Securities are to be admitted to trading on a MTF?
gold_answer: An Offer can qualify as an Exempt Offer when it is directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients (or Market Counterparties) and the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] Separately, in the specific scenario where an Issuer is seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF, the framework contemplates an Exempt Offer directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] In that same MTF admission context, the Issuer may run a simultaneous Exempt Offer to an unlimited number of Professional Clients under the Professional Client-only circumstance. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] The linkage is that the 200-Person, non-Professional-Client concept aligns across both passages, while the SOURCE adds the operational structuring point: the Issuer can pair that 200-Person MTF-related Exempt Offer with a parallel Professional Client-only Exempt Offer in the same fundraising. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] The Professional Client-only limb is expressly recognised as an Exempt Offer circumstance, enabling the “unlimited number of Professional Clients” component described for the simultaneous offer. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc]

question: Where an Authorised Person is (i) under Rule 3.11.2 or Rule 3.11.4 and operates as a Cell Company and (ii) also holds a Financial Services Permission to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, what annual supervision fees must be paid to the Regulator, and how does the number of Cells affect the total?
gold_answer: In this scenario, the Authorised Person must pay two annual supervision fee components to the Regulator: one tied to operating as a Cell Company and another tied to the specified insurance Regulated Activities carried on as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle. [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b] [#TGT:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579] For the Cell Company aspect, an Authorised Person under Rule 3.11.2 or Rule 3.11.4 that operates as a Cell Company must pay an additional annual supervision fee of $8,000 for the Cell Company, plus $1,000 for each Cell, so the total increases in direct proportion to the number of Cells. [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b] Separately, if the same Authorised Person has a Financial Services Permission to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, it must pay an annual supervision fee of $5,000 covering either or both of those Regulated Activities (i.e., the fee is $5,000 whether it carries on one or both). [#TGT:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579] Accordingly, the overall annual supervision fees payable are $5,000 plus $8,000 plus $1,000 multiplied by the number of Cells. [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b] [#TGT:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579]

question: If an Authorised Person runs a Cell Company (under Rule 3.11.2 or Rule 3.11.4) and also has permission to do insurance business as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, what yearly supervision fees does it owe, and what part changes when it adds more Cells?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person owes a combination of annual supervision fees: one fee schedule applies because it operates as a Cell Company under Rule 3.11.2 or Rule 3.11.4, and another fee applies because it has a Financial Services Permission to carry on specified insurance Regulated Activities as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle. [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b] [#TGT:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579] For the Cell Company part, it must pay an additional annual supervision fee made up of $8,000 for the Cell Company itself plus $1,000 for each Cell, so adding Cells increases the total by $1,000 per added Cell. [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b] For the insurance permission part, if it is permitted to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, it must pay $5,000 per year, and that $5,000 applies whether it carries on one or both of those Regulated Activities. [#TGT:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579] Putting these together, the fixed amounts are $8,000 (Cell Company) and $5,000 (insurance activities), and the variable amount is $1,000 times the number of Cells. [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b] [#TGT:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579]

question: Under this Part, what conduct is prohibited when a person provides information “in purported compliance,” and how does the non-compliance discussion extend beyond false or misleading information to cover obstruction of investigative powers (including examples)?
gold_answer: A person is prohibited from providing materially false or misleading information when doing so in purported compliance with a requirement imposed under this Part, whether the person does so knowingly or recklessly. [#TGT:77f73737-390b-4344-848c-df4d94932e96] The non-compliance discussion aligns this prohibition with a contravention where a person deliberately or recklessly provides information that is false or misleading in a material particular in purported compliance with a Part 17 requirement. [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23] In addition, the non-compliance discussion makes clear that contraventions are not limited to misinformation: conduct intended to obstruct the exercise of investigative powers “by any means” is also treated as a contravention. [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23] Examples of obstructive conduct include failing to attend at a specified time and place to answer questions, falsifying/concealing/destroying documents, failing to give or produce information or documents specified by us, failing to permit access to premises, and failing to provide assistance in relation to an investigation. [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23] Taken together, the rule on false or misleading information sets the baseline prohibition for purported compliance, while the non-compliance discussion adds that intentional obstruction of investigative activity is separately captured and illustrates what that obstruction can look like in practice. [#TGT:77f73737-390b-4344-848c-df4d94932e96] [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23]

question: When a Recognised Investment Exchange is drafting Business Rules to admit Units in an open-ended Collective Investment Fund to trading, how should it operationalise the requirement that instruments be capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner, and which specific fund-related factors must it assess for that purpose?
gold_answer: To admit Units to trading, a Recognised Investment Exchange must have Business Rules that ensure the Units are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner, and it should implement that standard by embedding an assessment that is tailored to Units in collective investment funds. [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215] For an open-ended Collective Investment Fund, the assessment should cover (and the Business Rules should be designed to take into account) the extent to which the Units are distributed to the public, whether there are appropriate market-making arrangements or, alternatively, whether the Fund Manager provides suitable arrangements for investors to redeem the Units, and whether investors receive sufficient transparency on value through periodic publication of the net asset value. [#SRC:72e47a23-5aa5-4df1-a4d6-2aaf037e9131] In practice, this means the Recognised Investment Exchange should translate the general “fair, orderly and efficient” trading requirement into admission checks or criteria that explicitly test those three open-ended fund elements, rather than treating Units like generic Financial Instruments. [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215] The linkage is that the Business Rules obligation to ensure fair, orderly and efficient trading is met, for Units, by applying the fund-specific factors (distribution, market-making/redemption arrangements, and NAV transparency) when deciding whether to admit the Units. [#SRC:72e47a23-5aa5-4df1-a4d6-2aaf037e9131]

question: If an Issuer is offering Securities to the public in or from ADGM and needs to publish a Prospectus, what can the Regulator do if the person making the Prospectus Offer doesn’t publish required information, and where do the Prospectus obligations come from?
gold_answer: In an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, the applicable requirements include an obligation to publish a Prospectus (including under Section 61 of FSMR), and those offer requirements sit within Sections 58 to 71 of FSMR and Chapter 4 of the Markets Rules ("MKT"). [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] If, in that Prospectus Offer setting, the person making the Prospectus Offer fails to publish information that they are required to publish by or under the Regulations, the Regulator is permitted (but not required) to publish that information instead. [#TGT:cd1d6043-c316-4559-ad75-ad86cdaeaa9f] The Regulations also specify how the Regulator would do this: the Regulator may publish the information in the manner prescribed in the Rules. [#TGT:cd1d6043-c316-4559-ad75-ad86cdaeaa9f] Practically, this means that where the Prospectus-related publication duties apply to the Issuer’s ADGM public offer, a publication failure can lead to the Regulator making the required information public using the Rules-based method. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd]

question: For an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, how should the annual supervision fee amount be determined and paid when the Applicant is seeking to operate an MTF, taking into account that the SOURCE sets the fee “pursuant to FEES Rule 3.17.2” and “payable in accordance with paragraph 1 of the FEES Rulebook,” while the TARGET distinguishes between (i) $15,000 per Regulated Activity and (ii) $60,000 where the Regulated Activity is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility without any additional Regulated Activity?
gold_answer: The annual supervision fee for an Authorised Person carrying on a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets is set at either $15,000 or $60,000, and the correct amount depends on whether the activity is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility and whether it is the only Regulated Activity. [#SRC:9a65518c-820e-4e90-abba-4a05d7c482c0] [#TGT:febdfdb0-1bc0-41ad-a131-4be1812571f8] Where the Applicant is seeking to operate an MTF (in relation to Virtual Assets), the SOURCE identifies a $60,000 annual supervision fee category established under FEES Rule 3.17.2 and payable under paragraph 1 of the FEES Rulebook. [#SRC:9a65518c-820e-4e90-abba-4a05d7c482c0] The TARGET clarifies how that $60,000 category applies in operational terms: the $60,000 amount is used when the Regulated Activity is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility and there is no additional Regulated Activity. [#TGT:febdfdb0-1bc0-41ad-a131-4be1812571f8] If the Authorised Person undertakes Regulated Activities beyond Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility, the TARGET indicates the annual supervision fee is $15,000 for each Regulated Activity, payable to the Regulator in addition to supervision fees due in respect of each Regulated Activity undertaken. [#TGT:febdfdb0-1bc0-41ad-a131-4be1812571f8] Payment is to be made in the manner contemplated by paragraph 1 of the FEES Rulebook as referenced in the SOURCE. [#SRC:9a65518c-820e-4e90-abba-4a05d7c482c0]

question: If an Authorised Person has a Financial Services Permission for Virtual Assets, when do they pay $15,000 and when do they pay $60,000 each year, and how does the SOURCE’s note that the fee is set under FEES Rule 3.17.2 and payable under paragraph 1 of the FEES Rulebook fit with the TARGET’s rule about “Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility without any additional Regulated Activity”?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission to carry on a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets must pay an annual supervision fee that is either $15,000 or $60,000, and the choice depends on the type and combination of Regulated Activities. [#TGT:febdfdb0-1bc0-41ad-a131-4be1812571f8] The SOURCE frames these amounts as the annual supervision fees set under FEES Rule 3.17.2 and indicates they are payable in accordance with paragraph 1 of the FEES Rulebook. [#SRC:9a65518c-820e-4e90-abba-4a05d7c482c0] In practical terms: - Pay $15,000 when the fee is calculated per Regulated Activity, because the TARGET sets $15,000 for each Regulated Activity the Authorised Person undertakes. [#TGT:febdfdb0-1bc0-41ad-a131-4be1812571f8] - Pay $60,000 when the Regulated Activity is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility and it is the only Regulated Activity, which aligns with the SOURCE’s $60,000 category for an Applicant seeking to operate an MTF (in relation to Virtual Assets). [#TGT:febdfdb0-1bc0-41ad-a131-4be1812571f8] [#SRC:9a65518c-820e-4e90-abba-4a05d7c482c0] The payment mechanics are tied to paragraph 1 of the FEES Rulebook as referenced in the SOURCE, while the TARGET explains when each amount applies based on the activity mix. [#SRC:9a65518c-820e-4e90-abba-4a05d7c482c0] [#TGT:febdfdb0-1bc0-41ad-a131-4be1812571f8]

question: When considering whether to modify or waive Rule 2.3.2 for an admission to the Official List, how should the Regulator assess whether investors have the necessary information, specifically in relation to the Applicant’s audited financial statements (including period covered, consolidation, accounting standards, and audit standards)?
gold_answer: The Regulator may modify or waive Rule 2.3.2 only where it considers the change desirable in the interests of investors and is satisfied that investors have enough information to make an informed judgement about the Issuer and the Shares for which admission to the Official List is sought. [#SRC:108a7eb5-7dc8-4146-9fbb-d68fe745ccca] In assessing whether investors have “necessary information” in this context, a central element is whether the Applicant has made available audited financial statements meeting the specified publication/filing and content conditions. [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1] Practically, the information baseline for investor judgement can be evidenced by confirming that the Applicant has published or filed audited accounts that: (i) cover three prior years, or a shorter period that the Regulator accepts; (ii) are consolidated for the Applicant and its subsidiary undertakings; (iii) are prepared under IFRS or other standards acceptable to the Regulator; and (iv) are audited and reported on under IAASB auditing standards or other standards acceptable to the Regulator. [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1] If these audited-account conditions are met (including any Regulator-accepted shorter period or alternative standards), that supports the Regulator’s satisfaction that investors have the necessary information when deciding whether a Rule 2.3.2 modification/waiver is appropriate. [#SRC:108a7eb5-7dc8-4146-9fbb-d68fe745ccca] [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1]

question: If the Regulator is thinking about waiving or changing Rule 2.3.2 for a company seeking admission to the Official List, what audited accounts information should be checked to help show investors can still make an informed judgement about the Issuer and the Shares?
gold_answer: A waiver or change to Rule 2.3.2 is only available where the Regulator thinks doing so is desirable for investors and is satisfied that investors still have enough information to make an informed judgement about the Issuer and the Shares being admitted to the Official List. [#SRC:108a7eb5-7dc8-4146-9fbb-d68fe745ccca] One key way to support that “enough information” test is to confirm the Applicant has made audited financial statements available in the form and scope required for audited accounts. [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1] To do that check, verify the Applicant has published or filed audited accounts that meet all of these points: they cover a prior period of three years (or a shorter period the Regulator accepts); they are consolidated for the Applicant and any subsidiary undertakings; they are prepared under IFRS or another standard the Regulator accepts; and they have been audited and reported on by auditors using IAASB auditing standards (or another standard the Regulator accepts). [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1] If those audited-account conditions are satisfied (including any Regulator-accepted alternatives), that helps demonstrate the investor-information basis the Regulator must be comfortable with before modifying or waiving Rule 2.3.2. [#SRC:108a7eb5-7dc8-4146-9fbb-d68fe745ccca] [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1]

question: If you are working out what goes into an Authorised Person’s Available Stable Funding (ASF), and you see AT1 Capital items, what exactly counts as AT1 Capital (including share premium), and what extra ASF screening step must you apply for Tier 2 instruments with short remaining maturity?
gold_answer: To handle AT1 Capital items correctly while building the Available Stable Funding (ASF) set, you need to apply two linked determinations: what counts as AT1 Capital, and what the ASF identification process requires (including a specific Tier 2 exclusion). [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1] AT1 Capital is made up of (a) capital instruments that satisfy the eligibility criteria in Rule 3.11.3 and (b) the Share premium accounts that relate to those eligible instruments. [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b] Separately, when an Authorised Person identifies capital instruments to include in ASF, it must do so by considering capital elements that meet the eligibility requirements under Rule 3.10.2, Rule 3.11.2, and Rule 3.12.2. [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1] In that ASF identification step, the Authorised Person must exclude all Tier 2 capital instruments that have a residual maturity of less than one year. [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1] So, you should (i) classify AT1 items as eligible instruments under Rule 3.11.3 plus their related share premium, and (ii) apply the ASF rule set and the Tier 2 short-maturity exclusion when deciding what is included in ASF. [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b] [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1]

question: Where a PFP Operator updates information it has published under Rule 18.5.1 to reflect a material change and provides notice of that change to PFP Clients, what specific records must it retain and for how long, including any related transaction documentation and due diligence materials?
gold_answer: A PFP Operator must both (i) keep its Rule 18.5.1 published information current for material changes and notify PFP Clients of those changes within a reasonable timeframe, and (ii) retain defined records for at least six years that evidence the disclosures and related compliance activity. [#TGT:40149b11-dcb8-48a6-ab09-8d8c37923183] Specifically, because the update and client notice relate to information published under Rule 18.5.1, the Operator must maintain records of all disclosures made under Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2 for a minimum of six years. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] In addition, the Operator must keep, for the same minimum six-year period, documentation exchanged between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect, to the extent such documentation exists in connection with the relevant PFP activity. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] The Operator must also retain records of the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1 for at least six years, which supports the integrity of the information being published and updated. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] The timing obligation for notifying PFP Clients is that notice must be provided within a reasonable timeframe after the material change occurs. [#TGT:40149b11-dcb8-48a6-ab09-8d8c37923183]

question: If a PFP Operator makes a material change to the information it publishes under Rule 18.5.1, what does it need to do for PFP Clients, and what records does it have to keep (and for how long) to show it did this and handled the related work?
gold_answer: When there is a material change affecting information published under Rule 18.5.1, the PFP Operator must update that published information so it reflects the change and must give PFP Clients notice of the material change within a reasonable timeframe after the change happens. [#TGT:40149b11-dcb8-48a6-ab09-8d8c37923183] To demonstrate and support this activity, the Operator must keep specified records for a minimum of six years. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] Those records include all disclosures made under Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2, which would cover the disclosures connected to the information being updated and notified. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] The Operator must also retain all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect, where such documentation exists in connection with the relevant transaction activity. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] Finally, it must keep records of the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1 for at least six years, as part of the overall record set it is required to maintain. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7]

question: How should a Recognised Body structure its internal compliance arrangements so that its Auditors can meet both (i) the general duty to disclose to the Regulator matters indicating a breach or likely breach of Regulations or Rules and (ii) the Appointed auditor’s duty to communicate information/opinions to the Regulator when specific material-significance or reporting-limitation circumstances arise (including Threshold Conditions/Recognition Requirements and going-concern concerns)?
gold_answer: A Recognised Body should implement internal systems and procedures that both (1) capture and escalate potential non-compliance matters for disclosure to the Regulator and (2) enable its Auditors (including an Appointed auditor) to make the specific communications to the Regulator that are triggered by defined audit-judgment circumstances. [#SRC:80eb597d-32ee-446e-a416-b5777f98698b] In practice, the Recognised Body’s arrangements should be designed so its Auditors can identify and report matters that may indicate a breach/likely breach or failure/likely failure to comply with Regulations or Rules, and so the Recognised Body can support compliance with those notification requirements. [#SRC:80eb597d-32ee-446e-a416-b5777f98698b] Those same arrangements should also ensure the Appointed auditor can communicate to the Regulator information or opinions on the matters referenced in sections 191(3) and 192(3) when the auditor reasonably believes there may have been a contravention that could be materially significant to the Regulator’s use of its powers, or when the information/opinion may be materially significant to whether the person concerned will satisfy Threshold Conditions or (for a Recognised Body) Recognition Requirements. [#TGT:46098015-5ac3-4e30-a252-1dc40ab3f6d6] The procedures should further support communication where the auditor reasonably believes the person concerned may cease to be a going concern, or where the auditor is unable to make required statements in the auditor’s report about preparation of annual accounts/other financial reports or other specified reporting statements. [#TGT:46098015-5ac3-4e30-a252-1dc40ab3f6d6]

question: If an Appointed auditor thinks a company might not be a going concern or can’t make certain statements in the audit report, what does the Recognised Body need to have in place so the auditor can notify the Regulator, and how does that connect to the general rule about telling the Regulator about likely breaches of Regulations or Rules?
gold_answer: The Recognised Body needs systems and procedures that make it possible for its Auditors to comply with notification duties to the Regulator, including situations that arise during audit work. [#SRC:80eb597d-32ee-446e-a416-b5777f98698b] This includes enabling disclosures to the Regulator of any matter that may indicate a breach or likely breach of, or a failure or likely failure to comply with, Regulations or Rules, and ensuring the Recognised Body’s Auditors can meet those notification requirements in practice. [#SRC:80eb597d-32ee-446e-a416-b5777f98698b] In addition, when the auditor is an Appointed auditor, the auditor must communicate to the Regulator information or an opinion on the matters mentioned in sections 191(3) and 192(3) if the auditor reasonably believes the person concerned is not, may not be, or may cease to be, a going concern.
