[#SRC:2722b40a-c3fd-4d87-a5aa-65796ac6bdf2] Put together, the weekly report should show both the person’s category and whether their positions are risk-reducing or not, as far as the Recognised Investment Exchange can determine. [#SRC:2722b40a-c3fd-4d87-a5aa-65796ac6bdf2]

question: Where an Authorised Person holds money received from a Professional Client under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement, how should that money be treated for Client Money classification purposes, and do the Client Money Rules and Safe Custody Rules apply to it?
gold_answer: Money received under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement from a Professional Client is treated as not being Client Money. [#SRC:875ef4dc-f3c8-464c-b6f3-6216b864e3bc] When that money is held by an Authorised Person pursuant to a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement, the Client Money Rules do not apply to it. [#TGT:d541bbc2-9a05-45ff-8063-6dd671feecb7] This conclusion depends on both (i) the client classification condition that the payer is a Professional Client and (ii) the holding condition that the asset or money is held by an Authorised Person under the same type of agreement. [#SRC:875ef4dc-f3c8-464c-b6f3-6216b864e3bc] [#TGT:d541bbc2-9a05-45ff-8063-6dd671feecb7] In addition, where an Authorised Person holds a Safe Custody Asset pursuant to a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement, the Safe Custody Rules do not apply in respect of that Safe Custody Asset. [#TGT:d541bbc2-9a05-45ff-8063-6dd671feecb7] Accordingly, in the specific scenario of money received from a Professional Client under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement and held by an Authorised Person under that agreement, the money is outside the definition of Client Money and is also outside the scope of the Client Money Rules. [#SRC:875ef4dc-f3c8-464c-b6f3-6216b864e3bc] [#TGT:d541bbc2-9a05-45ff-8063-6dd671feecb7]

question: If an Authorised Person gets money from a Professional Client under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement, is it treated as Client Money, and do the Client Money Rules and Safe Custody Rules apply?
gold_answer: In this situation, the money is not treated as Client Money, because it is money received under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement from a Professional Client. [#SRC:875ef4dc-f3c8-464c-b6f3-6216b864e3bc] Separately, when Client Money (or a Safe Custody Asset) is held by an Authorised Person under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement, the Client Money Rules and Safe Custody Rules do not apply in respect of that holding. [#TGT:d541bbc2-9a05-45ff-8063-6dd671feecb7] Putting these together, the classification point (Professional Client money under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement is not Client Money) and the scope point (rules do not apply where held by an Authorised Person under that agreement) both need to be satisfied to fully describe the regulatory treatment. [#SRC:875ef4dc-f3c8-464c-b6f3-6216b864e3bc] [#TGT:d541bbc2-9a05-45ff-8063-6dd671feecb7] The same rule-based exclusion from the Client Money Rules and Safe Custody Rules also covers Safe Custody Assets held by an Authorised Person under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement, even though the Client Money classification statement in the other passage is specifically about money received from a Professional Client. [#TGT:d541bbc2-9a05-45ff-8063-6dd671feecb7] [#SRC:875ef4dc-f3c8-464c-b6f3-6216b864e3bc]

question: For an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm, how should the Governing Body’s assessment of capital adequacy affect the firm’s obligation to maintain Capital Resources “at all times,” including any expectation to hold additional capital and liquid assets beyond the specified minimum types and amounts?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must continuously meet the baseline capital requirement and also use its Governing Body’s assessment to determine whether additional resources are needed beyond that baseline. Specifically, the Domestic Firm is required to have and maintain, at all times, Capital Resources of the types and amounts specified in, and calculated in accordance with, these Rules. [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56] In parallel, for the purposes of Rule 3.2.4, the Authorised Person’s Governing Body should evaluate whether the Capital Resources required by the Regulator under these Rules are adequate when viewed against the Authorised Person’s specific business model and risk profile. [#SRC:097ade5d-12c3-4d41-876b-1634652a822d] Where that assessment indicates the required Capital Resources do not adequately reflect the nature and risks of the Authorised Person’s business, the Authorised Person should maintain additional resources. [#SRC:097ade5d-12c3-4d41-876b-1634652a822d] This aligns with the Domestic Firm obligation to ensure it maintains capital and liquid assets in addition to the baseline requirement that are adequate in relation to the nature, size and complexity of its business, so there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due. [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56]

question: If an Authorised Person is a Domestic Firm, what does it have to keep “at all times,” and how does the Governing Body decide whether the firm should hold extra resources beyond the minimum to match its business and risks?
gold_answer: A Domestic Firm must always meet the rule-based minimum capital requirement, and it must also consider whether extra resources are needed based on its business characteristics and risks. The firm must have and maintain, at all times, Capital Resources of the types and amounts specified in, and calculated in accordance with, these Rules. [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56] In addition, the firm must ensure it maintains capital and liquid assets on top of that minimum that are adequate for the nature, size and complexity of its business, so there is no significant risk it cannot pay liabilities when they are due. [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56] For the purposes of Rule 3.2.4, the Authorised Person’s Governing Body should assess whether the Capital Resources required by the Regulator under these Rules are adequate in relation to the Authorised Person’s specific business model and risk profile. [#SRC:097ade5d-12c3-4d41-876b-1634652a822d] If the Governing Body concludes the required Capital Resources do not properly reflect the nature and risks of the business, the Authorised Person should maintain additional resources to address that gap. [#SRC:097ade5d-12c3-4d41-876b-1634652a822d]

question: For an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services that undertakes the activity of a Money Remitter, how must it determine the Capital Requirement for that activity, and how is the Money Remitter Variable Capital Requirement component calculated using monthly payment volume tiers?
gold_answer: For the Money Remitter activity, the Authorised Person must set the Capital Requirement by taking the highest applicable amount among the specified capital measures for that activity, including the Money Remitter’s Variable Capital Requirement and the relevant Expenditure Based Capital Minimum, and also comparing against the applicable Base Capital Requirement. [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304] In particular, for a Money Remitter the Capital Requirement must be the highest of: (i) the applicable Base Capital Requirement; and (ii) the Money Remitter-specific combination of (A) the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum and (B) the Variable Capital Requirement calculated in accordance with the Money Remitter rule. [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304] The Variable Capital Requirement for a Money Remitter is calculated as a tiered percentage applied to monthly payment volume and then summed across tiers. [#TGT:b1b3ae34-d42b-4c08-83fb-9ddac72f228c] Concretely, it equals 1.25% of the first $10 million of monthly payment volume, plus 0.5% of the next $90 million, plus 0.25% of the next $150 million, plus 0.125% of any remaining monthly payment volume. [#TGT:b1b3ae34-d42b-4c08-83fb-9ddac72f228c] The resulting Variable Capital Requirement figure is then used as the Variable Capital Requirement input when determining the highest amount for the Money Remitter activity’s Capital Requirement. [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304]

question: If an Authorised Person provides Money Services and acts as a Money Remitter, what numbers does it have to compare to set its Capital Requirement for that activity, and how do you work out the Money Remitter Variable Capital Requirement from monthly payment volume?
gold_answer: When the Authorised Person is carrying on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services and the relevant activity is being a Money Remitter, it must determine the Capital Requirement for that activity by selecting the highest amount from the required capital measures, rather than choosing a lower figure. [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304] For a Money Remitter, those measures include the applicable Base Capital Requirement and, for the Money Remitter category, both the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum and the Variable Capital Requirement calculated under the Money Remitter method. [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304] To compute the Money Remitter Variable Capital Requirement, you apply a set of percentage rates to bands of monthly payment volume and add the results together. [#TGT:b1b3ae34-d42b-4c08-83fb-9ddac72f228c] The bands are: 1.25% on the first $10 million, 0.5% on the next $90 million, 0.25% on the next $150 million, and 0.125% on any remaining monthly payment volume above those amounts. [#TGT:b1b3ae34-d42b-4c08-83fb-9ddac72f228c] After calculating that tiered sum, the Authorised Person uses it as the Variable Capital Requirement input when identifying the highest figure that becomes the Capital Requirement for the Money Remitter activity. [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304]

question: If an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business has to reconcile Client Accounts at least every calendar month, what does it need to keep in its Resolution Pack to show this, and what kind of control expectation goes with the monthly reconciliation rule?
gold_answer: The firm needs to do two connected things: it must have systems and controls that make sure reconciliations of Client Accounts are accurate and done as often as needed, but at least once each calendar month, and it must keep the latest reconciliation records in its Resolution Pack. [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] The control expectation is not just to perform reconciliations occasionally; it is to maintain adequate systems and controls designed to ensure the reconciliations are carried out accurately and on a regular schedule that meets the minimum monthly frequency. [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b] To evidence that reconciliation activity in the Resolution Pack, the Pack must include the most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments, meaning the latest completed reconciliation records for those areas should be present and up to date. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] Put together, the monthly reconciliation requirement drives the cadence and accuracy of the process, while the Resolution Pack requirement specifies that the newest reconciliation outputs for Client Money and Client Investments must be retained in that Pack as part of the firm’s records. [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]

question: When preparing a Product Summary Note for an Exempt Offer under Rule 4.3.1(13), what disclaimer-related content is the Issuer required to include, and what disclaimer-related content must the Issuer avoid including in or about the Product Summary Note?
gold_answer: For an Exempt Offer under Rule 4.3.1(13), the Issuer must include a particular disclaimer: the Product Summary Note must carry the prominent disclaimer referenced in Rule 4.3.4, placed on the front of the Product Summary Note and shown in bold. [#TGT:624cf5d5-aef8-4bd2-9587-d41858b3ede2] Beyond that mandated front-page disclaimer, the Issuer must refrain from including disclaimers that relate to information disclosed in the Product Summary Note or that are made in respect of the Product Summary Note. [#SRC:6d1b4cca-e1ac-42ee-bfe9-70c2c65bcf04] In practice, this means the Issuer should not add additional disclaimer statements elsewhere in the Product Summary Note (or otherwise “in respect of” it) that attempt to qualify, limit, or caveat the disclosed information, because the general rule is to avoid such disclaimers. [#SRC:6d1b4cca-e1ac-42ee-bfe9-70c2c65bcf04] This disclaimer discipline should be applied alongside the Exempt Offer content requirements that the Product Summary Note must present key information, be fair and balanced on benefits and risks, and avoid false or misleading statements or omissions. [#TGT:624cf5d5-aef8-4bd2-9587-d41858b3ede2] The result is a Product Summary Note that includes the required front-page disclaimer while not layering on additional disclaimer language that the general prohibition would capture. [#TGT:624cf5d5-aef8-4bd2-9587-d41858b3ede2] [#SRC:6d1b4cca-e1ac-42ee-bfe9-70c2c65bcf04]

question: When a Listed Entity/Reporting Entity writes its annual financial report, what does it need to say about adopting the Corporate Governance Principles, and how does that connect to the need to comply with Rule 9.2.10 on annual reporting of compliance?
gold_answer: In its annual financial report, a Listed Entity to which the annual reporting section applies must make specific statements about its Corporate Governance Principles position, and this reporting should be handled with awareness that Listed Entities/Reporting Entities also have to comply with Rule 9.2.10 on annual reporting of their compliance with those principles. [#SRC:88ccc385-cfe8-4e4e-afd3-80026e74b4dd] The annual financial report must state whether the best practice standards in APP 4 (the Corporate Governance Principles) have been adopted. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] If the standards have not been fully adopted or have only been partially adopted, the report must explain why that is the case and describe what actions (if any) have been taken to achieve compliance to the extent the standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] The report must also include a Directors’ statement on whether the Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, and that statement must be supported by information and assumptions and may include qualifications if needed. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] Preparing these disclosures in the annual financial report helps align the entity’s annual reporting with the separate Rule 9.2.10 compliance-reporting obligation. [#SRC:88ccc385-cfe8-4e4e-afd3-80026e74b4dd]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that includes Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, how must it both (i) obtain and reflect the Competent Person(s)’ prior written consent regarding the form and context of the presentation, and (ii) include the required Competent Person statements (named person, employment/Related Party status and employer, and professional organisation membership) within that same disclosure?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity should treat the Competent Person(s)’ prior written consent as a prerequisite to making the disclosure in the first place, and then ensure the disclosure text contains the specific Competent Person statements required for disclosures that include Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves. [#SRC:c30b96f6-edff-4774-b206-68a20fe00ba8] [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] Practically, this means the entity must secure written approval from the relevant Competent Person(s) covering the form and context in which the Exploration Results or the Mineral Resources/Ore Reserves estimates (and their supporting information) are presented, before issuing the disclosure. [#SRC:c30b96f6-edff-4774-b206-68a20fe00ba8] In the disclosure itself, it must also state that the disclosure is based on and fairly represents information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s). [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] Additionally, for each Competent Person, it must specify whether the person is an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party, and if neither, identify the Competent Person’s employer. [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] Finally, it must name the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member. [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203]

question: Where an Authorised Person is Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets, how should the term “Investments” (and the related concept of “Client Investments”) be interpreted for the purposes of Rule 17.8.1, and what additional COBS chapter compliance obligations apply in that custody scenario (including any guidance relevant to holding or controlling Client Money)?
gold_answer: For an Authorised Person that is Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets, the Rule 17.8.1 terminology must be applied on a Virtual Asset-inclusive basis, and the firm must also meet the specified COBS custody-related chapter requirements (with separate guidance where Client Money is involved). [#TGT:b2806cf3-5ff8-43bc-9eb3-8d2fa28c39e0] Specifically, for the purposes of Rule 17.8.1, references to “Investment” or “Investments” must be read as including “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets”, and the corresponding references to “Client Investments” must be read the same way. [#SRC:1a0d0b8c-b8bf-48a1-b6ab-683d17ae56a0] In addition, beyond the general requirements for an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets in Rules 17.1–17.6, an Authorised Person that is Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets must comply with the requirements in COBS Chapters 14, 15 and 16, as implemented through Rules 17.8.2–17.8.3. [#TGT:b2806cf3-5ff8-43bc-9eb3-8d2fa28c39e0] As guidance, where an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets holds or controls Client Money, it must comply with the Client Money Rules in Chapter 14, as modified by Rule 17.8.4. [#TGT:b2806cf3-5ff8-43bc-9eb3-8d2fa28c39e0]

question: If an Authorised Person has balance sheet positions in different currencies, how often does it have to do the evaluation of Exposure to interest rate risk from its Non Trading Book activities, and what extra measurement does it need to do because of the different currencies?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must evaluate its Exposure to the interest rate risk that comes from its Non Trading Book activities, and the minimum frequency for that evaluation is once each year (with that minimum stated as being subject to a condition in paragraph (2)). [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3] [#SRC:aac1f0b1-dd75-472e-9e45-c806fdf2a3f5] If the Authorised Person has balance sheet positions in different currencies, it also has to measure its risk Exposures separately in each of the material currencies, because the rule specifically adds this measurement requirement for multi-currency balance sheets. [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3] Putting these together, a multi-currency Authorised Person should ensure that its annual evaluation is informed by currency-by-currency measurement of risk Exposures for all material currencies, so that the evaluation covers the required Exposure assessment and the required measurement granularity. [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3] [#SRC:aac1f0b1-dd75-472e-9e45-c806fdf2a3f5]

question: If an Authorised Person takes eligible financial Collateral for an SFT, when can it count the collateral effect for the pre-settlement exposure, and when does it have to calculate E* (and use it instead of E) because the SFT is under a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and the Authorised Person is using the FCCA?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person can reflect the impact of eligible financial Collateral on the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure when that exposure is measured under Rule 4.9.15, by applying the collateral recognition approach set out in Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] Separately, if the SFT is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and the Authorised Person is using the FCCA, it has a mandatory calculation step for credit risk: it must compute E* for all its CR Exposures to any single Counterparty that are covered by that qualifying bilateral Netting agreement. [#TGT:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776] That E* calculation must follow Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4, including where the Authorised Person is using supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts. [#TGT:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776] Once E* is calculated, the Authorised Person must use E* in place of E when it calculates the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for its CR Exposures to that Counterparty under Section 4.8. [#TGT:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776] Taken together, this means collateral can be recognised for the pre-settlement exposure measurement under the Rule 4.9.15 pathway, while E* substitution is required for the Section 4.8 credit risk weighted exposure calculation when FCCA netting conditions apply. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] [#TGT:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776]

question: If someone wants to have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, and those Securities are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1, what do these two passages say they need to check—both the SOURCE condition about Rule 4.4.2 and the TARGET rule about an Approved Prospectus?
gold_answer: When Securities are being admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange and they qualify as Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1, the SOURCE says the section 61(1) prohibition does not apply to that admission, but only if the requirement in Rule 4.4.2 is satisfied. [#SRC:f70272ac-30bf-4e62-92d7-8b863f75cdf9] In parallel, the TARGET states a general restriction: a person must not have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange unless there is an Approved Prospectus for the relevant Securities, and this statement is expressed as being subject to subsection (3). [#TGT:82ade9b4-bba4-449c-815c-32d6ef292b54] Putting the two together for this fact pattern means you cannot rely only on the “Exempt Securities” label; you must also treat the SOURCE carve-out as conditional on Rule 4.4.2. [#SRC:f70272ac-30bf-4e62-92d7-8b863f75cdf9] At the same time, the admission-to-trading step is still within the TARGET’s scope, so the Approved Prospectus condition remains the default position for admissions unless the subsection (3) qualifier changes the outcome. [#TGT:82ade9b4-bba4-449c-815c-32d6ef292b54] Therefore, the practical checks are: confirm Exempt Securities status under Rule 4.4.1, ensure Rule 4.4.2 is met for the SOURCE exception, and assess whether an Approved Prospectus is required for the admission under the TARGET rule. [#SRC:f70272ac-30bf-4e62-92d7-8b863f75cdf9] [#TGT:82ade9b4-bba4-449c-815c-32d6ef292b54]

question: If the Regulator makes a decision (or makes Rules) that could harm someone’s rights, liabilities, or interests, can that person ask the Appeals Panel for a full merits review—and does it matter if the decision is an operational decision or one of the non‑Part 21 decisions like exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers?
gold_answer: Yes, an affected person can refer a qualifying decision to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review, but you must also check whether the decision falls into the operational-decision exclusion and note that some non‑Part 21 decisions are still explicitly treated as referable. [#TGT:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23] [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea] The basic trigger is that the decision (including a decision made under these Regulations by the Regulator or Rules made by the Regulator) may affect the person’s rights or liabilities or otherwise adversely affect the person’s interests, and the referral is made by that person. [#TGT:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23] FSMR aligns with that trigger by stating that all of our decisions that meet the same adverse-effect standard may be referred for a full merits review, but it expressly excludes operational decisions from that route. [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea] FSMR also adds that certain other decisions that are not subject to the Part 21 procedure may nevertheless be referred for a full merits review, and it gives the exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers as an example of that type of decision. [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea] So, if the decision meets the adverse-impact test, referral is generally available, except where it is operational, and it may also be available for specified non‑Part 21 decisions such as Own‑Initiative Powers. [#TGT:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23] [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea]

question: For a Recognised Clearing House that is providing Central Counterparty Services, how do the Rules identified as applicable to it frame the specific operational capability it must maintain for segregation and portability, including the permitted account structures and the objective of portability when a Member or other participant defaults?
gold_answer: A Recognised Clearing House providing Central Counterparty Services is expressly subject to a set of identified Rules, including Rule 4.12 on segregation and portability, and it must implement operational arrangements that meet the segregation/portability outcomes described for that topic. [#SRC:6112097d-0f5d-40e8-9a64-1aa7b6b520a6] Concretely, it must have systems and procedures that allow segregation and portability of positions of the Clients of its Members and other participants on its facilities, together with any collateral provided to it in relation to those positions. [#TGT:9ca78053-40eb-4073-b9b8-df05a7009571] Those systems and procedures must support maintaining Client positions and related collateral either in individual Client accounts or in Omnibus Client Accounts, meaning the Recognised Clearing House must be able to operate either account model for the covered positions and collateral. [#TGT:9ca78053-40eb-4073-b9b8-df05a7009571] In addition, its portability arrangements must be structured so that, if a Member or other participant defaults, the defaulting Member’s or other participant’s Clients’ positions and collateral can be transferred to one or more other Members or participants. [#TGT:9ca78053-40eb-4073-b9b8-df05a7009571] This segregation-and-portability capability sits within the broader set of Rules applicable to such a Recognised Clearing House, which also includes stress testing of capital, credit risk, and collateral and margin requirements. [#SRC:6112097d-0f5d-40e8-9a64-1aa7b6b520a6]

question: If a Recognised Clearing House is providing Central Counterparty Services, what does it need to have in place to keep Clients’ positions and collateral separate and make them movable if a Member defaults, and which Rule is named as covering that topic in the list of applicable Rules?
gold_answer: For a Recognised Clearing House that is providing Central Counterparty Services, the applicable requirements are identified as being set out in specific Rules, including Rule 4.12 for segregation and portability. [#SRC:6112097d-0f5d-40e8-9a64-1aa7b6b520a6] To meet the segregation and portability outcome, it must have systems and procedures that enable segregation and portability of positions of the Clients of its Members and other participants on its facilities, along with any collateral provided to it in respect of those positions. [#TGT:9ca78053-40eb-4073-b9b8-df05a7009571] Those systems and procedures must allow the Recognised Clearing House to keep the relevant Client positions and related collateral either in individual Client accounts or in Omnibus Client Accounts, so it needs the capability to operate under either account structure. [#TGT:9ca78053-40eb-4073-b9b8-df05a7009571] It must also design its portability arrangements so that, when a Member or other participant defaults, the positions and collateral of that defaulting Member’s or other participant’s Clients can be transferred to one or more other Members or participants. [#TGT:9ca78053-40eb-4073-b9b8-df05a7009571] This is one element within the broader set of Rules stated as applicable to a Recognised Clearing House providing Central Counterparty Services. [#SRC:6112097d-0f5d-40e8-9a64-1aa7b6b520a6]

question: When assessing whether Behaviour that involves effecting transactions or orders to trade (other than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) has secured the price of a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity at an abnormal or artificial level, what specific indicators is the Regulator likely to consider to determine whether the conduct creates, or is likely to create, an artificial price?
gold_answer: Where Behaviour involves effecting transactions or orders to trade other than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market, it can be problematic if it secures the price of a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity at an abnormal or artificial level. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] In determining whether the conduct creates, or is likely to create, an artificial price, the Regulator is likely to evaluate concrete indicators tied to the person’s relationship to the instrument and observable price dynamics. [#SRC:96c3bd3c-9315-4058-adc7-295da9439bb1] Key indicators the Regulator is likely to take into account include: [#SRC:96c3bd3c-9315-4058-adc7-295da9439bb1] - The extent to which the person had a direct or indirect interest in the price or value of the relevant Financial Instrument, Accepted Virtual Asset or Accepted Spot Commodity. [#SRC:96c3bd3c-9315-4058-adc7-295da9439bb1] - Whether price, rate, or option-volatility movements (and the volatility of those factors) for the relevant product are outside their normal intra-day, daily, weekly, or monthly range. [#SRC:96c3bd3c-9315-4058-adc7-295da9439bb1] - Whether the person has successively and consistently increased or decreased their bid, Offer, or the price paid for the relevant product. [#SRC:96c3bd3c-9315-4058-adc7-295da9439bb1] These indicators help connect the transaction/order Behaviour to whether it is securing an abnormal or artificial price level rather than reflecting legitimate trading consistent with Accepted Market Practices. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f]

question: If someone places trades or orders that are not for legitimate reasons and not in line with Accepted Market Practices, and those trades could be making the price of a Financial Instrument, Accepted Virtual Asset, or Accepted Spot Commodity look abnormal or artificial, what kinds of signs would the Regulator look at to decide if the price is being made artificial?
gold_answer: If trades or orders are placed other than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market, the Behaviour is of concern where it secures the price of a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity at an abnormal or artificial level. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] To decide whether the conduct creates, or is likely to create, an artificial price, the Regulator is likely to look for specific, observable signs about the trader’s incentives and the way prices move. [#SRC:96c3bd3c-9315-4058-adc7-295da9439bb1] In practice, the Regulator is likely to consider: [#SRC:96c3bd3c-9315-4058-adc7-295da9439bb1] - Whether the person had a direct or indirect interest in the price or value of the relevant product. [#SRC:96c3bd3c-9315-4058-adc7-295da9439bb1] - Whether price, rate, or option-volatility movements (and the volatility of those factors) are outside the normal intra-day, daily, weekly, or monthly range for that product. [#SRC:96c3bd3c-9315-4058-adc7-295da9439bb1] - Whether the person repeatedly moved their bid, Offer, or the price they paid in one direction (up or down) in a successive and consistent way. [#SRC:96c3bd3c-9315-4058-adc7-295da9439bb1] These signs are used to assess whether the non-legitimate, non-AMP trading Behaviour is what is driving the abnormal or artificial price outcome. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f]

question: If a Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund wants to do the Fund’s administration work itself, what must be true about how risk management and portfolio work are set up, and what does the Fund Manager still have to do about managing the Fund’s risks (including thinking about Fund Administrators, Eligible Custodians, and any prime brokers)?
gold_answer: A Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund can only be in a position to perform fund administration for the Fund when the Fund’s risk management and portfolio functions are adequately separated. [#SRC:5cba2a1e-1340-4401-a5c7-23c937abe4fc] Even in that case, the Fund Manager must ensure that the risks inherent in operating the Fund are adequately addressed. [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7] When doing this, the Fund Manager must take into account (1) the nature of the strategies and investment process it uses and (2) the role played by Fund Administrators and Eligible Custodians and, if they are appointed, prime brokers. [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7] Put together, the setup requirement (separating risk management from portfolio functions) is what allows the Fund Manager to take on administration, but it does not remove the duty to actively address operational risks in a way that matches how the Fund is run and how these service-provider roles fit into the Fund’s operation. [#SRC:5cba2a1e-1340-4401-a5c7-23c937abe4fc] [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7] This means the Fund Manager should treat the administration role—whether performed internally or by others—as part of the overall risk picture it must manage. [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7]

question: When seeking authorisation under the RegLab, how should an applicant align its own proposed test parameters and control boundaries with the Regulator’s blank-sheet measures (including client/exposure limits and geographical restrictions) that may be imposed when Rules are waived or modified for a FinTech Participant?
gold_answer: An applicant should treat its authorisation submission as needing to both (i) define how it will run the test and (ii) accommodate the Regulator’s ability to constrain the test’s scope and client impact when Rules are waived or modified for the FinTech Participant under the RegLab. [#SRC:7fae4f73-f02a-415f-88c1-6b1aa4936e19] In practice, the applicant must be able to clearly define the FinTech Proposal’s test parameters and control boundaries (along with key milestones and intended outcomes), and those definitions should be framed so they can operate within client and exposure limits and any boundaries/geographical restrictions the Regulator sets to control client impact and protect clients’ interests. [#TGT:40054dfa-768b-4ece-ac91-c15c83f4f16d] [#SRC:7fae4f73-f02a-415f-88c1-6b1aa4936e19] The applicant should also propose an acceptable reporting schedule for updates on development and testing, which supports oversight of compliance with any imposed limits or restrictions during the test. [#TGT:40054dfa-768b-4ece-ac91-c15c83f4f16d] Finally, because the Regulator may prescribe conditions and/or limitations as part of authorisation, the applicant should present its test design and controls in a way that can be adjusted to meet those prescribed constraints while continuing to satisfy applicable ADGM Regulations and Rules. [#TGT:40054dfa-768b-4ece-ac91-c15c83f4f16d] [#SRC:7fae4f73-f02a-415f-88c1-6b1aa4936e19]

question: In a RegLab application, what combined showing is required regarding (i) the applicant’s resources/fitness/experience and (ii) the safeguards and client protections, given that the Regulator may waive or modify certain Rules and instead impose client/exposure limits and geographical boundaries to control client impact?
gold_answer: The applicant must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Regulator that it meets core capability criteria while also presenting client-protection measures that remain effective under a blank-sheet approach where some Rules may be waived or modified and replaced with tailored limits and restrictions. [#TGT:40054dfa-768b-4ece-ac91-c15c83f4f16d] [#SRC:7fae4f73-f02a-415f-88c1-6b1aa4936e19] On capability, the applicant must show it satisfies (and will continue to satisfy) Threshold Conditions, including having adequate and appropriate resources (including financial resources) to develop and test the FinTech Proposal, being fit and proper, and having relevant technical and business knowledge and experience. [#TGT:40054dfa-768b-4ece-ac91-c15c83f4f16d] On client protection, the applicant must detail safeguards in place and explain why they are appropriate to the FinTech Proposal being tested, the risks posed, and the type of clients likely to be affected—this should be articulated with awareness that the Regulator may set client and exposure limits and impose boundaries/geographical restrictions to control client impact and protect clients’ interests. [#TGT:40054dfa-768b-4ece-ac91-c15c83f4f16d] [#SRC:7fae4f73-f02a-415f-88c1-6b1aa4936e19] To complete the showing, the applicant should also be able to define test parameters/control boundaries and propose a reporting schedule, supporting monitoring of how safeguards operate within any imposed limits or restrictions. [#TGT:40054dfa-768b-4ece-ac91-c15c83f4f16d] [#SRC:7fae4f73-f02a-415f-88c1-6b1aa4936e19]

question: When a Relevant Person is deciding whether to give a customer a low-risk rating under 7.1.1(1) based on geographical or jurisdictional risk factors, which types of publications qualify as “credible sources” for identifying countries with effective AML systems or FATF-consistent requirements, and which organisations may issue those publications?
gold_answer: In a low-risk rating decision under 7.1.1(1), a Relevant Person may rely on “credible sources” when evaluating geographical and jurisdictional risk factors, such as whether countries are identified as having effective systems to counter money laundering, low levels of corruption or other criminal activity, or have been assessed as having AML requirements consistent with and effectively implementing the FATF Recommendations. [#TGT:644bee29-fba0-448c-a5c0-c58e957e6e90] For the purpose of determining what counts as a “credible source” in this context, credible sources include (without limitation) mutual evaluations, detailed assessment reports, and follow-up reports. [#SRC:0ab1cb10-020d-43a9-94ea-fd6de14133ff] Those reports may be issued by FATF, the IMF, the World Bank, the OECD, and other International Organisations. [#SRC:0ab1cb10-020d-43a9-94ea-fd6de14133ff] Accordingly, when the Relevant Person is using the geographic/jurisdictional indicators in paragraph (c) to support a low-risk rating, it should ensure the country conclusions it relies on are drawn from one or more of these report types and issuers, rather than from unspecified or informal materials. [#TGT:644bee29-fba0-448c-a5c0-c58e957e6e90] This approach aligns the “credible sources” concept with the specific kinds of assessments and follow-ups produced by the listed international bodies. [#SRC:0ab1cb10-020d-43a9-94ea-fd6de14133ff]

question: If you want to treat a customer as low risk because they do business in a lower-risk country, what country checks do you need to consider, and what kinds of documents from which organisations can you use as the “credible sources” for those checks?
gold_answer: To support a low-risk rating under 7.1.1(1) using geographical or jurisdictional factors, you should consider whether the relevant country or countries are identified by credible sources as having effective systems to counter money laundering, having low levels of corruption or other criminal activity (including terrorism, money laundering, or illicit drugs), and being assessed as having AML requirements consistent with and effectively implementing the FATF Recommendations. [#TGT:644bee29-fba0-448c-a5c0-c58e957e6e90] The “credible sources” you use for those country conclusions can include mutual evaluations, detailed assessment reports, and follow-up reports. [#SRC:0ab1cb10-020d-43a9-94ea-fd6de14133ff] These materials may be issued by FATF, the IMF, the World Bank, the OECD, and other International Organisations. [#SRC:0ab1cb10-020d-43a9-94ea-fd6de14133ff] Practically, that means your country-risk justification for a low-risk rating should be anchored in one or more of these recognised report types from the listed international bodies, and then mapped to the specific paragraph (c) country indicators you are relying on. [#TGT:644bee29-fba0-448c-a5c0-c58e957e6e90] This keeps the geographic “lower risk” rationale tied to documented assessments rather than unsupported assertions. [#TGT:644bee29-fba0-448c-a5c0-c58e957e6e90]

question: For an Authorised Person in any Category, how do the Rules allocate which provisions apply depending on whether it operates as a Branch or as a Domestic Firm, and what continuous capital-resources standard must be met when the Authorised Person operates as a Domestic Firm?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person in any Category must determine which specific Rules apply by reference to whether it is operating as a Branch or as a Domestic Firm, and that classification then drives the applicable obligations. [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6] If the Authorised Person is operating as a Branch, the allocation in this Section indicates that Rule 3.2.2 is the relevant provision for that operating model. [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6] If instead the Authorised Person is operating as a Domestic Firm, the allocation in this Section indicates that Rules 3.2.3 to 3.2.5 apply to that operating model. [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6] In addition to that allocation, where the Authorised Person is a Domestic Firm it must maintain adequate capital resources on a continuous basis: at all times, its Capital Resources must be equal to or greater than the amount of its Capital Requirement. [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e] This “at all times” condition is a standing requirement for Domestic Firms and therefore applies continuously for so long as the Authorised Person is operating as a Domestic Firm under the Section’s allocation. [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e] [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6]

question: If an Authorised Person changes how it operates (as a Branch vs as a Domestic Firm), which rule numbers apply in each case, and what does it have to keep meeting all the time when it is a Domestic Firm?
gold_answer: The applicable Rules in this Section depend on whether the Authorised Person is operating as a Branch or as a Domestic Firm, so the first step is to identify the operating model. [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6] When the Authorised Person operates as a Branch, the Section specifies that Rule 3.2.2 is the Rule that applies to it in that capacity. [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6] When the Authorised Person operates as a Domestic Firm, the Section specifies that Rules 3.2.3 to 3.2.5 apply to it in that capacity. [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6] For the Domestic Firm operating model, there is also an ongoing capital standard: the Authorised Person must have Capital Resources that are at least equal to its Capital Requirement, and it must meet that test at all times. [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e] This means the continuous “at all times” capital-resources threshold is tied to the Domestic Firm status identified in the Section’s allocation of Rules. [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e] [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6]

question: When a Reporting Entity is preparing a chapter 10 financial disclosure document that is scheduled for later release, under what circumstances may it refrain from early disclosure, and when must it instead make an immediate disclosure under Rule 7.2.1—taking into account both the Listing Authority’s expectations and the fact that Rule 7.2.1 operates closely with periodic/financial disclosure obligations and broader general disclosure regimes (e.g., FSMR and Prospectus Offer documents)?
gold_answer: A Reporting Entity may generally avoid disclosing information early in a document that is intended to be released on a scheduled date, but only where the Listing Authority’s stated conditions for that approach are satisfied; otherwise, Rule 7.2.1 can require immediate disclosure even while the document is still being prepared. [#SRC:e8a0c0b9-00fb-491e-988e-ef77853ed914] This interaction is particularly relevant because Rule 7.2.1 is described as operating closely with periodic/financial disclosure obligations in chapter 10 and also alongside broader general disclosure obligations (including regimes such as FSMR and disclosure documents like Prospectus Offer documents and bidders/targets statements). [#TGT:05f69230-1c8e-4359-98fe-2f92e40b5e8f] In practice, the Listing Authority does not generally expect early disclosure of information that will appear in the scheduled document if all limbs in Rule 7.2.2 are met, or if the Listing Authority does not view disclosure as necessary under Rule 7.5.1(b) to avoid a false market. [#SRC:e8a0c0b9-00fb-491e-988e-ef77853ed914] However, during preparation of a chapter 10 financial disclosure, Inside Information may emerge that should be disclosed immediately under Rule 7.2.1, notwithstanding the planned later release of the chapter 10 document. [#SRC:e8a0c0b9-00fb-491e-988e-ef77853ed914] Because Rule 7.2.1 is framed as closely integrated with chapter 10 and general disclosure regimes, the Reporting Entity should treat the continuous disclosure trigger as capable of overriding the normal timing of periodic or other disclosure documents when Inside Information comes to light. [#TGT:05f69230-1c8e-4359-98fe-2f92e40b5e8f]

question: If a Reporting Entity is working on a chapter 10 financial report that will be published later, when can it wait until the planned release date, and when does it have to disclose right away under Rule 7.2.1—given that Rule 7.2.1 is meant to work closely with chapter 10 reports and other general disclosure documents like Prospectus Offer documents?
gold_answer: The Reporting Entity can usually wait for the planned release date of the chapter 10 document, but only if the Listing Authority’s stated conditions for not disclosing early are met; otherwise, it may need to disclose immediately under Rule 7.2.1 even before the scheduled publication. [#SRC:e8a0c0b9-00fb-491e-988e-ef77853ed914] This timing question matters because Rule 7.2.1 is described as closely linked to chapter 10 periodic/financial disclosures and also to wider general disclosure obligations, including disclosure documents such as Prospectus Offer documents and bidders/targets statements. [#TGT:05f69230-1c8e-4359-98fe-2f92e40b5e8f] Specifically, the Listing Authority does not generally expect early disclosure of information that will appear in the scheduled document if all limbs in Rule 7.2.2 are satisfied, or if the Listing Authority does not consider disclosure necessary under Rule 7.5.1(b) to prevent a false market. [#SRC:e8a0c0b9-00fb-491e-988e-ef77853ed914] But there are situations where, while preparing a chapter 10 financial disclosure, Inside Information is discovered and should be disclosed immediately under Rule 7.2.1. [#SRC:e8a0c0b9-00fb-491e-988e-ef77853ed914] Because Rule 7.2.1 is intended to operate closely with both chapter 10 reporting and broader disclosure regimes, the Reporting Entity should treat the emergence of Inside Information as a trigger that can require immediate disclosure rather than waiting for the scheduled document release. [#TGT:05f69230-1c8e-4359-98fe-2f92e40b5e8f]

question: If a Captive Insurer is not a Cell Company and its Long-Term Insurance Business has to be put into a Long-Term Insurance Fund under Rule 8.2, can it just send a written notice saying it is one single fund, or can the Regulator still make it set up one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds (including for only part of the business)?
gold_answer: The Captive Insurer has two required compliance routes when it is not a Cell Company and it carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund under Rule 8.2: it must either establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds, or it must notify the Regulator in writing that the Captive Insurer is deemed to constitute a single Long-Term Insurance Fund. [#TGT:510a1a41-dd30-47bf-b331-893b2b70a469] Even if the Captive Insurer chooses the written-notice option, the Regulator still has residual discretion to direct that a Captive Insurer conducting Long-Term Insurance Business establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds for its Long-Term Insurance Business or any part of that business. [#SRC:f6bf482b-33ba-4cf1-9375-26e6bfeb7ca7] So, sending the written notice can satisfy the Captive Insurer’s “either/or” obligation as stated, but it does not prevent the Regulator from later requiring the Captive Insurer to create one or more separate Long-Term Insurance Funds, potentially limited to only part of the Long-Term Insurance Business. [#TGT:510a1a41-dd30-47bf-b331-893b2b70a469] [#SRC:f6bf482b-33ba-4cf1-9375-26e6bfeb7ca7] The key linkage is that the Captive Insurer’s default choice (funds or written notice) operates alongside, and can be superseded in scope, by the Regulator’s ability to direct fund establishment for the whole business or a portion of it. [#TGT:510a1a41-dd30-47bf-b331-893b2b70a469] [#SRC:f6bf482b-33ba-4cf1-9375-26e6bfeb7ca7]

question: Under what conditions may an Authorised Person classify a Person as a Market Counterparty, and what specific pre-classification notification and response-period checks must be completed before classifying a Professional Client as a Market Counterparty for a particular Regulated Activity or Transaction (or for all Regulated Activities and Transactions)?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may classify a Person as a Market Counterparty only where the Person meets the threshold status and the additional rule conditions, and the Authorised Person has completed the required pre-classification notice-and-response steps for the relevant scope of activities or transactions. [#SRC:fea099c3-b4b0-4ab5-8ad8-760375f23413] Specifically, the Person must qualify as a “deemed” Professional Client in accordance with Rule 2.4.2, and the requirements in Rule 2.5(b) must have been met. [#SRC:fea099c3-b4b0-4ab5-8ad8-760375f23413] In addition, before classifying a Professional Client as a Market Counterparty, the Authorised Person must ensure the Person has been provided with a prior written notification stating the intended classification as a Market Counterparty, and that notice must relate either to a particular Regulated Activity or Transaction or to all Regulated Activities and Transactions. [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3] The Authorised Person must also confirm that the Person has not asked to be classified otherwise within the period specified in that notice, meaning the classification should not proceed if such a request is made during the stated period. [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3]

question: When can an Authorised Person treat someone as a Market Counterparty, and what written notice and “wait to see if they ask for a different classification” step has to happen first (for one specific Regulated Activity/Transaction or for all of them)?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person can only classify a Person as a Market Counterparty if the Person meets the required client status and the additional rule conditions, and the Authorised Person has completed the required written-notice and response-period checks before making the classification. [#SRC:fea099c3-b4b0-4ab5-8ad8-760375f23413] On eligibility, the Person must qualify as a “deemed” Professional Client under Rule 2.4.2, and the requirements in Rule 2.5(b) must also be satisfied. [#SRC:fea099c3-b4b0-4ab5-8ad8-760375f23413] Separately, before classifying a Professional Client as a Market Counterparty, the Authorised Person must ensure the Person has received a prior written notification that they will be classified as a Market Counterparty, and the notice must specify whether this applies to a particular Regulated Activity or Transaction or instead applies across all Regulated Activities and Transactions. [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3] The Authorised Person must also check that the Person did not request a different classification within the time period stated in the notice; if they did request otherwise within that period, the precondition for proceeding is not met. [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3]

question: How does the FSRA determine whether a digital/virtual token offering is regulated as a Security, and how does that case-by-case assessment relate to the Regulator’s ability to deem a non-Security investment to be a Security by written notice (including any conditions attached)?
gold_answer: A digital/virtual token offering can be treated as regulated when the FSRA concludes, after a token-specific review, that the token has the economic and legal attributes of a Security; in that situation the FSRA treats the token as a “Digital Security” and therefore as a Security under the relevant FSMR provision. [#SRC:ad5b9e34-f66a-4e3f-8373-a85bdc331124] This assessment is explicitly conducted case by case, reflecting the FSRA’s approach to conventional Securities and acknowledging that the classification may not be obvious without FSRA review, with investor protection cited as a reason for this approach. [#SRC:ad5b9e34-f66a-4e3f-8373-a85bdc331124] In parallel, the Regulator has an express power to issue a written notice that deems an investment that is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and the Rules made under them. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] That written notice power may be exercised on terms and conditions the Regulator considers appropriate, which provides a mechanism to formalize or tailor the regulatory treatment when applying the Regulations and Rules. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] Read together, the FSRA’s case-by-case token characterization supplies the substantive basis for treating a token as a Security, while the Regulator’s written-notice deeming power supplies an explicit instrument (with conditions) for applying the Regulations and Rules to an investment treated as a Security. [#SRC:ad5b9e34-f66a-4e3f-8373-a85bdc331124] [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]

question: When compiling the document in the Resolution Pack that identifies individuals critical or important to operational functions, which specific roles related to Client Money, Relevant Money and Safe Custody Assets must be treated as examples of such individuals, and how must their responsibilities be described in that Resolution Pack document?
gold_answer: In the Resolution Pack, the Authorised Person must include a document that identifies all senior manager, directors and other individuals (whether within the Authorised Person or elsewhere) who are critical or important to operational functions connected to the chapter’s obligations, and it must also state the nature of each person’s responsibility. [#TGT:9a2f70fe-ca63-4b72-a573-f428b37a1a24] For the purpose of that identification requirement, examples of individuals who are critical or important include (i) those needed to perform both internal and external reconciliations for Client Money, Relevant Money and Safe Custody Assets, and (ii) those responsible for client documentation that involves Client Money, Relevant Money and Safe Custody Assets. [#SRC:ad131b2c-da04-4e5f-bbc4-045f5ec9fcf1] Accordingly, the Resolution Pack’s “critical individuals” document should not only list the relevant people, but should describe their responsibilities in a way that makes clear whether they carry out the internal/external reconciliation functions and/or oversee the relevant client documentation functions, including where those individuals sit outside the Authorised Person. [#TGT:9a2f70fe-ca63-4b72-a573-f428b37a1a24] [#SRC:ad131b2c-da04-4e5f-bbc4-045f5ec9fcf1]

question: In the Resolution Pack, there is a document that lists key people and what they do. Which kinds of people must be included as examples when the work involves Client Money, Relevant Money, or Safe Custody Assets, and what extra detail about them has to be written down?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person’s Resolution Pack must contain a document that identifies the senior manager, directors and other individuals (inside the Authorised Person or elsewhere) who are critical or important to operational functions tied to the chapter’s obligations, and it must describe the nature of each person’s responsibility. [#TGT:9a2f70fe-ca63-4b72-a573-f428b37a1a24] When the operational work relates to Client Money, Relevant Money, or Safe Custody Assets, examples of the kinds of “critical or important” individuals that should be captured include people who are necessary to complete both internal and external reconciliations for those monies/assets, and people who are in charge of client documentation that involves those monies/assets. [#SRC:ad131b2c-da04-4e5f-bbc4-045f5ec9fcf1] Putting these together, the Resolution Pack entry should (1) name the relevant individuals and (2) explain their responsibilities in a way that clearly links them to reconciliation activities and/or client documentation responsibilities, including where those individuals are located outside the Authorised Person. [#TGT:9a2f70fe-ca63-4b72-a573-f428b37a1a24] [#SRC:ad131b2c-da04-4e5f-bbc4-045f5ec9fcf1]

question: If a company is an Authorised Person, what does it need to have in place for risk management, and what might the FCA look at (besides doing its own assessment) to judge how likely each risk is and what controls the company has?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person needs to set up and keep risk management systems and controls that let it identify, assess, mitigate, control, and monitor its risks. [#TGT:6f83c3c2-989d-47c2-952e-b1d8c7fb6c21] In addition, the firm must make sure its risk management systems actually give it the means to carry out those activities—identifying, assessing, mitigating, monitoring, and controlling risks—rather than being merely formal documentation. [#SRC:f5c0b126-6b54-4fe9-9522-52952b6adad1] When the FCA reviews the firm, it may do more than just its own assessment: it may also review the firm’s internal risk self-assessment. [#SRC:f5c0b126-6b54-4fe9-9522-52952b6adad1] Using that internal self-assessment, the FCA may consider how much each risk affects the FCA’s objectives, how likely the risk is to happen, and what controls and mitigation programmes the firm has put in place. [#SRC:f5c0b126-6b54-4fe9-9522-52952b6adad1] So, the firm should ensure its internal risk self-assessment reflects the operation of its systems and controls and clearly describes the controls and mitigation programmes supporting risk identification through monitoring and control. [#TGT:6f83c3c2-989d-47c2-952e-b1d8c7fb6c21] [#SRC:f5c0b126-6b54-4fe9-9522-52952b6adad1]

question: For an applicant intending to carry on a Regulated Activity where the client is a Retail Client under GEN 5.2.3, what specific systems, controls, and related policies/procedures must an Authorised Person demonstrate when applying for a Financial Services Permission to carry on that Regulated Activity with or for a Retail Client?
gold_answer: An applicant in scope of GEN 5.2.3 (i.e., intending to carry on a Regulated Activity where the client is a Retail Client) must, when it is an Authorised Person applying for a Financial Services Permission to carry on that Regulated Activity with or for a Retail Client, be able to show that it meets the specified “adequate systems and controls” requirements. [#SRC:1ad61409-a8d2-40b0-82f6-0ab30250c45a] [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884] In practical terms, the application should evidence all of the following elements: - Adequate systems and controls for carrying on Regulated Activities with or for a Retail Client. [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884] - Adequate systems and controls, including policies and procedures, designed to ensure compliance with the COBS requirements that are relevant to Retail Clients. [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884] - Adequate systems and controls to ensure Employees remain competent and capable to perform assigned functions, with particular focus on functions involving dealing with Retail Clients. [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884] - Adequate Complaints handling policies and procedures. [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884] These items collectively describe the requirements that GEN 5.2.3 points to for an applicant in the Retail Client context, and they are framed as conditions for the Financial Services Permission application by an Authorised Person. [#SRC:1ad61409-a8d2-40b0-82f6-0ab30250c45a] [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884]

question: If a firm is applying as an Authorised Person for a Financial Services Permission to do a Regulated Activity with or for a Retail Client, and GEN 5.2.3 applies because the client is a Retail Client, what are the main things the firm needs to have in place (systems/controls and policies/procedures)?
gold_answer: Where GEN 5.2.3 applies because the applicant intends to carry on a Regulated Activity and the client is a Retail Client, the applicant (as an Authorised Person applying for a Financial Services Permission) needs to have specific “adequate systems and controls” and related policies/procedures in place for work with or for Retail Clients. [#SRC:1ad61409-a8d2-40b0-82f6-0ab30250c45a] [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884] The required items are: - Systems and controls that are adequate for carrying on Regulated Activities with or for a Retail Client. [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884] - Systems and controls (including policies and procedures) that are adequate to ensure compliance with COBS requirements that matter for Retail Clients. [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884] - Systems and controls that are adequate to keep Employees competent and capable for their assigned functions, especially functions that involve dealing with Retail Clients. [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884] - Complaints handling policies and procedures that are adequate. [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884] Together, these describe what the applicant must be able to demonstrate in the permission application for the Retail Client scenario covered by GEN 5.2.3. [#SRC:1ad61409-a8d2-40b0-82f6-0ab30250c45a] [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884]

question: For an Authorised Person that has established a branch outside ADGM from which it conducts Regulated Activities, how is the annual supervision fee determined and paid, and in what circumstance may the Regulator also charge a supplementary fee linked to the branch’s jurisdictional regulatory cooperation arrangements?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that has established a branch outside ADGM and conducts Regulated Activities from that branch is required to pay the Regulator an annual supervision fee calculated as 50% of the highest annual supervision fee applicable to the Regulated Activities it undertakes from the branch. [#TGT:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] For the first period, the initial supervision fee is not necessarily a full-year amount; it must be prorated and then paid following the approach specified in Rule 1.2.2(a). [#TGT:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] In addition to these supervision-fee obligations for the outside-ADGM branch, the Regulator may impose a supplementary fee where the proposed branch would operate in a jurisdiction that lacks an adequate memorandum of understanding between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator for that jurisdiction. [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92] This supplementary fee is described as being in addition to the fees specified in Rule 7.1.1 and 7.1.2, and it is triggered by the absence of adequate cross-regulator cooperation arrangements for the branch’s jurisdiction. [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92]

question: How should a Recognised Body structure its arrangements so that its monitoring and enforcement of compliance with its rules is complemented by procedures for handling complaints about Persons using its facilities and appeals against the Recognised Body’s decisions, including where the Recognised Body is a Recognised Investment Exchange monitoring transactions to detect disorderly trading conditions or Market Abuse?
gold_answer: A Recognised Body should implement a single, coherent set of arrangements that both (i) monitors and enforces compliance with its rules and (ii) provides formal procedures to address complaints and appeals arising from use of its facilities and its decision-making. [#TGT:2ab875a8-156c-4fce-8482-013f133be759] The monitoring and enforcement component must be effective, and where the Recognised Body is a Recognised Investment Exchange it must include effective transaction monitoring designed to identify disorderly trading conditions or Market Abuse. [#TGT:2ab875a8-156c-4fce-8482-013f133be759] In parallel, the arrangements must include procedures to investigate complaints made to the Recognised Body about the conduct of Persons when they are using the Recognised Body’s facilities. [#SRC:e5494e74-1e44-4fa9-8687-49f899851a47] The arrangements must also include procedures that ensure appeals against decisions of the Recognised Body are resolved in a manner that is fair, independent, and impartial. [#SRC:e5494e74-1e44-4fa9-8687-49f899851a47] Taken together, this means the Recognised Body’s compliance oversight (including transaction monitoring for a Recognised Investment Exchange) should be complemented by complaint-investigation and appeal-resolution processes so that issues detected through monitoring or raised by users can be examined and, where relevant, challenged through an impartial appeal mechanism. [#TGT:2ab875a8-156c-4fce-8482-013f133be759] [#SRC:e5494e74-1e44-4fa9-8687-49f899851a47]

question: If a Recognised Body is checking that people follow its rules (and, for a Recognised Investment Exchange, watching transactions to spot disorderly trading conditions or Market Abuse), what extra processes must it also have for complaints about Persons using its facilities and for appeals against its decisions?
gold_answer: A Recognised Body must pair its compliance oversight with formal complaint and appeal processes, so that rule compliance is actively monitored and enforced while users also have structured routes for raising concerns and challenging decisions. [#TGT:2ab875a8-156c-4fce-8482-013f133be759] Specifically, it must have effective arrangements to monitor and enforce compliance with its rules; and if it is a Recognised Investment Exchange, those arrangements must include effective monitoring of transactions to identify disorderly trading conditions or Market Abuse. [#TGT:2ab875a8-156c-4fce-8482-013f133be759] Alongside that monitoring/enforcement framework, the arrangements must include procedures to investigate complaints made to the Recognised Body about the conduct of Persons when they are using the Recognised Body’s facilities. [#SRC:e5494e74-1e44-4fa9-8687-49f899851a47] The arrangements must also include procedures for resolving appeals against decisions of the Recognised Body, and that appeal resolution must be fair, independent, and impartial. [#SRC:e5494e74-1e44-4fa9-8687-49f899851a47] In practice, this means the Recognised Body’s transaction or rule monitoring function should be complemented by a complaint-investigation track and an impartial appeal track, so issues can be addressed whether they arise from surveillance/enforcement activity or from complaints about facility use and subsequent decisions. [#TGT:2ab875a8-156c-4fce-8482-013f133be759] [#SRC:e5494e74-1e44-4fa9-8687-49f899851a47]

question: If an Authorised Person already runs an MTF using Virtual Assets and then becomes a Recognised Investment Exchange, what must happen to its FSP, and when the Recognition Order lets it keep running the MTF, which rule set applies to that MTF work?
gold_answer: In this scenario, the firm needs to handle both (1) the change in its licensing/recognition position and (2) the rule framework that applies to the MTF activity once it is carried on by a Recognised Investment Exchange. When an Authorised Person operating an MTF wishes to also operate a Recognised Investment Exchange, it must give up (relinquish) its FSP once it obtains the Recognition Order to operate as a Recognised Investment Exchange. [#SRC:16e6290e-4660-4e38-9618-89de6a251764] If the FSRA licenses the firm to do both activities at the same time (operating an MTF and operating a Recognised Investment Exchange), the Recognition Order is expected to include a stipulation stating that dual permission (noted as being pursuant to MIR Rule 3.4.1). [#SRC:16e6290e-4660-4e38-9618-89de6a251764] Separately, a Recognised Investment Exchange is allowed to operate an MTF (or OTF) only if its Recognition Order contains a stipulation permitting that Regulated Activity. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388] Where the stipulation is included, the COBS rules that specifically govern MTFs and OTFs apply to the MTF/OTF function, and they apply only to that function. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388]

question: Where a Third Party Provider is permitted to make unilateral changes to the Governing Contract, what combined notice content and minimum advance delivery timing must it meet when proposing changes to the existing terms or to the information specified in Rule 20.2.2, including how Customer acceptance is treated and any termination right before the changes take effect?
gold_answer: When a Third Party Provider is allowed to make unilateral changes to the Governing Contract and proposes changes, it must both (i) deliver the proposed changes within the required lead time and (ii) include specific customer-facing statements about deemed acceptance and termination rights. [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468] [#TGT:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f] For timing, proposed changes to either the existing terms of the Governing Contract or the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 must be provided to the Customer no later than two months before the date the changes are intended to take effect. [#TGT:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f] For notice content, the Third Party Provider must inform the Customer that, unless the Customer notifies the Third Party Provider to the contrary before the proposed entry-into-force date, the Customer will be treated as having accepted the changes that were communicated under Rule 20.2.5. [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468] It must also inform the Customer that the Customer may terminate the Governing Contract without charge at any time before the proposed entry-into-force date. [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468]

question: If the Third Party Provider can change the Governing Contract on its own, what does it have to tell the Customer about (1) when the changes must be sent and (2) what happens if the Customer does nothing, including whether the Customer can end the contract for free before the changes start?
gold_answer: If the Third Party Provider is permitted to make unilateral changes to the Governing Contract and it proposes changes, it must meet both an advance-notice deadline and specific customer disclosures about acceptance and termination. [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468] [#TGT:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f] On timing, any proposed changes to the existing terms of the Governing Contract or to the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 must be provided to the Customer at least two months before the date the changes are intended to take effect. [#TGT:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f] On what the Customer must be told, the Third Party Provider has to explain that the Customer will be treated as having accepted the changes (as communicated under Rule 20.2.5) unless the Customer tells the Third Party Provider otherwise before the proposed date the changes start. [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468] It also has to tell the Customer that the Customer can terminate the Governing Contract without charge at any time before that proposed start date. [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468]

question: When an Issuer is considering either (i) making an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM or (ii) seeking admission of Securities to trading on a RIE/Recognised Investment Exchange, what is the combined prohibition and what is the stated compliance pathway/exception that permits the activity?
gold_answer: An Issuer is prohibited from making an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, and is likewise prohibited from having Securities admitted to trading on a RIE, unless the activity is carried out in the manner the applicable framework allows. [#SRC:5f3625e1-2e7d-4bc8-b5e4-a0649ca42237] The general rule is framed as a “shall not” restriction on any person making an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or arranging for Securities to be admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange. [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a] For an Issuer specifically, the SOURCE clarifies that the prohibition applies to Offers of Securities to the Public made in or from ADGM and to admissions to trading on a RIE, and it identifies the permitted route as doing so only in accordance with FSMR and MKT. [#SRC:5f3625e1-2e7d-4bc8-b5e4-a0649ca42237] The TARGET provides the complementary exception structure: the prohibition is lifted only where the action is “provided by or under these Regulations,” meaning the Regulations themselves must contain the enabling basis for the Offer or admission. [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a] Read together, the compliance pathway is that an Issuer may proceed only where the Regulations permit it and where the Issuer follows the FSMR and MKT requirements identified for such Offers/admissions. [#SRC:5f3625e1-2e7d-4bc8-b5e4-a0649ca42237] [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a]

question: If someone wants to make an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market, and an Issuer wants to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM (or get Securities admitted to trading on a RIE), what do the rules say they can and cannot do, and what is the allowed way to do it?
gold_answer: The rules set a baseline ban: a person is not allowed to make an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or to have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange unless the Regulations themselves allow it. [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a] For Issuers, the restriction is described in the specific context of “Offers of Securities to the Public” made in or from ADGM, and it also covers the scenario where the Issuer has Securities admitted to trading on a RIE. [#SRC:5f3625e1-2e7d-4bc8-b5e4-a0649ca42237] The permitted route is not a free choice: the Issuer may only proceed if it does so in accordance with the governing framework identified for these activities. [#SRC:5f3625e1-2e7d-4bc8-b5e4-a0649ca42237] In parallel, the general exception language requires that the Offer or admission must be “provided by or under these Regulations,” so the legal basis must come from the Regulations rather than from the person’s preference. [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a] Putting both together, an Issuer (and any person) must treat Offers in ADGM and admissions to trading as prohibited by default and only proceed where the Regulations permit it and, for Issuers, where the activity is carried out in line with FSMR and MKT. [#SRC:5f3625e1-2e7d-4bc8-b5e4-a0649ca42237] [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a]

question: How should an Authorised Person be categorised where its Financial Services Permission includes Managing Assets and it also undertakes Dealing in Investments as Agent, but only in a way that is wholly incidental to Managing Assets; and how does that interact with the Category 2 test for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal) and the requirement that dealing activities are not limited in scope?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person should be treated as falling within Category 3C (rather than Category 3A) if it carries out Dealing in Investments as Agent only in a manner that is wholly incidental to Managing Assets, and it otherwise meets the Category 3C conditions. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] Category 3C applies where the Financial Services Permission authorises one or more specified Regulated Activities, including Managing Assets, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5. [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0] The “wholly incidental” linkage is important because, although Category 3A is generally determined by authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Agent (and the absence of certain other authorisations), the text expressly directs that incidental Dealing in Investments as Agent alongside Managing Assets results in Category 3C treatment. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] Separately, Category 2 is triggered by authorisation for Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal), combined with dealing activities that are not limited in scope, and the firm not meeting Categories 1 or 5. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] Therefore, to remain in Category 3C, the firm must not meet the Category 2 criteria while satisfying the Category 3C conditions tied to Managing Assets and the exclusion of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B and 5. [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0]

question: If an Authorised Person is allowed to do Managing a Collective Investment Fund and also does Dealing in Investments as Agent only as a small, wholly incidental part of that work, which category should it be in, and what would make it Category 2 instead?
gold_answer: It should be regarded as Category 3C if it carries out Dealing in Investments as Agent only in a manner that is wholly incidental to Managing an Investment Fund (or Managing Assets), and it otherwise fits the Category 3C definition. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] Category 3C covers an Authorised Person whose Financial Services Permission authorises one or more listed Regulated Activities, including Managing a Collective Investment Fund, provided it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5.
